All hands, battle stations. I hope we won't need your services, Bones.", 'Battle status?', 'Plot his exact point of entry, Mister Stiles.', "The moment he begins entering the comet's tail, he becomes visible. End run, gentlemen. We'll swing around the other side and catch him at that moment.", "Let's get him, Mister Sulu.", 'Steady as she goes. Phaser crews ready?', "He'll only be visible for a moment. Stand by.", 'At the last moment he must have guessed our move. Hard to starboard, helm!', "He did exactly what I would have done. I won't underestimate him again. Now, fire blind. Lay down a pattern.", 'Full astern! Emergency warp speed!', 'Do we have emergency warp?', 'Navigation?', 'Phasers, Mister Spock?', 'Feed this to the space recorder and jettison immediately.', 'Yeoman. Affirmative. Continue log entries.', 'Limited range.', 'Back to his old course.', "I wouldn't make that assumption. I don't think their Captain will either.", 'Same as before, Mister Sulu. Stay with him.', "Let's get them while we are. Before we enter the Neutral Zone. Full ahead, Mister Sulu. Maximum warp.", 'Phasers, stand by.', 'We know their Achilles heel, Mister Stiles. Their weapon takes all their energy. They must become visible in order to launch it.', "I'm aware of that, Mister Stiles. Are phasers ready?", 'Lieutenant Uhura, inform Command base, In my opinion, no option. On my responsibility, we are proceeding into the Neutral Zone. Steady as we go, Mister Sulu. Continue firing.', 'Cease fire.', 'However?', 'What?', 'Go to sensor probes.', 'All right, Mister Spock, work quietly.', "Thank you, Yeoman. Bring it to the Bridge. I'll be there in a moment.", "I wish I were on a long sea voyage somewhere. Not too much deck tennis, no frantic dancing, and no responsibility. Why me? I look around that Bridge, and I see the men waiting for me to make the next move. And Bones, what if I'm wrong?", "No, I don't really expect an answer.", "It's all right. It's all right.", "Power on. Reverse course. He'll try to slip under us.", 'Phasers, fire.', 'Cease fire.', 'Analysis, quickly.', 'Helm, hard over. Phasers, fire point-blank.', 'Captain to Sickbay.', 'Casualties?', 'Thank you, Doctor. Report, Mister Spock?', 'Ship damage?', 'Weapons status?', 'Fully operable, Scotty?', 'Go. Lieutenant Uhura, take over navigation.', 'Maybe we can pull them back to our side of the Neutral Zone. Hold our position. Play dead.', 'Forward phasers, stand by. Fire! Fire! Stiles, can you hear me? Fire!', 'Fire! Stiles, can you hear me? Fire!', 'Fire!', 'Stiles, can you hear me? Fire! Stiles!', 'Mister Sulu, prepare to move in on the Romulan vessel. Ship-to-ship, Uhura. Put this on the screen.', 'Captain. Standing by to beam your survivors aboard our ship. Prepare to abandon your vessel.', 'What purpose will it serve to die?', 'Are you all right, Mister Spock?', 'And you, Stiles?', 'How many men did we lose, Bones?', 'It never makes any sense. We both have to know that there was a reason.']
Flattened Dialogue: Good. Kirk here. Maintain course to outpost four. Keep me informed. Kirk out. Since the days of the first wooden vessels, all shipmasters have had one happy privilege. That of uniting two people in the bonds of matrimony. We are gathered here today with you, Angela Martine, and you, Robert Tomlinson, in the sight of your fellows, in accordance with our laws and our many beliefs so that you may pledge your Kirk here. Full ahead. All decks, condition red. Scotty. Did Outpost 4 give anything at all on the attacking vessel, Lieutenant? Mister Spock, put this star sector on our screen. Now show our position. Signal this to all decks, Lieutenant. This is the Captain speaking. In our next action, we can risk neither miscalculation nor error By any man aboard. Listen carefully. Science Officer. What you do not know and must be told is that my command orders on this subject are precise and inviolable. No act, no provocation Will be considered sufficient reason to violate the zone. We may defend ourselves, But if necessary to avoid interspace war, Both these outposts and this vessel will be considered expendable. Captain out. After a whole century, what will a Romulan ship look like, Mister Stiles? I doubt they'll radio and identify themselves. I had no idea that history was your specialty. Their war, Mister Stiles. Not yours. Don't forget it. Outpost 2 was the first to go silent, Lieutenant? Open a channel to our nearest command base. Quarter hour reports on our position and status. Call battle stations, Mister Sulu. Energise main phasers, Mister Styles. All weapons to full power. Kirk here. We're minutes away, Hansen. What's your status? Confirm what hit you, Hansen. What vessel? Identity? Can you locate the intruder for us? Tie us in. Affirmative. You're visual, Hansen. What do you have on the intruder? Lock us onto your screen. Do you have phaser capacity? We're still out of range. Make a challenge. Warn that ship off. Position of the intruder, Mister Spock. Go to full magnification. I don't see anything. I can't understand it. Discontinue. Contact remaining outposts. Have them signal us any sightings or sensor readings in their area. Their invisibility screen may work both ways. With that kind of power consumption, they may not be able to see us. Parallel course. Negative. You and Mister Sulu will match its course and speed with the object on our sensors exactly, move for move. If he has sensors, I want him to think we're a reflection, an echo. Under no circumstances are you to cross into the Neutral Zone without my direct orders. Cancel battle stations. All decks, standby alert. Mister Stiles. Mister Stiles, are you questioning my orders? Very well. All decks, security alert. Pipe it in. Put it on the screen. I didn't quite get that, Mister Stiles. Repeat it. I assume you're complimenting Mister Spock on his ability to decode. Well, here's one thing you can be sure of, Mister. Leave any bigotry in your quarters. There's no room for it on the Bridge. Do I make myself clear? Stay with him, helm. What's our position, navigator? Bring it to the briefing room. Are you ready, gentlemen? Comments? Yes, well gentlemen, the question still remains. Can we engage them with a reasonable possibility of victory? Meaning we can outrun them? Go ahead, Mister Styles. I called this session for opinions. Explain. Sit down, Mister. Are you suggesting we fight to prevent a fight? Captain to Bridge. What's our position? Are you continuing to broadcast tactical reports? And at this distance? Thank you, Lieutenant. Check our course ahead, Mister Spock. Comet Icarus four. Composition? And when an object passes through it, even an invisible object? Our chance, gentlemen. Prepare to attack. All hands, battle stations. I hope we won't need your services, Bones. Battle status? Plot his exact point of entry, Mister Stiles. The moment he begins entering the comet's tail, he becomes visible. End run, gentlemen. We'll swing around the other side and catch him at that moment. Let's get him, Mister Sulu. Steady as she goes. Phaser crews ready? He'll only be visible for a moment. Stand by. At the last moment he must have guessed our move. Hard to starboard, helm! He did exactly what I would have done. I won't underestimate him again. Now, fire blind. Lay down a pattern. Full astern! Emergency warp speed! Do we have emergency warp? Navigation? Phasers, Mister Spock? Feed this to the space recorder and jettison immediately. Yeoman. Affirmative. Continue log entries. Limited range. Back to his old course. I wouldn't make that assumption. I don't think their Captain will either. Same as before, Mister Sulu. Stay with him. Let's get them while we are. Before we enter the Neutral Zone. Full ahead, Mister Sulu. Maximum warp. Phasers, stand by. We know their Achilles heel, Mister Stiles. Their weapon takes all their energy. They must become visible in order to launch it. I'm aware of that, Mister Stiles. Are phasers ready? Lieutenant Uhura, inform Command base, In my opinion, no option. On my responsibility, we are proceeding into the Neutral Zone. Steady as we go, Mister Sulu. Continue firing. Cease fire. However? What? Go to sensor probes. All right, Mister Spock, work quietly. Thank you, Yeoman. Bring it to the Bridge. I'll be there in a moment. I wish I were on a long sea voyage somewhere. Not too much deck tennis, no frantic dancing, and no responsibility. Why me? I look around that Bridge, and I see the men waiting for me to make the next move. And Bones, what if I'm wrong? No, I don't really expect an answer. It's all right. It's all right. Power on. Reverse course. He'll try to slip under us. Phasers, fire. Cease fire. Analysis, quickly. Helm, hard over. Phasers, fire point-blank. Captain to Sickbay. Casualties? Thank you, Doctor. Report, Mister Spock? Ship damage? Weapons status? Fully operable, Scotty? Go. Lieutenant Uhura, take over navigation. Maybe we can pull them back to our side of the Neutral Zone. Hold our position. Play dead. Forward phasers, stand by. Fire! Fire! Stiles, can you hear me? Fire! Fire! Stiles, can you hear me? Fire! Fire! Stiles, can you hear me? Fire! Stiles! Mister Sulu, prepare to move in on the Romulan vessel. Ship-to-ship, Uhura. Put this on the screen. Captain. Standing by to beam your survivors aboard our ship. Prepare to abandon your vessel. What purpose will it serve to die? Are you all right, Mister Spock? And you, Stiles? How many men did we lose, Bones? It never makes any sense. We both have to know that there was a reason.

Title: Balance of Terror
Dialogue: ['There was a call for you from the Bridge.', "You're discussing tactics. Do you realise what this really comes down to? Millions and millions of lives hanging on what this vessel does.", "Based on what? Memories of a war over a century ago? On theories about a people we've never even met face to face?", 'War is never imperative, Mister Spock.', "Amen to that. We're taking a big gamble, Jim.", 'Do we violate the treaty, Captain?', 'Once inside, they can claim we did. A set-up. They want war, we furnish the provocation.', 'Captain, I', "But I've got one. Something I seldom say to a customer, Jim. In this galaxy, there's a mathematical probability of three million Earth-type planets. And in all of the universe, three million million galaxies like this. And in all of that, and perhaps more, only one of each of us. Don't destroy the one named Kirk.", 'McCoy here.', "Twenty two so far. Mainly radiation burns, mostly from the ship's outer areas. Could have been much, much worse, Captain.", 'Only one. Tomlinson. The boy who was getting married this morning. His fiance is at the chapel.']
Flattened Dialogue: There was a call for you from the Bridge. You're discussing tactics. Do you realise what this really comes down to? Millions and millions of lives hanging on what this vessel does. Based on what? Memories of a war over a century ago? On theories about a people we've never even met face to face? War is never imperative, Mister Spock. Amen to that. We're taking a big gamble, Jim. Do we violate the treaty, Captain? Once inside, they can claim we did. A set-up. They want war, we furnish the provocation. Captain, I But I've got one. Something I seldom say to a customer, Jim. In this galaxy, there's a mathematical probability of three million Earth-type planets. And in all of the universe, three million million galaxies like this. And in all of that, and perhaps more, only one of each of us. Don't destroy the one named Kirk. McCoy here. Twenty two so far. Mainly radiation burns, mostly from the ship's outer areas. Could have been much, much worse, Captain. Only one. Tomlinson. The boy who was getting married this morning. His fiance is at the chapel.

Title: Balance of Terror
Dialogue: ["Still no answer from Earth Outpost number two, Captain, and now number three's gone silent.", "Earth Outpost four reports they're under attack. A space vessel, identity unknown.", 'Verified, Captain.', 'Referring to the map on your screens, you will note beyond the moving position of our vessel, a line of Earth outpost stations. Constructed on asteroids, they monitor the Neutral Zone established by treaty after the Earth-Romulan conflict a century ago.', 'As you may recall from your histories, this conflict was fought,', 'By our standards today, with primitive atomic weapons and in primitive space vessels', 'Which allowed no quarter, no captives. Nor was there even ship-to-ship visual communication. Therefore, no human, Romulan, or ally has ever seen the other. Earth believes the Romulans to be warlike, cruel, treacherous, and only the Romulans know what they think of Earth. The treaty, set by sub-space radio, established this Neutral Zone, entry into which by either side, would constitute an act of war. The treaty has been unbroken since that time. Captain.', 'Outpost two coming into sensor range, Captain.', 'Sweeping the area of Outpost two. Sensor reading indefinite. Double-checking Outpost three. I read dust and debris. Both Earth outposts gone, and the asteroids they were constructed on, pulverised.', "And showing on my sensors, Captain. At least it's still there.", 'Outpost four disintegrated, Captain.', 'Disappeared. Interesting how they became visible for just a moment.', 'Invisibility is theoretically possible, Captain, with selective bending of light. But the power cost is enormous.', 'Blip has changed its heading. And in a very leisurely manoeuvre. They may not be aware of us.', 'His heading is now one eleven mark fourteen. The exact heading a Romulan would take, Jim, for the Neutral Zone and home.', 'I have a fix on it, Captain. I believe I can lock on it, get a picture of their Bridge.', 'Very well.', 'Steady on one eleven mark fourteen. Back on their original course, Captain, toward the Neutral Zone.', "From the outpost's protective shield. Cast rodinium. This is the hardest substance known to our science.", 'Lab theorises an enveloping energy plasma forcing an implosion.', 'Obviously, their weaponry is superior to ours, and they have a practical invisibility screen.', 'Or on what this vessel fails to do, Doctor.', 'I agree. Attack.', 'Yes, indeed we do, Mister Stiles. And if Romulans are an offshoot of my Vulcan blood, and I think this likely, then attack becomes even more imperative.', 'It is for them, Doctor. Vulcan, like Earth, had its aggressive colonising period. Savage, even by Earth standards. And if Romulans retain this martial philosophy, then weakness is something we dare not show.', 'Do you want a galactic war on your conscience?', 'A comet, magnitude seven, dead ahead, and the intruder changing course toward it.', 'Quite ordinary. An ionised mass, a trail of frozen vapour particles.', 'It leaves a visible trail.', "Intruder now bearing directly for comet's tail.", "He's maintaining that bearing, Captain.", "We're losing sensor contact, Captain.", "It'll take time to correct, sir.", 'Impossible, Captain.', 'Phasers operational, Captain. Intruder bearing one eleven mark fourteen.', "He may think we're destroyed, Captain.", 'Intruder holding steady. Course one eleven mark fourteen.', 'They did, Doctor.', "We're still on our side, Captain.", 'Motion sensor signal stopped.', 'Vessel wreckage. Metal moulds, conduit, plastoform and a body, Captain. However.', 'Insufficient mass, sir.', 'Simple debris. Not a vessel, a trick.', "Nothing, sir. No motion out there at all. We've lost them, Captain.", "Captain, I must make further repairs on the transfer coil. It's giving out again.", 'Debris on our scanners.', 'Same type as before, sir, except, one metal-cased object!', 'Nuclear device of some kind, sir. Our phasers detonated it less than one hundred metres away.', 'Mainly overloads and circuit burnouts.', "We have engine power now, Captain, if you'd like to move off and make repairs.", 'Damage reports, Mister Stiles?', 'Will you require assistance here?', 'Yes, very well, thank you, Captain.', 'I saved a trained navigator so he could return to duty. I am capable of no other feelings in such matters.']
Flattened Dialogue: Still no answer from Earth Outpost number two, Captain, and now number three's gone silent. Earth Outpost four reports they're under attack. A space vessel, identity unknown. Verified, Captain. Referring to the map on your screens, you will note beyond the moving position of our vessel, a line of Earth outpost stations. Constructed on asteroids, they monitor the Neutral Zone established by treaty after the Earth-Romulan conflict a century ago. As you may recall from your histories, this conflict was fought, By our standards today, with primitive atomic weapons and in primitive space vessels Which allowed no quarter, no captives. Nor was there even ship-to-ship visual communication. Therefore, no human, Romulan, or ally has ever seen the other. Earth believes the Romulans to be warlike, cruel, treacherous, and only the Romulans know what they think of Earth. The treaty, set by sub-space radio, established this Neutral Zone, entry into which by either side, would constitute an act of war. The treaty has been unbroken since that time. Captain. Outpost two coming into sensor range, Captain. Sweeping the area of Outpost two. Sensor reading indefinite. Double-checking Outpost three. I read dust and debris. Both Earth outposts gone, and the asteroids they were constructed on, pulverised. And showing on my sensors, Captain. At least it's still there. Outpost four disintegrated, Captain. Disappeared. Interesting how they became visible for just a moment. Invisibility is theoretically possible, Captain, with selective bending of light. But the power cost is enormous. Blip has changed its heading. And in a very leisurely manoeuvre. They may not be aware of us. His heading is now one eleven mark fourteen. The exact heading a Romulan would take, Jim, for the Neutral Zone and home. I have a fix on it, Captain. I believe I can lock on it, get a picture of their Bridge. Very well. Steady on one eleven mark fourteen. Back on their original course, Captain, toward the Neutral Zone. From the outpost's protective shield. Cast rodinium. This is the hardest substance known to our science. Lab theorises an enveloping energy plasma forcing an implosion. Obviously, their weaponry is superior to ours, and they have a practical invisibility screen. Or on what this vessel fails to do, Doctor. I agree. Attack. Yes, indeed we do, Mister Stiles. And if Romulans are an offshoot of my Vulcan blood, and I think this likely, then attack becomes even more imperative. It is for them, Doctor. Vulcan, like Earth, had its aggressive colonising period. Savage, even by Earth standards. And if Romulans retain this martial philosophy, then weakness is something we dare not show. Do you want a galactic war on your conscience? A comet, magnitude seven, dead ahead, and the intruder changing course toward it. Quite ordinary. An ionised mass, a trail of frozen vapour particles. It leaves a visible trail. Intruder now bearing directly for comet's tail. He's maintaining that bearing, Captain. We're losing sensor contact, Captain. It'll take time to correct, sir. Impossible, Captain. Phasers operational, Captain. Intruder bearing one eleven mark fourteen. He may think we're destroyed, Captain. Intruder holding steady. Course one eleven mark fourteen. They did, Doctor. We're still on our side, Captain. Motion sensor signal stopped. Vessel wreckage. Metal moulds, conduit, plastoform and a body, Captain. However. Insufficient mass, sir. Simple debris. Not a vessel, a trick. Nothing, sir. No motion out there at all. We've lost them, Captain. Captain, I must make further repairs on the transfer coil. It's giving out again. Debris on our scanners. Same type as before, sir, except, one metal-cased object! Nuclear device of some kind, sir. Our phasers detonated it less than one hundred metres away. Mainly overloads and circuit burnouts. We have engine power now, Captain, if you'd like to move off and make repairs. Damage reports, Mister Stiles? Will you require assistance here? Yes, very well, thank you, Captain. I saved a trained navigator so he could return to duty. I am capable of no other feelings in such matters.

Title: Balance of Terror
Dialogue: ['Alert! Alert! All decks alert! Alert! Alert! Captain to the Bridge. All decks alert.', 'All decks, condition red. All decks, condition red.', 'Our speed is now maximum, sir.', 'Battle stations. All hands to battle stations. Battle stations. Battle stations. All decks acknowledge. All decks acknowledge, sir. All stations show green.', 'Screen is on full mag, sir.', 'Acknowledged, sir.', 'Cancel battle stations.', 'I agree, sir. Respectfully recommend all decks maintain security alert.', 'Security alert, sir.', "Something visual ahead, Captain, at extreme range. He's changing course, sir.", 'Turning, sir.', "They're turning, sir. We're staying with them.", 'Attack, without a visible target? How do we aim our phasers?', 'And hope for a lucky shot before they zero in on us?', 'And if they could report they destroyed us?', 'All stations manned, Captain.', 'Acknowledged, Captain.', 'Phaser crew signal ready, sir.', 'Sir, nothing in', 'Hard to starboard.', 'Phaser overload. Control circuit burnout.', 'Captain, are they surrendering?', "Full power, sir. It's still overtaking us. If we can get one phaser working, sir, one shot might detonate it.", "Ten seconds to impact. Captain, It's dissipating, sir.", 'Five, four, three, two, one. Impact!', 'Ahead, sir. Maximum.', "Debris scatter ahead, sir. We've hit him.", 'Lateral power, sir.', 'More wreckage, sir, scattering across our path.', 'Enemy vessel becoming visible, sir.']
Flattened Dialogue: Alert! Alert! All decks alert! Alert! Alert! Captain to the Bridge. All decks alert. All decks, condition red. All decks, condition red. Our speed is now maximum, sir. Battle stations. All hands to battle stations. Battle stations. Battle stations. All decks acknowledge. All decks acknowledge, sir. All stations show green. Screen is on full mag, sir. Acknowledged, sir. Cancel battle stations. I agree, sir. Respectfully recommend all decks maintain security alert. Security alert, sir. Something visual ahead, Captain, at extreme range. He's changing course, sir. Turning, sir. They're turning, sir. We're staying with them. Attack, without a visible target? How do we aim our phasers? And hope for a lucky shot before they zero in on us? And if they could report they destroyed us? All stations manned, Captain. Acknowledged, Captain. Phaser crew signal ready, sir. Sir, nothing in Hard to starboard. Phaser overload. Control circuit burnout. Captain, are they surrendering? Full power, sir. It's still overtaking us. If we can get one phaser working, sir, one shot might detonate it. Ten seconds to impact. Captain, It's dissipating, sir. Five, four, three, two, one. Impact! Ahead, sir. Maximum. Debris scatter ahead, sir. We've hit him. Lateral power, sir. More wreckage, sir, scattering across our path. Enemy vessel becoming visible, sir.

Title: Balance of Terror
Dialogue: ['Outpost 4 reported under attack, sir. Then message terminates.', 'No identification, sir.', 'All decks standing by, sir.', 'Yes, Captain, then Outpost three an hour later.', 'Yes, sir.', 'Sir, regaining contact with Outpost four. Switching to speakers.', 'Tied in, sir.', "Trying to, sir. They don't acknowledge.", 'Continuing to challenge, sir. Still no response.', 'Yes, sir.', "Picking up communication. It's from their ship.", 'Sounds like code, sir.', 'Cryptography is working on it, sir.', 'Transmission has been cut off. I made a tape of it, sir.', 'This is Uhura, Captain.', 'Course unchanged, sir. Estimating treaty boundary in twenty one minutes.', 'Affirmative, Captain.', 'Approximately three hours before receiving a reply to our first message.', 'Yes, Captain.', 'Hailing frequencies open, sir.']
Flattened Dialogue: Outpost 4 reported under attack, sir. Then message terminates. No identification, sir. All decks standing by, sir. Yes, Captain, then Outpost three an hour later. Yes, sir. Sir, regaining contact with Outpost four. Switching to speakers. Tied in, sir. Trying to, sir. They don't acknowledge. Continuing to challenge, sir. Still no response. Yes, sir. Picking up communication. It's from their ship. Sounds like code, sir. Cryptography is working on it, sir. Transmission has been cut off. I made a tape of it, sir. This is Uhura, Captain. Course unchanged, sir. Estimating treaty boundary in twenty one minutes. Affirmative, Captain. Approximately three hours before receiving a reply to our first message. Yes, Captain. Hailing frequencies open, sir.

Title: Shore Leave
Dialogue: ['Anything from the landing party?', "A kink in my back. That's it. A little higher, please. Push. Push hard. Dig it in there, Mister", "Thank you, Yeoman. That's sufficient.", 'I have enough of that from Doctor McCoy, Yeoman. Thank you.', "Have Doctor McCoy's report channeled to my quarters, Lieutenant.", "Captain's log. Stardate 3025 er, point 3. We are orbiting an uninhabited planet in the Omicron Delta region. A planet remarkably like Earth, or how we remember Earth to be. Park-like, beautiful, green, flowers, trees, green lawn, quiet and restful. Almost too good to be true.", "I may be tired, Yeoman, but I'm not falling apart. Dismissed.", "Mister Spock, we're beaming down the starboard section first. Which section would you like to go with?", 'Kirk here.', 'Yes. Open a channel, Uhura.', "I hadn't planned to, Bones. Why?", 'Explain.', "That's pretty good. I got one for you. The rabbit was followed by a little blonde girl, right?", "All right, Doctor, I'll take your report under consideration. Captain out. That's a McCoy pill, with a little mystery sugar-coating. He wants to get me down there. I'm afraid I won't swallow it.", 'Yes, Mister Spock, what is it?', "That's much too low a rating.", "A crewman's right ends where the safety of the ship begins. That man will go a shore on my orders. What's his name?", 'Rodriguez, Teller, everything all right?', "Good. That should be sufficient. Beam it up to Mister Spock when you're ready, and start enjoying yourselves.", 'Thank you.', "Restful. After what we've been through, it's hard to believe a place this beautiful exists.", 'McCoy! McCoy!', 'Bones, know any good rabbit jokes lately?', 'Footprints. Could be a rabbit. It would have to be an unusual creature to make this size tracks. What about Mister Sulu? Will he confirm what you saw?', 'Bridge, this is the Captain.', 'Has the first shore party beamed down yet?', 'Get this message to all shore parties. Stand by. No one is to leave the ship.', "You're the doctor, Doctor. Can you explain this?", "Neither can I. I admit it looks harmless. It probably is harmless. But before I bring my people down here, I want proof it's harmless.", "What do you think you're doing?", 'Where did you get it, Mister Sulu?', 'Mister Sulu.', "I'll hang on to it. The fresh air seems to have made you trigger-happy.", "Are you sure our instruments didn't show any animal life on this planet?", "I'd like to believe this is an elaborate gag, but. Yeoman Barrows, you accompany Mister Sulu. Find out where those tracks came from. Doctor, you come with me back to the glade. I'd like another look at that area.", 'This is turning out to be one very unusual shore leave.', 'How?', "What's the matter, Bones, you getting a persecution complex?", 'I know the feeling very well. I had it at the Academy. An upper classman there. One practical joke after another, and always on me. My own personal devil. A guy by the name of Finnegan.', "Serious? I'll make a confession, Bones. I was absolutely grim, which delighted Finnegan no end. He's the kind of guy to put a bowl of cold soup in your bed or a bucket of water propped on a half-open door. You never knew where he'd strike next. More tracks. Looks like your rabbit came from over there.", "Yes. You follow the rabbit. I'll backtrack the girl. I'll meet you around the other side of the hill.", "Finnegan? I can't believe it.", "All right, let's try that one again. Go!", 'Yeoman Barrows.', 'What happened?', 'Who was?', 'Barrows, give me a report.', "Are you sure you're not imagining all this?", 'Mister Sulu was with you. Where is he now?', 'Stay with her, Doctor.', 'Mister Sulu! Sulu!', 'Mister Sulu! Sulu!', 'Sulu!', 'Ruth? Ruth.', "McCoy, do you read me? Ruth. Ruth, how can it be you? How could you possibly be here? You haven't aged. It's been fifteen years.", 'Kirk here.', 'What?', "No, but I'm sure he's all right.", "Yes, I'm fine.", 'Yes, Mister Rodriguez.', "Don't you like birds, Mister Rodriguez?", "Mister Rodriguez, have the search parties rendezvous at the glade. I'd like some answers to all this.", "I don't want to.", "You haven't told me. You haven't told me", 'Ruth.', 'Kirk here.', 'Yes, Mister Spock.', 'Specify.', 'Can you pinpoint the source?', "Keep me posted, Mister Spock. We'll continue our investigation down here. Captain out.", "You're the science officer, Mister Spock. I want some answers.", "First there was McCoy's Alice in Wonderland where there was supposedly no animal life. And Sulu's gun where there's no refined metal detected. Rodriguez' birds. And then my, well, the two people I saw.", 'One hallucination flattened me with a clout on the jaw.', 'The other.', 'Yes.', "I'm already on maximum.", "Negative. Our people here are armed with phasers. Besides, there's yet to be any real danger. Captain out.", 'McCoy. McCoy, do you read me? Kirk to McCoy. Come in.', 'A what?', "I do. I've met some interesting personalities myself. Have you seen any of the others while I've been gone?", 'I hope he got through to everybody. Communications are almost out.', "Trying to. Something's obstructing it. Mister Spock, my orders were no one was to leave the ship.", 'Good. We can use your help.', 'Until we can find out what this is all about.', "That way. Spread out. Let's find it.", 'No.', "Yeoman! We're in trouble. I need every crewman alert and thinking.", 'Neither do I, Mister Sulu, but before we leave this planet, I will.', 'Tricorder?', 'Mister Spock. What do you make of that?', 'I want an exact judgment, Mister Spock.', 'Are you saying this is a plant, Mister Spock?', 'By who? And why? And why these particular things?', "McCoy's body?", 'Spock?', "McCoy's death is a scientific fact.", 'I was, I was thinking about the Academy. My days', "Finnegan. Finnegan! What's been happening to my people?", "Take Sulu. Find McCoy's body. This man is my problem.", "That's an order, Mister Spock.", 'I want some answers.', 'Can you feel that?', 'Finnegan. One thing', 'Answers.', "A lot of things. What's been happening to my people?", "I'm not a plebe. This is today, fifteen years later. What are you doing here?", 'Yes, I enjoyed it. After all these years. I did enjoy it. The one thing I wanted to do after all these years was to beat the tar out of Finnegan.', "That we're all meeting people and things that we happen to be thinking about at the moment.", 'Dangerous if we happen to be thinking about', 'Difficult.', 'Spock.', "We've got to get back to the landing party and warn them.", 'Sulu, Rodriguez, Barrows. Title: Shore Leave
Dialogue: ['They should be sending up a report momentarily, Captain. Something wrong?', 'Doctor McCoy is correct, Captain. After what this ship has been through in the last three months, there is not a crewman aboard who is not in need of rest. Myself excepted, of course.', 'Not necessary in my case, Captain. On my planet, to rest is to rest, to cease using energy. To me, it is quite illogical to run up and down on green grass using energy instead of saving it.', 'Very well, Captain. Something I did come to discuss.', "I picked this up from Doctor McCoy's log. We have a crewmember aboard who's showing signs of stress and fatigue. Reaction time down nine to twelve percent, associational reading norm minus three.", "He's becoming irritable and quarrelsome, yet he refuses to take rest and rehabilitation. Now, He has that right, but we've found", "James Kirk. Enjoy yourself, Captain. It's an interesting planet. You'll find it quite pleasant. Very much like your Earth.", "Scouts have detected no animals, artefacts, or force fields of any kind. Only peace, sunshine, and good air. You'll have no problems.", 'Captain.', "I'm getting strange readings from the planet surface, Captain. Some sort of power field down there.", 'A highly sophisticated type of energy draining our power and increasing, beginning to affect our communications.', "Could be coming from beneath the planet's surface. Patterns indicate some sort of industrial activity.", 'Any chance these could be hallucinations?', 'That sounds like a painful reality.', 'There must be some logical explanation.', 'Your signal is very weak. Can you turn up your gain?', 'Captain, shall I beam down an armed party?', "Necessary, Captain. Unable to contact you by communicator, and the transporter is useless to us now. As I told you before, there's an unusual power field down here. It's soaking up all the energy at the source. I calculated the rate of its growth, and reasoned that I just might be able to transport one more person.", 'This is not human skin tissue, Captain. It more closely resembles the cellular casting we use for wound repairs. Much finer, of course.', 'This is definitely a mechanical contrivance. It has the same basic cell structure as the plants here, even the trees, the grass.', "I'm saying that these are all multicellular castings. The plants, the animals, the people. They're all being manufactured.", 'All we know for certain is that they act exactly like the real thing. Just as pleasant or just as deadly.', 'At this point, Captain, my analysis may not sound very scientific.', 'There is one slight possibility, very slim, but nevertheless. Captain, what were your thoughts just before you encountered the people you described?', 'Captain, wait.', 'Did you enjoy it, Captain?', "Which supports a theory I've been formulating.", 'Yes. Somehow our thoughts are read, these things are quickly manufactured and provided for us.', 'Yes. We must all control our thoughts.', 'The force field we encountered is obviously underground, manufacturing these things. Passages lead to the surface. Just for example, when Rodriguez thought of a tiger', 'Captain.', 'The term is amusement park.', 'An old Earth name for a place where people could go to see and do all sorts of fascinating things.', 'I tend to agree.', "Captain, I'll go back aboard ship and take over. With all due respect to the young lady, I've already had as much shore leave as I care for.", 'Did you enjoy your rest, gentlemen?', 'Most illogical.']
Flattened Dialogue: They should be sending up a report momentarily, Captain. Something wrong? Doctor McCoy is correct, Captain. After what this ship has been through in the last three months, there is not a crewman aboard who is not in need of rest. Myself excepted, of course. Not necessary in my case, Captain. On my planet, to rest is to rest, to cease using energy. To me, it is quite illogical to run up and down on green grass using energy instead of saving it. Very well, Captain. Something I did come to discuss. I picked this up from Doctor McCoy's log. We have a crewmember aboard who's showing signs of stress and fatigue. Reaction time down nine to twelve percent, associational reading norm minus three. He's becoming irritable and quarrelsome, yet he refuses to take rest and rehabilitation. Now, He has that right, but we've found James Kirk. Enjoy yourself, Captain. It's an interesting planet. You'll find it quite pleasant. Very much like your Earth. Scouts have detected no animals, artefacts, or force fields of any kind. Only peace, sunshine, and good air. You'll have no problems. Captain. I'm getting strange readings from the planet surface, Captain. Some sort of power field down there. A highly sophisticated type of energy draining our power and increasing, beginning to affect our communications. Could be coming from beneath the planet's surface. Patterns indicate some sort of industrial activity. Any chance these could be hallucinations? That sounds like a painful reality. There must be some logical explanation. Your signal is very weak. Can you turn up your gain? Captain, shall I beam down an armed party? Necessary, Captain. Unable to contact you by communicator, and the transporter is useless to us now. As I told you before, there's an unusual power field down here. It's soaking up all the energy at the source. I calculated the rate of its growth, and reasoned that I just might be able to transport one more person. This is not human skin tissue, Captain. It more closely resembles the cellular casting we use for wound repairs. Much finer, of course. This is definitely a mechanical contrivance. It has the same basic cell structure as the plants here, even the trees, the grass. I'm saying that these are all multicellular castings. The plants, the animals, the people. They're all being manufactured. All we know for certain is that they act exactly like the real thing. Just as pleasant or just as deadly. At this point, Captain, my analysis may not sound very scientific. There is one slight possibility, very slim, but nevertheless. Captain, what were your thoughts just before you encountered the people you described? Captain, wait. Did you enjoy it, Captain? Which supports a theory I've been formulating. Yes. Somehow our thoughts are read, these things are quickly manufactured and provided for us. Yes. We must all control our thoughts. The force field we encountered is obviously underground, manufacturing these things. Passages lead to the surface. Just for example, when Rodriguez thought of a tiger Captain. The term is amusement park. An old Earth name for a place where people could go to see and do all sorts of fascinating things. I tend to agree. Captain, I'll go back aboard ship and take over. With all due respect to the young lady, I've already had as much shore leave as I care for. Did you enjoy your rest, gentlemen? Most illogical.

Title: Shore Leave
Dialogue: ['Aye, aye, Captain.', 'Doctor McCoy calling from the planet, Captain.', 'Aye, aye, sir.', 'Bridge.', "Negative, Captain. They're just about to start.", 'Aye, aye, sir.', 'This is the bridge, Captain. Our power systems have just come back in. Do you require assistance?', 'Aye, aye, sir.', 'Sir?']
Flattened Dialogue: Aye, aye, Captain. Doctor McCoy calling from the planet, Captain. Aye, aye, sir. Bridge. Negative, Captain. They're just about to start. Aye, aye, sir. This is the bridge, Captain. Our power systems have just come back in. Do you require assistance? Aye, aye, sir. Sir?

Title: Shore Leave
Dialogue: ['Beautiful, beautiful. No animals, no people, no worries. Just what the doctor ordered. Right, Doctor?', 'Do you think the Captain will authorise shore leave here?', "He'd like it.", "To get some cell-structure records. A blade of grass, a bush, a tree, a flower petal. With these, we can tell the whole planet's biology.", "What is it? What's the matter?", "See what? I don't see anything. What is it, Doc?", "Target shooting, Captain. Isn't it a beauty? Haven't got anything like this in my collection.", "I found it. I know it's a crazy coincidence, but I've always wanted one like this. Found it lying right over there. An old-time police special, and in beautiful condition. Hasn't been one like this made in a couple of centuries.", 'It fires lead pellets propelled by expanding gases from a chemical explosion.', "Captain, take cover! There's a Samurai after me.", "I mean, there was. Captain, you've got to believe me.", 'Got a call a few minutes ago. Rodriguez. Said you were rendezvousing back at the glade.', "That's not all. So's my phaser.", 'Yes, sir. Look. Someone beaming down from the bridge.', "We're stranded down here, Captain?", 'Captain! Captain!', "You'd better have a look at this, sir. I don't understand.", "It's like a dummy, Captain. It couldn't be alive.", 'Still operating, sir.', 'Captain!', "He's gone. Dragged off.", 'Sir.', 'Play? As advanced as you obviously are, and you still play?']
Flattened Dialogue: Beautiful, beautiful. No animals, no people, no worries. Just what the doctor ordered. Right, Doctor? Do you think the Captain will authorise shore leave here? He'd like it. To get some cell-structure records. A blade of grass, a bush, a tree, a flower petal. With these, we can tell the whole planet's biology. What is it? What's the matter? See what? I don't see anything. What is it, Doc? Target shooting, Captain. Isn't it a beauty? Haven't got anything like this in my collection. I found it. I know it's a crazy coincidence, but I've always wanted one like this. Found it lying right over there. An old-time police special, and in beautiful condition. Hasn't been one like this made in a couple of centuries. It fires lead pellets propelled by expanding gases from a chemical explosion. Captain, take cover! There's a Samurai after me. I mean, there was. Captain, you've got to believe me. Got a call a few minutes ago. Rodriguez. Said you were rendezvousing back at the glade. That's not all. So's my phaser. Yes, sir. Look. Someone beaming down from the bridge. We're stranded down here, Captain? Captain! Captain! You'd better have a look at this, sir. I don't understand. It's like a dummy, Captain. It couldn't be alive. Still operating, sir. Captain! He's gone. Dragged off. Sir. Play? As advanced as you obviously are, and you still play?

Title: Shore Leave
Dialogue: ["I couldn't have prescribed better. We are one weary ship.", "Depending upon my report and that of the other scouting parties. You know, you have to see this place to believe it. It's like something out of Alice in Wonderland. The Captain has to come down.", "He needs it. You've got your problems, I've got mine. He's got ours, plus his, plus four hundred and thirty other people's. Where are you going?", 'Sulu!', 'Did you see them?', 'Captain, are you beaming down?', 'Well, either our scouting probes and detectors are malfunctioning, and all us scouts careless and beauty-intoxicated, or I must report myself unfit for duty.', 'On this supposedly uninhabited planet, I just saw a large rabbit', 'Pull a gold watch from his vest and claim that he was late.', 'As a matter of fact, yes.', 'And they disappeared through a hole in a hedge.', 'Over here. Over here.', 'As a matter of fact, I do, but this is not one of them. Look at this. I saw what I saw, or maybe I hallucinated it, but I want you to take a look and tell me what you think about it.', 'Negative. He was examining the flora at the time.', 'Collecting specimens.', "You're cancelling the shore leave on account of this, Jim?", 'Well, no.', "Absolutely. No birds, no mammals, no insects, nothing. I'm certain our readings weren't off.", 'Well, it could have been worse.', 'You could have seen the rabbit.', "Well, yeah, I'm beginning to feel a little bit picked on, if that's what you mean.", 'And you being the very serious young', "A girl's footprints. The young blonde girl I saw chasing it.", "Good. I've got a personal grudge against that rabbit, Jim.", 'What was it?', 'Sounds like Don Juan.', 'Did you find Mister Sulu, Captain?', 'Did you find Mister Sulu?', 'Sir? Are you all right?', 'Feeling better?', "It's a beautiful place. A little strange, I'll admit.", "I see what you mean, but then you'd have whole armies of Don Juans to fight off. And me, too.", "You are all of those things and many more. They'll look even lovelier with you wearing them.", "Now, look, I don't know how or why, but the dress is here. I'd like to see you in it. Why don't you put it on?", "My dear girl, I am a doctor. When I peek, it's in the line of duty.", "McCoy here. I can't read you very well. Is this Rodriguez?", "Right. What the devil's wrong with communications? Esteban. Esteban.", 'This is where the Captain said to rendezvous. I swear I heard someone moving around.', "A princess shouldn't be afraid, not with a brave knight to protect her.", "These things cannot be real. Hallucinations can't harm us. Go back to where you were.", "Possibly because no one has died, Jim. I was taken below the surface for some rather remarkable repairs. It's amazing. They've got a factory complex down there you wouldn't believe. They can build or do anything immediately.", 'Oh. Them. Well I, er, I was thinking about a little cabaret I know on Rigel Two, and, er, there were these two girls in the chorus line. And well, here they are. Well after all, I am on shore leave.', 'Oh, yes. So you are. Well, girls, I suppose you can turn something up.', "It's what the doctor ordered, Jim.", 'Indeed we did, Mister Spock.']

He's got ours, plus his, plus four hundred and thirty other people's. Where are you going? Sulu! Did you see them? Captain, are you beaming down? Well, either our scouting probes and detectors are malfunctioning, and all us scouts careless and beauty-intoxicated, or I must report myself unfit for duty. On this supposedly uninhabited planet, I just saw a large rabbit Pull a gold watch from his vest and claim that he was late. As a matter of fact, yes. And they disappeared through a hole in a hedge. Over here. Over here. As a matter of fact, I do, but this is not one of them. Look at this. I saw what I saw, or maybe I hallucinated it, but I want you to take a look and tell me what you think about it. Negative. He was examining the flora at the time. Collecting specimens. You're cancelling the shore leave on account of this, Jim? Well, no. Absolutely. No birds, no mammals, no insects, nothing. I'm certain our readings weren't off. Well, it could have been worse. You could have seen the rabbit. Well, yeah, I'm beginning to feel a little bit picked on, if that's what you mean. And you being the very serious young A girl's footprints. The young blonde girl I saw chasing it. Good. I've got a personal grudge against that rabbit, Jim. What was it? Sounds like Don Juan. Did you find Mister Sulu, Captain? Did you find Mister Sulu? Sir? Are you all right? Feeling better? It's a beautiful place. A little strange, I'll admit. I see what you mean, but then you'd have whole armies of Don Juans to fight off. And me, too. You are all of those things and many more. They'll look even lovelier with you wearing them. Now, look, I don't know how or why, but the dress is here. I'd like to see you in it. Why don't you put it on? My dear girl, I am a doctor. When I peek, it's in the line of duty. McCoy here. I can't read you very well. Is this Rodriguez? Right. What the devil's wrong with communications? Esteban. Esteban. This is where the Captain said to rendezvous. I swear I heard someone moving around. A princess shouldn't be afraid, not with a brave knight to protect her. These things cannot be real. Hallucinations can't harm us. Go back to where you were. Possibly because no one has died, Jim. I was taken below the surface for some rather remarkable repairs. It's amazing. They've got a factory complex down there you wouldn't believe. They can build or do anything immediately. Oh. Them. Well I, er, I was thinking about a little cabaret I know on Rigel Two, and, er, there were these two girls in the chorus line. And well, here they are. Well after all, I am on shore leave. Oh, yes. So you are. Well, girls, I suppose you can turn something up. It's what the doctor ordered, Jim. Indeed we did, Mister Spock.

Title: The Galileo Seven
Dialogue: ['Captain to shuttlecraft Galileo. Stand by, Mister Spock.', "No problem, Commissioner. And may I remind you that I have standing orders to investigate all quasars and quasar-like phenomena wherever they may be encountered. Besides, it's three days to Makus. And the rendezvous doesn't take place for five.", 'No problem. Captain to Galileo. All systems cleared for take off.', 'Launch shuttlecraft.', 'Anything at all?', 'Try and get me a fix on the Galileo.', "That thing out there has ionized this complete sector. None of our instruments work. At least four complete solar systems in the immediate vicinity. And out there somewhere, a twenty four foot shuttlecraft, off course, out of control. Finding a needle in a haystack would be child's play.", "I'm aware of that, Commissioner. At the same time I have certain scientific duties I must perform, and investigating the Murasaki effect is one.", 'We have two days to find them.', 'What would you have me do, turn around and leave them there?', 'Thank you, Lieutenant. Mister Sulu.', 'Set course for Taurus Two.', "If they're not there, Commissioner, then they're dead by now.", 'Mister Sulu.', 'Anything on your scanners?', 'Have you tried tying in to the auxiliary power?', 'Transport room, this is the captain speaking. Are the transporters beaming up yet?', 'Thank you. This is the captain speaking. Flight deck, prepare Columbus for immediate exit, for a search of the planet surface. Correlate co-ordinates with Mister Sulu. Thank you. Anything, Uhura?', 'We have until 2823.8 to continue the search, Commissioner.', "Look, these people are my friends and my shipmates. I intend to continue the ship's search for them until the last possible moment.", "I'm familiar with the regulations, Commissioner. I know all about your authority. Launch shuttlecraft Columbus.", 'Have them proceed to the next quadrant. Any word from engineering on our sensors?', 'What about the transporters?', 'Thank you, Lieutenant.', 'Yes, Commissioner?', "I haven't forgotten, Commissioner.", "I haven't forgotten that, Commissioner. This is the captain. Try using overload power on the transporters. We've got to get them working.", 'Uhura, order the Columbus to open its course two degrees on every lap from now on.', "It also means we have a fighting chance to cover the majority of the planet's surface. Mind your helm, Mister Sulu.", 'Good. This is the captain. Landing parties one, two, and three, report to transporter room for immediate beaming down to surface of the planet. Ordinance condition One A.', "I'm depending on luck, Lieutenant. It's almost the only tool we have that'll work.", 'What word from the sensor section?', "I'm not interested in the last report. I want to know now.", "I'm perfectly aware of how much time I have left.", 'You do that.', 'What about radio communication?', "Do? I intend to continue the search. Foot by foot, inch by inch, by candlelight if necessary, until the last possible moment. And if you'd keep your nose off my bridge, I'd be thankful.", "I'm in command here, Mister Ferris.", 'Put Lieutenant Kelowitz on visual.', 'Report.', 'There are casualties?', "Thank you, Lieutenant. You'd better report to Sickbay yourself.", "But they're still out there.", "The Columbus hasn't returned yet. I still have two search parties out.", 'Lieutenant.', 'Order the transporter room to immediately beam up the two search parties from the surface. Attempt to contact the Columbus.', 'Then have them return immediately. Mister Sulu, prepare to abandon search. Set course for Makus Three.', 'What about the other systems?', 'Stand ready, Mister Sulu. How long before the Columbus comes on board?', 'Twenty three minutes.', 'Mister Sulu, proceed on course for Makus Three, at space normal speed.', 'Those are my orders. Lieutenant Uhura, order all sensor sections to direct beams aft. Full function, continuous operation until further orders.', 'Sensors, a meteorite?', 'A hundred and eighty degrees about, Mister Sulu. Lieutenant Uhura, contact transporter room. All beams ready. Full normal speed.', 'Activate beams.', 'Mister Sulu, proceed on course to Makus Three. Ahead warp factor one.', 'Mister Spock.', "There's really something I don't understand about all of this. Maybe you can explain it to me. Logically, of course. When you jettisoned the fuel and ignited it, you knew there was virtually no chance of it being seen, yet you did it anyhow. That would seem to me to be an act of desperation.", "Now we all know, and I'm sure the doctor will agree with me, that desperation is a highly emotional state of mind. How does your well-known logic explain that?", 'I see. You mean you reasoned that it was time for an emotional outburst.', "You're not going to admit that for the first time in your life, you committed a purely human emotional act?", "Mister Spock, you're a stubborn man."]

I'm familiar with the regulations, Commissioner. I know all about your authority. Launch shuttlecraft Columbus. Have them proceed to the next quadrant. Any word from engineering on our sensors? What about the transporters? Thank you, Lieutenant. Yes, Commissioner? I haven't forgotten, Commissioner. I haven't forgotten that, Commissioner. This is the captain. Try using overload power on the transporters. We've got to get them working. Uhura, order the Columbus to open its course two degrees on every lap from now on. It also means we have a fighting chance to cover the majority of the planet's surface. Mind your helm, Mister Sulu. Good. This is the captain. Landing parties one, two, and three, report to transporter room for immediate beaming down to surface of the planet. Ordinance condition One A. I'm depending on luck, Lieutenant. It's almost the only tool we have that'll work. What word from the sensor section? I'm not interested in the last report. I want to know now. I'm perfectly aware of how much time I have left. You do that. What about radio communication? Do? I intend to continue the search. Foot by foot, inch by inch, by candlelight if necessary, until the last possible moment. And if you'd keep your nose off my bridge, I'd be thankful. I'm in command here, Mister Ferris. Put Lieutenant Kelowitz on visual. Report. There are casualties? Thank you, Lieutenant. You'd better report to Sickbay yourself. But they're still out there. The Columbus hasn't returned yet. I still have two search parties out. Lieutenant. Order the transporter room to immediately beam up the two search parties from the surface. Attempt to contact the Columbus. Then have them return immediately. Mister Sulu, prepare to abandon search. Set course for Makus Three. What about the other systems? Stand ready, Mister Sulu. How long before the Columbus comes on board? Twenty three minutes. Mister Sulu, proceed on course for Makus Three, at space normal speed. Those are my orders. Lieutenant Uhura, order all sensor sections to direct beams aft. Full function, continuous operation until further orders. Sensors, a meteorite? A hundred and eighty degrees about, Mister Sulu. Lieutenant Uhura, contact transporter room. All beams ready. Full normal speed. Activate beams. Mister Sulu, proceed on course to Makus Three. Ahead warp factor one. Mister Spock. There's really something I don't understand about all of this. Maybe you can explain it to me. Logically, of course. When you jettisoned the fuel and ignited it, you knew there was virtually no chance of it being seen, yet you did it anyhow. That would seem to me to be an act of desperation. Now we all know, and I'm sure the doctor will agree with me, that desperation is a highly emotional state of mind. How does your well-known logic explain that? I see. You mean you reasoned that it was time for an emotional outburst. You're not going to admit that for the first time in your life, you committed a purely human emotional act? Mister Spock, you're a stubborn man.

Title: The Galileo Seven
Dialogue: ['Power up. All instruments activated. All readings normal. All go.', 'Position?', 'Make up your mind please, Mister Latimer.', 'Considerably, Mister Boma.', 'Stop forward momentum, Mister Latimer.', 'Galileo to Enterprise. Galileo to Enterprise. Come in, please.', 'Galileo to Enterprise. Galileo to Enterprise. We are out of control, being pulled directly into the heart of Murasaki three one two. Being hit by violent radiation on outer hull. Course three point two five', "I'd say your evaluation is reasonable, Mister Boma.", "Picturesque descriptions will not mend broken circuits, Mister Scott. I think you'll find your work is cut out for you. Galileo to Enterprise. Galileo to Enterprise. Come in, please.", 'I expect nothing, Mister Scott. It is merely logical to try all the alternatives. Doctor McCoy, a reading on the atmosphere, please.', 'Just the facts, Doctor.', "Thank you for your opinion. It will be duly noted. You're recording this, Yeoman?", "Mister Scott, if you'll make a survey of the damage, please.", "Gentlemen, I think we should move outside, make room for Mister Scott to do his work. Mister Latimer, Mister Gaetano, you'll arm yourselves and scout out the area, keeping in visual contact with the ship.", 'Under present conditions, extremely poor.', "If the ionisation effect is as widespread as I believe it is, Doctor, they'll be searching for us without instrumentation, by visual contact only. On those terms, this is a very large planet.", "Not as long as we're grounded. We may be here for a very long time, Doctor.", 'My big chance? For what, Doctor?', 'I am a logical man, Doctor.', 'Perhaps, Doctor, but I know of no better way to begin. I realise command does have its fascinations, even under circumstances such as these. But I neither enjoy the idea of command, nor am I frightened of it. It simply exists. And I will do whatever logically needs to be done. Excuse me.', 'In what way?', 'The weight of three grown men.', "Doctor McCoy, with very few exceptions we use virtually every piece of equipment aboard this craft in attaining orbit. There's very little excess weight, except among the passengers.", 'Unless the situation changes radically, yes.', 'As commanding officer, the choice will be mine.', "A very quaint idea, Mister Boma, but I do believe I'm better qualified to make the selection than any random drawing of lots.", 'My choice will be a logical one, arrived at through logical means.', "But attaining a desired goal always is, Doctor. Now gentlemen, I suggest we move outside to make a further examination of the hull in the event we've overlooked any minor damage.", 'Come on, Boma.', 'What was it?', 'Nothing there.', "I don't doubt your word.", 'Folsom Point.', "There's a remarkable resemblance to the Folsom Point discovered in 1925, old world calendar, New Mexico, North America. A bit more crude about the shaft, I believe. Not very efficient.", 'Am I in error, Mister Boma?', 'Then what, Mister Boma?', 'My concern for the dead will not bring him back to life, Mister Boma.', 'Bringing him back to the ship should not interfere with our repair efforts. If you need assistance, I', 'Perhaps if you were to channel the second auxiliary tank through the primary intake valve.', 'Excellent, Doctor.', 'Which would still leave us at least one hundred and fifty pounds overweight.', 'It is more rational to sacrifice one life than six, Doctor.', 'You might be wise to start.', 'For what?', "Mister Boma, we're working against time.", 'Doctor, perhaps you know the correct words for such an occasion.', 'My place is here. If you please, Doctor.', 'By dealing with first things first, I hope to increase our chances of staying alive. Well, Mister Scott.', 'What happened?', 'That would seem to solve the problem of who to leave behind. Consider the alternatives, Mister Scott.', 'Mister Scott, there are always alternatives.', 'Wood rubbing on some kind of leather.', 'Not a tribal culture. Their artefacts are too primitive. More likely a loose association of some sort.', 'How, Mister Boma?', "I'm frequently appalled by the low regard you Earthmen have for life.", 'Mister Boma?', 'Doctor McCoy?', 'It does, indeed. It seems logical to me, also. But to take life indiscriminately,', "I am not interested in the opinion of the majority, Mister Gaetano. Components must be weighed. Our danger to ourselves as well as our duties to other life forms, friendly or not. There's a third course.", 'I think not. Doctor McCoy.', "You and Yeoman Mears return to the ship. Assist Mister Scott in any way possible. We'll be back shortly.", "Gentlemen, you'll follow my orders to the letter, firing only when so instructed, and at my designated targets.", "We'll fire to frighten, Mister Gaetano, not to kill.", 'I am in command, Mister Gaetano. The orders and the responsibility will be mine. Follow me.', "I hear them. They're directly ahead of us. Several, I believe. Direct your phasers to two o'clock and to ten o'clock.", "Yes, I know. But fortunately, I'm giving the orders. Take aim please, and fire when I give a signal.", 'Fire. Cease fire. They should think twice before bothering us again.', 'It was not necessary. Fear will do for us what needs to be done. Mister Boma, you will return with me to the Galileo. Mister Gaetano, you remain on guard here. Keep in contact with the ship.', "Yes, we found them. They won't bother us again.", 'Go, Mister Scott.', "That's all very well, but we don't have a substitute supply.", 'They would also seem to be our only hope.', 'Yeoman, your phaser.', "They won't attack for at least several hours. By then, with luck, we'll be gone.", "We don't have to maintain it very long, Mister Scott. In less than twenty four hours, the Enterprise will be forced to abandon its search in order to make a rendezvous. If we can't maintain orbit after that time, it won't make any difference. If we burn up in a decaying orbit or die here on the planet's surface, we shall surely die. Doctor, your phaser. Go to work, Mister Scott.", 'Take this back to Mister Scott for conversion, please Doctor.', "And give this to Mister Scott in the event I don't return.", "I have a certain scientific curiosity about what's become of Mister Gaetano. Return to the ship, please.", 'Most illogical reaction. We demonstrated our superior weapons. They should have fled.', 'Of course.', 'Doctor, I am not responsible for their unpredictability.', "They're studying us, for the moment.", 'My opinion, Mister Boma.', 'Seal the windows!', 'Mister Boma, your tone is increasingly hostile.', 'Curious. Most illogical.', 'Strange. Step by step, I have made the correct and logical decisions. And yet two men have died.', 'I do seem to have miscalculated regarding them, and inculcated resentment on your parts. The sum of the parts cannot be greater than the whole.', 'How much longer, Mister Scott?', "Mister Scott, how much power do we have left in the ship's batteries?", 'Will they electrify the exterior of this ship?', "Get to the centre of the ship. Don't touch the plates. Be sure you're insulated. Stand by. Are you ready, Scott?", 'All right. Go. Again! Again!', "I believe we've used enough. Mister Scott. I suggest you continue draining the phasers.", 'For the moment.', "The moment they discover they're not seriously hurt, they'll be back. Meanwhile, please check the aft compartment. See if there's anything you can unload to lighten the ship.", 'It will of course have to be left behind.', "I wouldn't recommend it. The creatures won't be far away.", 'It would expose members of this crew to unnecessary peril.', "Gentlemen. All right, Mister Boma, you'll have your burial, provided the creatures will permit it.", 'How about weight?', 'And how long can we hold it?', 'To land here again? Not a very attractive possibility.', 'Doctor McCoy. Mister Boma. When can we lift off, Scott?', "Gentlemen, The ship will lift off in exactly ten minutes. You have that long to bury Mister Gaetano. Now, it appears to be clear outside, at least for the moment. I'll assist you. Hurry.", 'Get into the ship! Immediate lift off!', 'No! Go back! Lift off! Go back! No!', 'All right, All right! Go! Go! Go! Go!', 'Go, Scott!', 'I told you to lift off!', 'Get us off, Scott!', "Quite right, Mister Scott. There's somebody holding us down. All systems are go, but we're not moving.", 'Our boosters.', 'Would you rather stay here?', 'May I remind you we have yet to achieve orbit, nor can we maintain it long. An hour from now we may be right back where we started from.', 'Gentlemen, by coming after me, you may well have destroyed what slim chance you had for survival. The logical thing for you to have done was to have left me behind.', 'That is a most illogical attitude. Orbit in one minute, Mister Scott. Fuel status?', 'It is the usual end of a decaying orbit.', "Infinitely preferable to the kind of death we'd be granted on the planet's surface, I should think.", 'Did l? I may have been mistaken.', 'The Enterprise is surely on course for Makus Three by now. I for one do not believe in angels.', 'Yes. My first command.', 'Galileo to Enterprise. Galileo to Enterprise, come in, please. Galileo to Enterprise. Come in, please.', 'Perhaps, Mister Boma.', 'No one out there to see it.', 'Totally illogical. There was no chance.', 'Captain.', 'Quite correct, Captain.', 'Quite simply, Captain. I examined the problem from all angles, and it was plainly hopeless. Logic informed me that under the circumstances, the only possible action would have to be one of desperation. Logical decision, logically arrived at.', "Well, I wouldn't put it in exactly those terms, Captain, but those are essentially the facts.", 'No, sir.', 'Yes, sir.']

Title: The Galileo Seven
Dialogue: ["We're being drawn right into it.", 'You all right?', 'Scotty? Boma?', 'Yeoman?', 'Upsy-daisy.', 'What happened?', "Partial pressure of oxygen, seventy millimetres of mercury. Nitrogen one forty. Breathable, if you're not running in competition.", "Traces of argon, neon, krypton, all in acceptable quantities. However, I wouldn't recommend this place as a summer resort.", 'What do you think our chances are of contacting the Enterprise?', "But they'll be looking for us.", "Then you don't think they'll find us.", "Well, I can't say much for the circumstances, but at least it's your big chance.", "Command. Oh, I know you, Mister Spock. You've never voiced it, but you've always thought that logic was the best basis on which to build command. Am I right?", "It'll take more than logic to get us out of this.", 'Or the equivalent weight in equipment.', 'Mister Spock, life and death are seldom logical.', 'Not his head, Mister Boma, his heart. His heart.', 'This should save us at least fifty pounds, Mister Spock.', "I can't believe you're serious about leaving someone behind. Now whatever it is that's out there", "I'm not talking about rationality.", "Mister Spock, that's your place.", 'Now look. We may all die here. At least let us die like men, not machines.', "Mister Spock! Something's happening outside.", 'What do those supersensitive ears make of that, Mister Spock?', 'Seems logical to me.', 'Yes.', 'Right.', 'I hope not. Scotty has an idea.', 'Trouble is, they happen to be our only defence.', 'Just where are you going?', "I don't know. He'll risk his neck locating Gaetano and if he finds him, he's just as liable to order him to stay behind. You tell me.", "Well, it won't unless we get these phasers back.", "Well, Mister Spock, they didn't stay frightened very long, did they?", 'You mean they should have respected us?', 'Mister Spock, respect is a rational process. Did it ever occur to you they might react emotionally, with anger?', 'They were perfectly predictable to anyone with feeling. You might as well admit it, Mister Spock, your precious logic brought them down on us.', 'Studying us, Mister Spock? They seem to learn rather quickly.', "And you've brought our furry friends down on us.", "A little less analysis and more action. That's what we need, Mister Spock.", "That won't be long enough.", "It must've worked.", 'Mister Boma.', "Don't be a fool, Mister Spock. We couldn't leave you out there.", 'We got off!', "Mister Spock, remind me to tell you that I'm sick and tired of your logic.", 'After that?', 'Well, at least I lived long enough to hear that. Is there anything we can do?', 'Well, Mister Spock, so ends your first command.', 'How long have we got now, Scotty?', "It may be the last action you'll ever take, Mister Spock, but it was all human.", "That's exactly what I mean."]
Flattened Dialogue: We're being drawn right into it. You all right? Scotty? Boma? Yeoman? Upsy-daisy. What happened? Partial pressure of oxygen, seventy millimetres of mercury. Nitrogen one forty. Breathable, if you're not running in competition. Traces of argon, neon, krypton, all in acceptable quantities. However, I wouldn't recommend this place as a summer resort. What do you think our chances are of contacting the Enterprise? But they'll be looking for us. Then you don't think they'll find us. Well, I can't say much for the circumstances, but at least it's your big chance. Command. Oh, I know you, Mister Spock. You've never voiced it, but you've always thought that logic was the best basis on which to build command. Am I right? It'll take more than logic to get us out of this. Or the equivalent weight in equipment. Mister Spock, life and death are seldom logical. Not his head, Mister Boma, his heart. His heart. This should save us at least fifty pounds, Mister Spock. I can't believe you're serious about leaving someone behind. Now whatever it is that's out there I'm not talking about rationality. Mister Spock, that's your place. Now look. We may all die here. At least let us die like men, not machines. Mister Spock! Something's happening outside. What do those supersensitive ears make of that, Mister Spock? Seems logical to me. Yes. Right. I hope not. Scotty has an idea. Trouble is, they happen to be our only defence. Just where are you going? I don't know. He'll risk his neck locating Gaetano and if he finds him, he's just as liable to order him to stay behind. You tell me. Well, it won't unless we get these phasers back. Well, Mister Spock, they didn't stay frightened very long, did they? You mean they should have respected us? Mister Spock, respect is a rational process. Did it ever occur to you they might react emotionally, with anger? They were perfectly predictable to anyone with feeling. You might as well admit it, Mister Spock, your precious logic brought them down on us. Studying us, Mister Spock? They seem to learn rather quickly. And you've brought our furry friends down on us. A little less analysis and more action. That's what we need, Mister Spock. That won't be long enough. It must've worked. Mister Boma. Don't be a fool, Mister Spock. We couldn't leave you out there. We got off! Mister Spock, remind me to tell you that I'm sick and tired of your logic. After that? Well, at least I lived long enough to hear that. Is there anything we can do? Well, Mister Spock, so ends your first command. How long have we got now, Scotty? It may be the last action you'll ever take, Mister Spock, but it was all human. That's exactly what I mean.

Title: The Galileo Seven
Dialogue: ['Nothing clear, Captain. Just a few words about being pulled off course.', "Captain, there's one planet in this solar system capable of sustaining human life. It's type M, oxygen, nitrogen, and it's listed as Taurus Two. It's unexplored. As far as we can determine with our equipment malfunction, it's just about dead-centre of the Murasaki effect.", 'Nothing, Captain.', 'All wavelengths dominated by ionisation effects, sir. Transmission is blocked, reception impossible.', 'Captain, the Columbus has returned from searching quadrant seven seven nine X by five three four M. Results negative.', "They're working on them, sir. Still inoperable.", "They're still reported unsafe.", 'At last report they were getting some readings', 'Yes, sir.', 'Sir, sensor section reporting. Static interference still creating false images. Estimates eighty percent undependable.', 'Clearing slowly. Still incapable of transmission or reception.', 'Captain Kirk, landing party number two has been beamed back aboard ship. They have casualties. One dead, two injured.', 'Yes, sir.', "I'm in partial contact with them now, sir.", 'Captain, the sensor section says the beams are working again.', 'No, sir. Too much interference.', 'Twenty three minutes, sir.', 'The Columbus is aboard, sir. The flight hatch is closed. Transporter room reports last of the landing parties have beamed safely up. All systems report secured for warp factors.', 'Yes, sir.', 'Transporters locked in, sir.', 'Captain, transporter room just beamed up five persons. Alive and well.']
Flattened Dialogue: Nothing clear, Captain. Just a few words about being pulled off course. Captain, there's one planet in this solar system capable of sustaining human life. It's type M, oxygen, nitrogen, and it's listed as Taurus Two. It's unexplored. As far as we can determine with our equipment malfunction, it's just about dead-centre of the Murasaki effect. Nothing, Captain. All wavelengths dominated by ionisation effects, sir. Transmission is blocked, reception impossible. Captain, the Columbus has returned from searching quadrant seven seven nine X by five three four M. Results negative. They're working on them, sir. Still inoperable. They're still reported unsafe. At last report they were getting some readings Yes, sir. Sir, sensor section reporting. Static interference still creating false images. Estimates eighty percent undependable. Clearing slowly. Still incapable of transmission or reception. Captain Kirk, landing party number two has been beamed back aboard ship. They have casualties. One dead, two injured. Yes, sir. I'm in partial contact with them now, sir. Captain, the sensor section says the beams are working again. No, sir. Too much interference. Twenty three minutes, sir. The Columbus is aboard, sir. The flight hatch is closed. Transporter room reports last of the landing parties have beamed safely up. All systems report secured for warp factors. Yes, sir. Transporters locked in, sir. Captain, transporter room just beamed up five persons. Alive and well.

Title: The Galileo Seven
Dialogue: ["Scanners are blank, Captain. We're getting a mass of readings I've never seen. Nothing makes sense.", 'Yes, sir.', 'Aye, aye, sir.', 'Yes, Captain?', 'Totally inoperative, sir. No readings at all.', 'Yes, sir. No change.', "But Captain, two degrees means they'll be overlooking more than a dozen terrestrial miles on each search loop.", 'Yes, sir.', 'Captain, course set for Makus Three.', 'Space normal, sir?', "Captain, there's something there on screen, at Taurus Two.", "No. It's holding a lateral line. There it is again. Holding steady, Captain.", 'Whatever it was, Captain, it just burned up in the atmosphere.', 'Aye, aye, sir. Warp factor one.']

No readings at all. Yes, sir. No change. But Captain, two degrees means they'll be overlooking more than a dozen terrestrial miles on each search loop. Yes, sir. Captain, course set for Makus Three. Space normal, sir? Captain, there's something there on screen, at Taurus Two. No. It's holding a lateral line. There it is again. Holding steady, Captain.
