Title: Operation -- Annihilate!
Dialogue: ["No, sir. I've tried every major transmitting station on Deneva. None of them have acknowledged my contact signal.", "But sir, that's a call sign for a private transmitter.", 'Yes, sir.', 'Aye, aye, sir.', 'Making contact, Captain.', "Captain, I'm having difficulty on that transmitter call to Deneva.", 'Yes, sir.', "Captain. I've made contact with your private transmitter, sir.", 'Contact broken, sir.', 'Sorry, sir.', "I'm afraid that's impossible at the moment, Captain. They stopped broadcasting immediately. They do not acknowledge my contact signal.", 'Yes, sir.', 'Captain, receiving messages from a ground station.', "The things are dying, sir. It's working."]
Flattened Dialogue: No, sir. I've tried every major transmitting station on Deneva. None of them have acknowledged my contact signal. But sir, that's a call sign for a private transmitter. Yes, sir. Aye, aye, sir. Making contact, Captain. Captain, I'm having difficulty on that transmitter call to Deneva. Yes, sir. Captain. I've made contact with your private transmitter, sir. Contact broken, sir. Sorry, sir. I'm afraid that's impossible at the moment, Captain. They stopped broadcasting immediately. They do not acknowledge my contact signal. Yes, sir. Captain, receiving messages from a ground station. The things are dying, sir. It's working.

Title: Operation -- Annihilate!
Dialogue: ['As I speculated, Captain, the overall pattern of mass insanity destroying civilisations follows an almost straight line through this section of the galaxy. Over here the Beta Portilin system the ancient civilisations. Archaeologists have given us information indicating that they were the beginning. Two hundred years ago, Levinius Five was swept by mass insanity, then Theta Cygni Twelve. The last was Ingraham B, two years ago.', 'The ship is a one-man vessel of Denevan configuration, Captain. He does not seem to be out of control. His course is straight for the sun.', 'Outer hull temperature now four hundred and eighty degrees and rising.', "So are we. Hull temperature one thousand degrees and rising. The sun's gravimetric pull increasing.", 'All clear, Captain. Hull temperature falling, gravimetric pull approaching tolerance level.', 'Planet development is normal, Captain. Originally colonised as a freighting-line base in this area.', 'No Federation contacts for over a year.', 'Lieutenant Uhura has had no further response to our signals. Sensors report the expected number of humans on the planet surface. However, they are strangely quiet. Very little activity.', "They're here, Captain. In the buildings. Strangely quiescent.", 'Captain, several people approaching.', 'Indeed. They seemed most concerned for our safety.', 'Their attitude was inconsistent with their actions.', 'Captain, I understand how you must', 'Notice the ventilator, Captain. Apparently they were trying to keep something outside from getting in. Obviously they were not entirely successful.', 'That is correct. I am at a loss to understand it.', "The streets are extraordinarily quiet, Captain. We've seen no other Denevans, and the ones we stunned earlier were gone when we came out.", 'A peculiar buzzing sound. We were about to investigate it.', 'Incredible. Not only should it have been destroyed by our phasers, it does not even register on my tricorder.', 'It is not life as we know or understand it. Yet t is obviously alive, it exists.', 'Captain, I suggest we risk taking it aboard.', 'No! No!', "No, I won't.", 'I must take the ship.', 'Down! I must take it down.', 'Doctor McCoy. Captain.', "These restraints will no longer be necessary. Nor will your sedatives, Doctor. I'll be able to return to duty. I apologise for my weakness earlier when I tried to take control of the ship. I simply did not understand.", 'I am a Vulcan, Doctor. Pain is a thing of the mind. The mind can be controlled.', 'It is proving to be an inconvenience, but it is manageable. And the creature, with all of its thousands of parts, even now is pressuring me. It wants this ship, but I am resisting.', 'I have my own will, Captain. Let me help.', 'I am a Vulcan. I am a Vulcan. There is no pain.', 'I was.', "I have an errand on the planet's surface. You will beam me down to the same co-ordinates as before.", 'That is an order, Mister Scott.', 'Until the pain was gone, Captain. It has been discontinued by me.', "One of the creatures will have to be captured and analysed, Captain. We did not have a clear opportunity to do so earlier when I was attacked. Since my nervous system is already affected, as you pointed out, Doctor, I don't believe they can do much more to me.", 'I am in complete control of myself, Doctor. The fact that I am here proves that I do not belong in bed.', 'Thank you, Captain.', "Come in, gentlemen. I believe you'll find this interesting. Doctor, your medical skill and curiosity are quite admirable, but I assure you I'm all right.", 'Unimportant at the moment, Doctor. Please observe. Interesting, gentlemen. A one-celled creature resembling, more than anything else, a huge, individual brain cell.', "Do you understand what I'm suggesting, Captain?", 'And although it is not physically connected to the other cells, it is nevertheless part of the whole creature, guided by the whole, drawing its strength from the whole, which probably accounts for its unusual resistance to our phaser weapons.', 'From a place where our physical laws do not apply. We may therefore find it difficult to destroy, Captain.', 'Yes, sir.', 'I regret I see no other choice for you, Captain. We already know this thing has destroyed three civilisations. Perhaps more.', "Including myself, Doctor, and Captain Kirk's young nephew. Understandably upsetting, but once it spreads past here, there are dozens of colonies beyond and billions of people.", "I therefore request permission to beam down to the planet's surface. I also suggest that your nephew accompany me.", 'Captain, I do not make this request lightly. I do not know how much longer I can hold out against the pain. But I do know what the boy will go through should he regain consciousness.', 'It exists physically. It occupies space. It has mass, therefore gravity. It converts matter to energy.', 'A possibility.', 'Yes. In essence, it can be done. A string of satellites around the planet with burning tri-magnesite and trevium.', 'Of course. The light of the sun at the proximity where the Denevan declared himself free was one million candles per square inch. If this works, the satellites we orbit will produce light of such intensity that even someone in a closed, darkened area will be affected by it.', "Captain, you'll need a host for the next step in the test to determine whether the creature can be driven from the body. I am the logical choice.", "There'll be none on the planet's surface, Doctor.", 'The creature within me is gone. I am free of it and the pain.', "And I'm also quite blind. An equitable trade, Doctor. Thank you.", 'Interesting. Just as dogs are sensitive to certain sounds which humans cannot hear, these creatures evidently are sensitive to light which we cannot see.', 'Doctor it was my selection as well. It is done.', 'An hereditary trait, Captain. The brightness of the Vulcan sun has caused the development of an inner eyelid, which acts as a shield against high-intensity light. Totally instinctive, Doctor. We tend to ignore it, as you ignore your own appendix.', 'Quite the contrary, Captain. I had a very strong reaction. My first sight was the face of Doctor McCoy bending over me.', 'My pleasure, Captain.', 'Why, thank you, Doctor McCoy.']
Flattened Dialogue: As I speculated, Captain, the overall pattern of mass insanity destroying civilisations follows an almost straight line through this section of the galaxy. Over here the Beta Portilin system the ancient civilisations. Archaeologists have given us information indicating that they were the beginning. Two hundred years ago, Levinius Five was swept by mass insanity, then Theta Cygni Twelve. The last was Ingraham B, two years ago. The ship is a one-man vessel of Denevan configuration, Captain. He does not seem to be out of control. His course is straight for the sun. Outer hull temperature now four hundred and eighty degrees and rising. So are we. Hull temperature one thousand degrees and rising. The sun's gravimetric pull increasing. All clear, Captain. Hull temperature falling, gravimetric pull approaching tolerance level. Planet development is normal, Captain. Originally colonised as a freighting-line base in this area. No Federation contacts for over a year. Lieutenant Uhura has had no further response to our signals. Sensors report the expected number of humans on the planet surface. However, they are strangely quiet. Very little activity. They're here, Captain. In the buildings. Strangely quiescent. Captain, several people approaching. Indeed. They seemed most concerned for our safety. Their attitude was inconsistent with their actions. Captain, I understand how you must Notice the ventilator, Captain. Apparently they were trying to keep something outside from getting in. Obviously they were not entirely successful. That is correct. I am at a loss to understand it. The streets are extraordinarily quiet, Captain. We've seen no other Denevans, and the ones we stunned earlier were gone when we came out. A peculiar buzzing sound. We were about to investigate it. Incredible. Not only should it have been destroyed by our phasers, it does not even register on my tricorder. It is not life as we know or understand it. Yet t is obviously alive, it exists. Captain, I suggest we risk taking it aboard. No! No! No, I won't. I must take the ship. Down! I must take it down. Doctor McCoy. Captain. These restraints will no longer be necessary. Nor will your sedatives, Doctor. I'll be able to return to duty. I apologise for my weakness earlier when I tried to take control of the ship. I simply did not understand. I am a Vulcan, Doctor. Pain is a thing of the mind. The mind can be controlled. It is proving to be an inconvenience, but it is manageable. And the creature, with all of its thousands of parts, even now is pressuring me. It wants this ship, but I am resisting. I have my own will, Captain. Let me help. I am a Vulcan. I am a Vulcan. There is no pain. I was. I have an errand on the planet's surface. You will beam me down to the same co-ordinates as before. That is an order, Mister Scott. Until the pain was gone, Captain. It has been discontinued by me. One of the creatures will have to be captured and analysed, Captain. We did not have a clear opportunity to do so earlier when I was attacked. Since my nervous system is already affected, as you pointed out, Doctor, I don't believe they can do much more to me. I am in complete control of myself, Doctor. The fact that I am here proves that I do not belong in bed. Thank you, Captain. Come in, gentlemen. I believe you'll find this interesting. Doctor, your medical skill and curiosity are quite admirable, but I assure you I'm all right. Unimportant at the moment, Doctor. Please observe. Interesting, gentlemen. A one-celled creature resembling, more than anything else, a huge, individual brain cell. Do you understand what I'm suggesting, Captain? And although it is not physically connected to the other cells, it is nevertheless part of the whole creature, guided by the whole, drawing its strength from the whole, which probably accounts for its unusual resistance to our phaser weapons. From a place where our physical laws do not apply. We may therefore find it difficult to destroy, Captain. Yes, sir. I regret I see no other choice for you, Captain. We already know this thing has destroyed three civilisations. Perhaps more. Including myself, Doctor, and Captain Kirk's young nephew. Understandably upsetting, but once it spreads past here, there are dozens of colonies beyond and billions of people. I therefore request permission to beam down to the planet's surface. I also suggest that your nephew accompany me. Captain, I do not make this request lightly. I do not know how much longer I can hold out against the pain. But I do know what the boy will go through should he regain consciousness. It exists physically. It occupies space. It has mass, therefore gravity. It converts matter to energy. A possibility. Yes. In essence, it can be done. A string of satellites around the planet with burning tri-magnesite and trevium. Of course. The light of the sun at the proximity where the Denevan declared himself free was one million candles per square inch. If this works, the satellites we orbit will produce light of such intensity that even someone in a closed, darkened area will be affected by it. Captain, you'll need a host for the next step in the test to determine whether the creature can be driven from the body. I am the logical choice. There'll be none on the planet's surface, Doctor. The creature within me is gone. I am free of it and the pain. And I'm also quite blind. An equitable trade, Doctor. Thank you. Interesting. Just as dogs are sensitive to certain sounds which humans cannot hear, these creatures evidently are sensitive to light which we cannot see. Doctor it was my selection as well. It is done. An hereditary trait, Captain. The brightness of the Vulcan sun has caused the development of an inner eyelid, which acts as a shield against high-intensity light. Totally instinctive, Doctor. We tend to ignore it, as you ignore your own appendix. Quite the contrary, Captain. I had a very strong reaction. My first sight was the face of Doctor McCoy bending over me. My pleasure, Captain. Why, thank you, Doctor McCoy.

Title: Operation -- Annihilate!
Dialogue: ["There's no medical or scientific cause for what happened on those planets. Jim.", "There's one possibility. The mass insanity may have reached this planet, too.", "Jim, your brother Sam and his family, aren't they stationed on this planet?", 'Jim, did you know who that woman was?', "There's something wrong, Jim. Their nervous systems. Unconscious like this, there should be just routine autonomic activity, but I'm getting a very high reading, as though even in their unconscious state, they're being violently stimulated.", 'Is this your brother, Jim?', "I'm sorry, Jim. The boy's unconscious, but he's still alive.", "I'd better get the boy and his mother back to the ship. I can't do much for them down here.", 'McCoy to Enterprise. Prepare to beam up party of four.', "Ready to beam up, Captain. I'd like you to be onboard when your sister-in-law regains consciousness.", "I won't be able to give you the exact cause until I get the plates back from the lab. They're both in extreme pain. I sedated them heavily. But your sister-in-law seems to have a high tolerance. The tranquilliser hasn't affected her much.", 'Yes.', "When she answers questions, any questions, it's as if she's fighting to get the answers out. As though something is exerting pain to stop her.", "I'll do everything I can, Jim, to save him.", "Nurse. That's the second time he's come out of it. Either he's fighting us, or something inside of him is fighting us.", "Let's prepare to close. Nurse!", 'Miss Chapel.', 'Miss Chapel, if you cannot assist me as required, call another nurse in here. But do one or the other now.', "To be very frank, Jim, I don't know that I can do anything for Spock or your nephew. They're pieces of some form of living tissue. I removed one from Spock's spinal cord, the other from your sister-in-law's body. They're both the same. The boy's too weak to touch. Besides, removal of the tissue wouldn't stop the pain anyhow as far as I can tell.", "No. I just removed these for examination. His body's full of these tentacles, entwining and growing all about his nervous system.", "The same. Evidently, when the creature attacks, it leaves a stinger much like a bee or wasp, leaving one of these in the victim's body. It takes over the victim very rapidly, and the entwining is far, far too involved for conventional surgery to remove.", "I'm sorry, Jim. The lab, the science departments, we're all stumped.", "The K3 indicator registers the level of pain. Watch as I turn it on. That's what he's been going through. I've never seen anything like it. No wonder the poor devils go mad.", 'Who knows, Jim? I know the amount of pain the creature can inflict upon him, but whether he can control it hour to hour', 'Yes.', "Jim, aren't you forgetting something? There are over a million colonists on that planet down there, just as much your responsibility. They need your help, too.", "Jim, this is ridiculous. I don't want my patients running around. He should be in bed.", "Jim, that man is sick. Don't give me any damnable logic about him being the only man for the job.", "You may be controlling the pain, Mister Spock, but you're far from all right.", "I'm sorry, Captain. I've tried everything I can. Variant radiation, intense heat, even as great as nine thousand degrees.", "Which happens to be my point. The thing won't die, even at temperatures and radiation which would burn Spock and your nephew to ashes.", "Captain, I understand your concern. Your affection for Spock, the fact that your nephew is the last survivor of your brother's family.", 'Gentlemen, I want it stopped, too, but not at the cost of destroying over a million people.', "If killing five people saves ten, it's a bargain. Is that your simple logic, Mister Spock?", "I'm sorry, Jim. We've been over and over it, made every conceivable test.", "Jim, we've been through it and through it. Radiation, heat", 'Nothing lethal about light.', "You can't move Deneva closer to the sun, Jim.", "Well, I can rig a test cubicle in the bio-lab, put our specimen in it. But I don't", 'Put on your masks.', 'Completed.', "It worked! We can do it. What's the matter, Jim? We can do it.", "Well, I don't know. Maybe trial", "But I'd have to put a", 'Do you have any idea of the risk?', 'Do you know what one million candlelight per square inch can do to your optic nerves?', "All right. I'll rig up a protective pair of goggles.", "Unfortunately, you're both right. It's the only thing we can do. All right, Mister Spock.", "Mister Spock's the best first officer in the fleet.", 'Completed.', 'Oh, no.', "I threw the total spectrum of light at the creature. It wasn't necessary. I didn't stop to think that only one kind of light might've killed it.", "I didn't need to throw the blinding white light at all, Jim. Spock, I", 'McCoy here.', "Yes, Captain. He'll be happy to hear that.", "The blindness was temporary, Jim. There's something about his optical nerves which aren't the same as a human's.", "'Tis a pity your brief blindness did not increase your appreciation for beauty, Mister Spock.", "Unusual eye arrangement. I might've known he'd turn up with something like that.", "I said, please don't tell Spock I said he was the best first officer in the fleet."]

Title: Operation -- Annihilate!
Dialogue: ["Captain, we're picking up a ship on our sensors, heading directly into the Denevan sun. He'll burn up.", "He's too close, Captain.", 'He burned up, Captain.', 'Aye, sir.', 'Aye, aye, sir.', 'Completing the seeding orbit, Captain. Two hundred and ten ultraviolet satellites now in position. Seventy two miles altitude, permanent orbit about the planet.', 'Ready, Captain.', 'Warp factor one, sir.']
Flattened Dialogue: Captain, we're picking up a ship on our sensors, heading directly into the Denevan sun. He'll burn up. He's too close, Captain. He burned up, Captain. Aye, sir. Aye, aye, sir. Completing the seeding orbit, Captain. Two hundred and ten ultraviolet satellites now in position. Seventy two miles altitude, permanent orbit about the planet. Ready, Captain. Warp factor one, sir.

Title: Operation -- Annihilate!
Dialogue: ['Out of range, sir.', "Captain, we'll get too close to the sun.", "Aye, they make regular trips from here carrying supplies to the asteroid belt for the miners and bringing cargo out. I've made the run a couple of times myself as an engineering advisor.", 'None, sir. Just that noise we heard.', 'Mister Spock, I thought you were still confined to Sickbay.', "Here, now. Where do you think you're going?", 'Not likely, Mister Spock.', "Aye, sir, and I'm sorry I have to disobey it. The Captain said no one was to transport down. Mister Spock.", "Freeze right there, Mister Spock, or I'll put you to sleep for sure. This is Mister Scott in the transporter room. Get me the Captain.", "He said he was transporting down to the surface, sir. Your orders were that no one was to beam down unless you authorised it. And knowing Mister Spock's determination on some things, I thought I'd better hold him here until I got your orders.", 'Scanners ready, sir.', 'All satellites operative, Captain.']
Flattened Dialogue: Out of range, sir. Captain, we'll get too close to the sun. Aye, they make regular trips from here carrying supplies to the asteroid belt for the miners and bringing cargo out. I've made the run a couple of times myself as an engineering advisor. None, sir. Just that noise we heard. Mister Spock, I thought you were still confined to Sickbay. Here, now. Where do you think you're going? Not likely, Mister Spock. Aye, sir, and I'm sorry I have to disobey it. The Captain said no one was to transport down. Mister Spock. Freeze right there, Mister Spock, or I'll put you to sleep for sure. This is Mister Scott in the transporter room. Get me the Captain. He said he was transporting down to the surface, sir. Your orders were that no one was to beam down unless you authorised it. And knowing Mister Spock's determination on some things, I thought I'd better hold him here until I got your orders. Scanners ready, sir. All satellites operative, Captain.

Title: Operation -- Annihilate!
Dialogue: ['Doctor, the readings have never looked like that before, not even on Mister Spock.', "Doctor, that's not all you're going to do?", 'Doctor, there is more of it in him, entwined all through his body.', 'Mister Spock.', 'Mister Spock.', 'Bridge, this is Sickbay. Tell Doctor McCoy Mister Spock just left here.', "He's delirious and possibly dangerous.", 'Ready, Doctor.', "Doctor, the results of the first tests on the creature's remains."]
Flattened Dialogue: Doctor, the readings have never looked like that before, not even on Mister Spock. Doctor, that's not all you're going to do? Doctor, there is more of it in him, entwined all through his body. Mister Spock. Mister Spock. Bridge, this is Sickbay. Tell Doctor McCoy Mister Spock just left here. He's delirious and possibly dangerous. Ready, Doctor. Doctor, the results of the first tests on the creature's remains.

Title: Amok Time
Dialogue: ['Oh, Captain. Got a minute?', "It's Spock. Have you noticed anything strange about him?", "Well, it's nothing I can pinpoint without an examination, but he's become increasingly restive. If he were not a Vulcan, I'd almost say nervous. And for another thing, he's avoiding food. I checked and he hasn't eaten at all in three days.", 'Miss Chapel.', 'Captain.', "What's this?", "Oh! Vulcan plomeek soup, and I'll bet you made it too. You never give up hoping, do you?", "It's all right. Carry on, Miss Chapel.", 'Jim, when I suggested to Spock that it was time for his routine check-up, your logical, unemotional first officer turned to me and said, you will cease to pry into my personal matters, Doctor, or I shall certainly break your neck.', "Come in, Spock. I'm all ready for you.", "My orders were to give you a thorough physical. In case you hadn't noticed, I have to answer to the same commanding officer that you do. Come on, Spock. Yield to the logic of the situation.", "Jim, you've got to get Spock to Vulcan.", "No! Now. Right away. If you don't get him to Vulcan within a week eight days at the outside, he'll die. He'll die, Jim.", "I don't know.", "There's a growing imbalance of body functions, as if in our bodies huge amounts of adrenalin were constantly being pumped into our bloodstreams. Now, I can't trace it down in my biocomps. Spock won't tell me what it is. But if it isn't stopped somehow, the physical and emotional pressures will simply kill him.", "He does, and he's as tightlipped about it as an Aldebaran Shellmouth. No use to ask him, Jim. He won't talk.", "Well, that's that.", "You can't go off to Vulcan against Starfleet orders. You'll be busted", 'I shall be honoured, sir.', 'He called it Koon-ut what?', 'And they still go mad at this time. Perhaps the price they pay for having no emotions the rest of the time.', 'Yeah. Hot as Vulcan. Now I understand what that phrase means.', "I wonder when his T'Pring arrives.", "T'Pau. Officiating at Spock's wedding?", "Leonard McCoy, ma'am.", 'With him?', "Ma'am, I don't understand. Are you trying to say that she rejected him? That she doesn't want him?", 'I doubt it. Not in his present condition.', "You can't do it, Jim.", 'No. She said their laws and customs were not binding on you.', "In this climate? If the heat doesn't get you, the thin air will. You can't do it!", 'Jim, listen, if you', 'These men are friends. To force them to fight until one of them is killed', 'Spock! No!', "Is this Vulcan chivalry? The air's too hot and thin for Kirk. He's not used to it.", "I can compensate for the atmosphere and the temperature with this. At least it'll give Kirk a fighting chance.", "You're going to have to kill him, Jim.", "It's a tri-ox compound. It'll help you breathe. Now be careful!", 'McCoy to Enterprise.', "Have the transporter room stand by to beam up the landing party. As strange as it may seem, Mister Spock, you're in command now. Any orders?", 'Spock, I', 'Spock, I', 'Nurse, would you mind, please?', 'Spock, what happened down there? The girl? The wedding?', "There's just one thing, Mister Spock. You can't tell me that when you first saw Jim alive that you weren't on the verge of giving us an emotional scene that would have brought the house down. .", 'Of course, Mister Spock, your reaction was quite logical.', "In a pig's eye!"]
Flattened Dialogue: Oh, Captain. Got a minute? It's Spock. Have you noticed anything strange about him? Well, it's nothing I can pinpoint without an examination, but he's become increasingly restive. If he were not a Vulcan, I'd almost say nervous. And for another thing, he's avoiding food. I checked and he hasn't eaten at all in three days. Miss Chapel. Captain. What's this? Oh! Vulcan plomeek soup, and I'll bet you made it too. You never give up hoping, do you? It's all right. Carry on, Miss Chapel. Jim, when I suggested to Spock that it was time for his routine check-up, your logical, unemotional first officer turned to me and said, you will cease to pry into my personal matters, Doctor, or I shall certainly break your neck. Come in, Spock. I'm all ready for you. My orders were to give you a thorough physical. In case you hadn't noticed, I have to answer to the same commanding officer that you do. Come on, Spock. Yield to the logic of the situation. Jim, you've got to get Spock to Vulcan. No! Now. Right away. If you don't get him to Vulcan within a week eight days at the outside, he'll die. He'll die, Jim. I don't know. There's a growing imbalance of body functions, as if in our bodies huge amounts of adrenalin were constantly being pumped into our bloodstreams. Now, I can't trace it down in my biocomps. Spock won't tell me what it is. But if it isn't stopped somehow, the physical and emotional pressures will simply kill him. He does, and he's as tightlipped about it as an Aldebaran Shellmouth. No use to ask him, Jim. He won't talk. Well, that's that. You can't go off to Vulcan against Starfleet orders. You'll be busted I shall be honoured, sir. He called it Koon-ut what? And they still go mad at this time. Perhaps the price they pay for having no emotions the rest of the time. Yeah. Hot as Vulcan. Now I understand what that phrase means. I wonder when his T'Pring arrives. T'Pau. Officiating at Spock's wedding? Leonard McCoy, ma'am. With him? Ma'am, I don't understand. Are you trying to say that she rejected him? That she doesn't want him? I doubt it. Not in his present condition. You can't do it, Jim. No. She said their laws and customs were not binding on you. In this climate? If the heat doesn't get you, the thin air will. You can't do it! Jim, listen, if you These men are friends. To force them to fight until one of them is killed Spock! No! Is this Vulcan chivalry? The air's too hot and thin for Kirk. He's not used to it. I can compensate for the atmosphere and the temperature with this. At least it'll give Kirk a fighting chance. You're going to have to kill him, Jim. It's a tri-ox compound. It'll help you breathe. Now be careful! McCoy to Enterprise. Have the transporter room stand by to beam up the landing party. As strange as it may seem, Mister Spock, you're in command now. Any orders? Spock, I Spock, I Nurse, would you mind, please? Spock, what happened down there? The girl? The wedding? There's just one thing, Mister Spock. You can't tell me that when you first saw Jim alive that you weren't on the verge of giving us an emotional scene that would have brought the house down. . Of course, Mister Spock, your reaction was quite logical. In a pig's eye!

Title: Amok Time
Dialogue: ['A minute.', 'No, nothing in particular. Why ?', 'That just sounds like Mister Spock in one of his contemplative phases.', "Bones, I'm a busy man.", 'Spock said that?', 'Spock, what the devil is this all about?', "All right, Spock, let's have it.", "I'm more interested in your request for shore leave. In all the years", "In all the years that I've known you, you've never asked for a leave of any sort. In fact, you've refused them. Why now?", "Agreed, but that isn't the question, is it? If there's a problem of some sort, illness in the family", "Then since we're headed for Altair Six, and since the shore facilities there are excellent", "Spock, I'm asking you. What's wrong?", 'Bridge. Helm.', 'Alter course to Vulcan. Increase speed to warp four.', "I suppose most of us overlook the fact that even Vulcans aren't indestructible.", 'Put it on audio over here, Lieutenant.', 'Lieutenant Uhura, acknowledge that message.', 'Mister Chekov, compute course and speed necessary for compliance.', "Head directly for Altair Six. Sailor's luck, Mister Spock. Or, as one of Finagle's Laws puts it, 'Any home port the ship makes ill be somebody else's, not mine'. The new president of Altair Six wants to get himself launched a week early, so we have to be there a week early. Don't worry. I'll see that you get your leave as soon as we're finished.", 'Bridge. Navigation.', 'Mister Chekov, how late will we arrive for the ceremonies if we increase speed to maximum and divert to Vulcan just long enough to drop off Mister Spock?', 'How far behind schedule will diverting to Vulcan put us?', 'Thank you, Mister Chekov. Kirk, out.', 'Mister Spock. Come with me, please.', "Deck five. You've changed course for Vulcan, Mister Spock. Why?", 'Do you deny it?', "Then why'd you do it?", "I'm trying to help you, Spock.", 'I order you to report to the Sickbay.', "Complete examination. McCoy's waiting.", 'Bones, I will, I will. As soon as this mission is', 'Why must he die? Why within eight days? Explain.', "You keep saying that. Are you a doctor, or aren't you?", "You say you're convinced he knows what it is?", "Stay. McCoy has given me his medical evaluation of your condition. He says you're going to die unless something is done. What? Is it something only your planet can do for you? Spock! You've been called the best first officer in the fleet. That's an enormous asset to me. If I have to lose that first officer, I want to know why.", 'No, I do not understand. Explain. Consider that an order.', "Would it help if I told you that I'll treat this as totally confidential?", 'What?', 'What kind of biology?', "You mean the biology of Vulcans? Biology as in reproduction? Well, there's no need to be embarrassed about it, Mister Spock. It happens to the birds and the bees.", "I guess the rest of us assume that it's done quite logically.", "But you're not a fish, Mister Spock. You're", "I haven't heard a word you've said, and I'll get you to Vulcan somehow.", "Lieutenant, get me Admiral Komack at Starfleet Command, Sector Nine. Pipe it down to McCoy's office.", "I'm aware of that, sir, but it's of the utmost importance. You must give me permission to divert to Vulcan.", "I can't, sir, but believe me, I wouldn't make such a request", 'Sir, the delay would be, at most, a day. I can hardly believe that', "No, it's not. I know the Altair situation. We would be one of three starships. Very impressive, very diplomatic, but it's simply not that vital.", "I can't let Spock die, can I, Bones? And he will if we go to Altair. I owe him my life a dozen times over. Isn't that worth a career? He's my friend. Bridge. Navigation.", "Mister Chekov, lay in a course for Vulcan. Tell Engineering I want warp eight or better. Push her for all she'll take.", 'I see. Very well. Carry on, Mister Chekov. Kirk, out.', 'Bridge.', "Will I? You've been most patient with my kinds of madness.", 'Is it permitted?', 'Thank you, Mister Spock.', 'Open the channel, Lieutenant. Vulcan Space Central, this is the USS Enterprise requesting permission to assume standard orbit.', 'He described it to me as meaning marriage or challenge. In the distant past, Vulcans killed to win their mates.', "It's lovely. I wish the breeze were cooler.", 'The atmosphere is thinner than Earth.', "Marriage party? You said T'Pring was your wife.", "Bones, you know who that is? T'Pau. The only person to ever turn down a seat on the Federation Council.", 'He never mentioned that his family was this important.', "Ma'am.", 'What is it? What happened?', 'Spock?', "We'll stay.", 'Think Spock can take him?', 'What happens to Spock if I decline?', "I can't?", 'And you said Spock might not be able to handle him. If I can knock Spock out without really hurting him', "If I get into any trouble, I'll quit. And Spock wins, and honour is satisfied.", "Bones. He's my first officer and my friend. I disregarded Starfleet orders to bring him here. Another thing, that's T'Pau of Vulcan. All of Vulcan in one package. How can I back out in front of her?", 'I accept the challenge.', 'What do you mean, if both survive?', "Now wait a minute, ma'am. Who said anything about a fight to the death?", "Kill Spock? That's not what I came to Vulcan for, is it? What's that?", 'Sound medical advice.', "Don't you think you better check with me first?", 'Blame McCoy. That was no tri-ox compound he shot me with. He slipped in a neural paralyser. Knocked me out, simulated death.', 'Kirk here.', 'Relay it, Lieutenant.', "Well, a little late, but I'm glad they're seeing it our way. How about that T'Pau? They couldn't turn her down. Mister Chekov, lay in a course for Altair Six. Leave orbit when ready. Kirk out.", 'Yes, Mister Spock. I understand.', "Come on, Spock. Let's go mind the store."]

Open the channel, Lieutenant. Vulcan Space Central, this is the USS Enterprise requesting permission to assume standard orbit. He described it to me as meaning marriage or challenge. In the distant past, Vulcans killed to win their mates. It's lovely. I wish the breeze were cooler. The atmosphere is thinner than Earth. Marriage party? You said T'Pring was your wife. Bones, you know who that is? T'Pau. The only person to ever turn down a seat on the Federation Council. He never mentioned that his family was this important. Ma'am. What is it? What happened? Spock? We'll stay. Think Spock can take him? What happens to Spock if I decline? I can't? And you said Spock might not be able to handle him. If I can knock Spock out without really hurting him If I get into any trouble, I'll quit. And Spock wins, and honour is satisfied. Bones. He's my first officer and my friend. I disregarded Starfleet orders to bring him here. Another thing, that's T'Pau of Vulcan. All of Vulcan in one package. How can I back out in front of her? I accept the challenge. What do you mean, if both survive? Now wait a minute, ma'am. Who said anything about a fight to the death? Kill Spock? That's not what I came to Vulcan for, is it? What's that? Sound medical advice. Don't you think you better check with me first? Blame McCoy. That was no tri-ox compound he shot me with. He slipped in a neural paralyser. Knocked me out, simulated death. Kirk here. Relay it, Lieutenant. Well, a little late, but I'm glad they're seeing it our way. How about that T'Pau? They couldn't turn her down. Mister Chekov, lay in a course for Altair Six. Leave orbit when ready. Kirk out. Yes, Mister Spock. I understand. Come on, Spock. Let's go mind the store.

Title: Amok Time
Dialogue: ['Doctor McCoy.', 'Captain.', 'Oh.', "Well, Mister Spock hasn't been eating, Doctor, and I, I just happened to notice.", 'Yes, Mister Spock?', "I don't understand.", "I came to tell you that we are bound for Vulcan. We'll be there in just a few days.", 'My name is Christine.', "Oh, I'd be very glad to do that, Mister Spock.", "Doctor, what's going on?"]
Flattened Dialogue: Doctor McCoy. Captain. Oh. Well, Mister Spock hasn't been eating, Doctor, and I, I just happened to notice. Yes, Mister Spock? I don't understand. I came to tell you that we are bound for Vulcan. We'll be there in just a few days. My name is Christine. Oh, I'd be very glad to do that, Mister Spock. Doctor, what's going on?

Title: Amok Time
Dialogue: ['What is this?', "Poking and prying! If I want anything from you, I'll ask for it!", 'Captain, I should like to request a leave of absence on my home planet. On our present course you can divert to Vulcan with a loss of but two point eight light days.', 'I have made my request, Captain. All I require from you is that you answer it. Yes or no.', 'It is undignified for a woman to play servant to a man who is not hers.', 'You have my request, Captain. Will you grant it or not?', 'Captain, surely I have enough leave time accumulated.', 'No. Nothing of that nature, Captain.', 'No! I must. I wish to take my leave on Vulcan.', "I need rest. I'm asking you to accept that answer.", 'Thank you, Captain.', "No. We're not.", 'I quite understand, Captain.', 'Changed the course?', 'No. No, by no means, Captain. It is quite possible.', 'Captain, I accept on your word that I did it, but I do not know why, nor do I remember doing it. Captain, lock me away. I do not wish to be seen. I cannot. No Vulcan could explain further.', 'Ask me no further questions. I will not answer.', 'Sickbay?', "My orders were to report to Sickbay, Doctor. I have done so. And now I'll go to my quarters.", "Examine me, for all the good it'll do either of us.", 'Come.', 'It is a thing no out-worlder may know except those very few who have been involved. A Vulcan understands, but even we do not speak of it among ourselves. It is a deeply personal thing. Can you see that, Captain, and understand?', 'Captain, there are some things which transcend even the discipline of the service.', 'It has to do with biology.', 'Biology.', 'Vulcan biology.', "The birds and the bees are not Vulcans, Captain. If they were, if any creature as proudly logical as us were to have their logic ripped from them as this time does to us. How do Vulcans choose their mates? Haven't you wondered?", 'No. No. It is not. We shield it with ritual and customs shrouded in antiquity. You humans have no conception. It strips our minds from us. It brings a madness which rips away our veneer of civilisation. It is the pon farr. The time of mating. There are precedents in nature, Captain. The giant eelbirds of Regulus Five, once each eleven years they must return to the caverns where they hatched. On your Earth, the salmon. They must return to that one stream where they were born, to spawn or die in trying.', "No. Nor am I a man. I'm a Vulcan. I'd hoped I would be spared this, but the ancient drives are too strong. Eventually, they catch up with us, and we are driven by forces we cannot control to return home and take a wife. Or die.", 'Let me alone. Let me alone!', 'Miss Chapel.', "I had a most startling dream. You were trying to tell me something, but I couldn't hear you. It would be illogical for us to protest against our natures. Don't you think?", 'Your face is wet.', 'Vulcan. Miss Chapel.', 'Yes, I know, Christine. Would you make me some of that plomeek soup?', 'It is obvious that you have surmised my problem, Doctor. My compliments on your insight. Captain, there is a thing that happens to Vulcans at this time. Almost an insanity, which you would no doubt find distasteful.', "Then would you beam down to the planet's surface and stand with me? There is a brief ceremony.", 'It is my right. By tradition, the male is accompanied by his closest friends.', 'I also request McCoy accompany me.', 'This is Spock.', "T'Pring, parted from me and never parted, never and always touching and touched. We meet at the appointed place.", "She is T'Pring. My wife.", 'This is the land of my family. It has been held by us for more than two thousand Earth years. This is our place of Koon-ut-kal-if-fee,', 'The marriage party approaches. I hear them.', "By our parents' arrangement. A ceremony while we were but seven years of age. Less than a marriage but more than a betrothal. One touches the other in order to feel each other's thoughts. In this way our minds were locked together, so that at the proper time, we would both be drawn to Koon-ut-kal-if-fee.", 'They are not outworlders. They are my friends. I am permitted this.', 'This is Kirk.', "With my life, T'Pau.", "T'Pau.", 'My friend does not understand.', "He does not know. I will do what I must, T'Pau, but not with him! His blood does not burn. He is my friend!", "I burn, T'Pau. My eyes are flame. My heart is flame. Thee has the power, T'Pau. In the name of my fathers, forbid. Forbid! T'Pau. I plead with thee! I beg!", "Yes. I'll follow you up in a few minutes. You will instruct Mister Chekov to plot a course for the nearest Starbase where I must surrender myself to the authorities. T'Pring. Explain.", 'Why the challenge, and why you chose my captain as your champion.', 'I see no logic in preferring Stonn over me.', 'Logical. Flawlessly logical.', "Stonn. She is yours. After a time, you may find that having is not so pleasing a thing after all as wanting. It is not logical, but it is often true. Spock here. Stand by to beam up. Live long, T'Pau, and prosper.", 'I shall do neither. I have killed my captain and my friend. Energize.', 'Doctor, I shall be resigning my commission immediately, of course.', 'So I would appreciate your making the final arrangements.', "Doctor, please, let me finish. There can be no excuse for the crime of which I'm guilty. I intend to offer no defence. Furthermore, I shall order Mister Scott to take immediate command of this vessel.", 'Captain! Jim!', "I'm pleased to see you, Captain. You seem uninjured. I am at something of a loss to understand it, however.", 'Indeed.', "Ah, yes, the girl. Most interesting. It must have been the combat. When I thought I had killed the captain, I found I had lost all interest in T'Pring. The madness was gone.", 'Merely my quite logical relief that Starfleet had not lost a highly proficient captain.', 'Thank you, Captain.', 'Thank you, Doctor.']
Flattened Dialogue: What is this? Poking and prying! If I want anything from you, I'll ask for it! Captain, I should like to request a leave of absence on my home planet. On our present course you can divert to Vulcan with a loss of but two point eight light days. I have made my request, Captain. All I require from you is that you answer it. Yes or no. It is undignified for a woman to play servant to a man who is not hers. You have my request, Captain. Will you grant it or not? Captain, surely I have enough leave time accumulated. No. Nothing of that nature, Captain. No! I must. I wish to take my leave on Vulcan. I need rest. I'm asking you to accept that answer. Thank you, Captain. No. We're not. I quite understand, Captain. Changed the course? No. No, by no means, Captain. It is quite possible. Captain, I accept on your word that I did it, but I do not know why, nor do I remember doing it. Captain, lock me away. I do not wish to be seen. I cannot. No Vulcan could explain further. Ask me no further questions. I will not answer. Sickbay? My orders were to report to Sickbay, Doctor. I have done so. And now I'll go to my quarters. Examine me, for all the good it'll do either of us. Come. It is a thing no out-worlder may know except those very few who have been involved. A Vulcan understands, but even we do not speak of it among ourselves. It is a deeply personal thing. Can you see that, Captain, and understand? Captain, there are some things which transcend even the discipline of the service. It has to do with biology. Biology. Vulcan biology. The birds and the bees are not Vulcans, Captain. If they were, if any creature as proudly logical as us were to have their logic ripped from them as this time does to us. How do Vulcans choose their mates? Haven't you wondered? No. No. It is not. We shield it with ritual and customs shrouded in antiquity. You humans have no conception. It strips our minds from us. It brings a madness which rips away our veneer of civilisation. It is the pon farr. The time of mating. There are precedents in nature, Captain. The giant eelbirds of Regulus Five, once each eleven years they must return to the caverns where they hatched. On your Earth, the salmon. They must return to that one stream where they were born, to spawn or die in trying. No. Nor am I a man. I'm a Vulcan. I'd hoped I would be spared this, but the ancient drives are too strong. Eventually, they catch up with us, and we are driven by forces we cannot control to return home and take a wife. Or die. Let me alone. Let me alone! Miss Chapel. I had a most startling dream. You were trying to tell me something, but I couldn't hear you. It would be illogical for us to protest against our natures. Don't you think? Your face is wet. Vulcan. Miss Chapel. Yes, I know, Christine. Would you make me some of that plomeek soup? It is obvious that you have surmised my problem, Doctor. My compliments on your insight. Captain, there is a thing that happens to Vulcans at this time. Almost an insanity, which you would no doubt find distasteful. Then would you beam down to the planet's surface and stand with me? There is a brief ceremony. It is my right. By tradition, the male is accompanied by his closest friends. I also request McCoy accompany me. This is Spock. T'Pring, parted from me and never parted, never and always touching and touched. We meet at the appointed place. She is T'Pring. My wife. This is the land of my family. It has been held by us for more than two thousand Earth years. This is our place of Koon-ut-kal-if-fee, The marriage party approaches. I hear them. By our parents' arrangement. A ceremony while we were but seven years of age. Less than a marriage but more than a betrothal. One touches the other in order to feel each other's thoughts. In this way our minds were locked together, so that at the proper time, we would both be drawn to Koon-ut-kal-if-fee. They are not outworlders. They are my friends. I am permitted this. This is Kirk. With my life, T'Pau. T'Pau. My friend does not understand. He does not know. I will do what I must, T'Pau, but not with him! His blood does not burn. He is my friend! I burn, T'Pau. My eyes are flame. My heart is flame. Thee has the power, T'Pau. In the name of my fathers, forbid. Forbid! T'Pau. I plead with thee! I beg! Yes. I'll follow you up in a few minutes. You will instruct Mister Chekov to plot a course for the nearest Starbase where I must surrender myself to the authorities. T'Pring. Explain. Why the challenge, and why you chose my captain as your champion. I see no logic in preferring Stonn over me. Logical. Flawlessly logical. Stonn. She is yours. After a time, you may find that having is not so pleasing a thing after all as wanting. It is not logical, but it is often true. Spock here. Stand by to beam up. Live long, T'Pau, and prosper. I shall do neither. I have killed my captain and my friend. Energize. Doctor, I shall be resigning my commission immediately, of course. So I would appreciate your making the final arrangements. Doctor, please, let me finish. There can be no excuse for the crime of which I'm guilty. I intend to offer no defence. Furthermore, I shall order Mister Scott to take immediate command of this vessel. Captain! Jim! I'm pleased to see you, Captain. You seem uninjured. I am at something of a loss to understand it, however. Indeed. Ah, yes, the girl. Most interesting. It must have been the combat. When I thought I had killed the captain, I found I had lost all interest in T'Pring. The madness was gone. Merely my quite logical relief that Starfleet had not lost a highly proficient captain. Thank you, Captain. Thank you, Doctor.

Title: Amok Time
Dialogue: ['Yes, Captain?', 'Aye, sir.', "How do you figure it, Chekov? First we're going to Vulcan, then we're going to Altair, then we're headed to Vulcan again, and now we're headed back to Altair.", 'Maybe you ought to plot a course back for Vulcan, just in case.']
Flattened Dialogue: Yes, Captain? Aye, sir. How do you figure it, Chekov? First we're going to Vulcan, then we're going to Altair, then we're headed to Vulcan again, and now we're headed back to Altair. Maybe you ought to plot a course back for Vulcan, just in case.

Title: Amok Time
Dialogue: ["Captain, something's coming in on the Starfleet channel. Priority and urgent, sir.", 'Message complete, sir. Switching over.', 'Aye, aye, sir.', 'Starfleet Command. Yes, sir.', 'Communication to Mister Spock. Lieutenant Uhura here. The captain asked me to', "Captain. We're standing by on Vulcan hailing frequencies, sir.", "She's lovely, Mister Spock. Who is she?", 'Enterprise. Lieutenant Uhura here.', 'Captain Kirk. Message from Starfleet Command, top priority.', "Response to T'Pau's request for diversion of Enterprise to planet Vulcan", 'Hereby approved. Any reasonable delay granted. Komack, Admiral, Starfleet Command.']
Flattened Dialogue: Captain, something's coming in on the Starfleet channel. Priority and urgent, sir. Message complete, sir. Switching over. Aye, aye, sir. Starfleet Command. Yes, sir. Communication to Mister Spock. Lieutenant Uhura here. The captain asked me to Captain. We're standing by on Vulcan hailing frequencies, sir. She's lovely, Mister Spock. Who is she? Enterprise. Lieutenant Uhura here. Captain Kirk. Message from Starfleet Command, top priority. Response to T'Pau's request for diversion of Enterprise to planet Vulcan Hereby approved. Any reasonable delay granted. Komack, Admiral, Starfleet Command.

Title: Amok Time
Dialogue: ["We'll have to head directly there at warp six, sir. Insufficient time to stop off at Vulcan.", 'Navigation. Chekov here.', "I don't understand, Captain.", "We're on course for Vulcan, Captain, as Mister Spock ordered.", "I think I'm going to get space sick.", "Mister Sulu, you don't think", 'Bridge. Navigation.', 'Course already plotted. Laying it in, sir.']
Flattened Dialogue: We'll have to head directly there at warp six, sir. Insufficient time to stop off at Vulcan. Navigation. Chekov here. I don't understand, Captain. We're on course for Vulcan, Captain, as Mister Spock ordered. I think I'm going to get space sick. Mister Sulu, you don't think Bridge. Navigation. Course already plotted. Laying it in, sir.

Title: Who Mourns for Adonais
Dialogue: ['Bugs the? Well, carry out the standard procedures on Pollux Four.', 'Bones, could you get that excited over a cup of coffee?', "Why, Bones? Scotty's a good man.", 'I like to think of it not so much losing an officer as gaining', "Actually, I'm losing an officer.", 'Cartographic Detail, stand by.', 'Preliminary reports, Mister Spock.', 'Cartographic Sections, implement standard orders.', 'Analysis, Mister Spock.', 'What is it, Mister Spock? Is it a hand?', 'A trick, then? A projection?', 'Hard about.', 'Reverse all engines.', 'Lieutenant, relay our position and circumstances to Starbase Twelve immediately.', 'Mister Sulu try rocking the ship. Full impulse power forward and back.', 'Thank you. Mister Sulu?', 'Mister Spock. Status.', 'Thank you. Mister Sulu. Our forward tractor beams, adjust to repel.', 'Activate.', "Let's all take a look at it, Mister Spock.", 'Response frequencies, Lieutenant.', 'This is Captain James T. Kirk, commanding the USS Enterprise. Please identify yourself.', 'Are you responsible for stopping the ship?', "Give it back, then we'll talk.", "I don't know who or what you are, but I must warn you we have the power to defend ourselves. If you value your safety, release this ship.", 'Never mind the history lesson. Release the ship!', 'Compensate.', "All right! Whatever you're doing, turn it off! You win!", "Let's go, Bones. You in good voice?", "If we don't accept his invitation, we'll have a crushed eggshell where this ship used to be.", 'Insulted, Spock?', "Good. We'll tackle him together. We already know the questions. You're the best man to find the answers.", 'Tricorders.', 'Come on.', "You know of Earth? You've been there?", 'You mentioned Agamemnon, Hector, Odysseus. How do you know about them?', 'Mister Chekov.', "And you haven't yet. Readings, Doctor.", 'Evidently not so simple.', "All right. We're here at your invitation. Would you mind telling us what you want without all the Olympian generalities?", 'Transporter room.', 'Enterprise, come in.', 'What is it you want?', "If you want to play god and call yourself Apollo, that's your business, but you're no god to us, Mister.", "And you've got a lot to learn!", 'Analysis. Lieutenant Palamas, what do you know about Apollo?', 'And this thing?', 'I think the appearance of this is for our benefit. Bones?', 'Fine, but what power, and where is it? Scout around with your tricorders. Find the source of that power. Bones.', 'Bones, I wonder if five thousand years ago', 'I have an idea. What if he is really Apollo?', "Apollo, we're willing to talk, but you'll find we don't bow to every creature who happens to have a bag of tricks.", 'I have four hundred and thirty people on that ship up there.', "Scotty. Very impressive. How'd you do it?", 'Bones, how is he?', 'He would have been rather difficult to stop.', "Mister Chekov, I think you'd better continue your investigation.", 'How do you feel, Scotty?', 'It would seem so.', "Mister Scott, I understand your concern over her, but she volunteered to go with him, hopefully to find out more about him. She's doing her job. I think it's about time you started doing yours. We've got to find out the source of his power. You've got a tricorder. Use it if you're able to.", "And one more thing. I want no more unauthorised action against Apollo or whatever he is. That's an order!", 'Besides, you stiff-necked thistle head, you could have gotten yourself killed.', "Apollo's no god. But he could have been taken for one, though, once. Say five thousand years ago, a highly sophisticated group of space travellers landed on Earth around the Mediterranean.", "Especially if they had the power to alter their form at will and command great energy. In fact, they couldn't have been taken for anything else.", "I've just picked up readings for our own people, sir.", 'Apollo has no difficulty focusing. He taps that energy, Mister Scott.', 'Are you suggesting that he, Apollo, taps a flow of energy and channels it through his body?', "Mister Chekov, I think you've earned your pay for the week. But where is the source of that power?", 'Is that all you have to offer?', 'Bones, is it possible', "Where's Lieutenant Palamas?", 'Scotty!', "All right, mister. You wanted worshippers? You've got enemies. You want us to bow down, you'll have to", 'Take care of Scotty.', "Where's Apollo?", "Don't you mean the English story, the Cheshire Cat?", 'All right, all right, all right.', 'Very good, Mister Chekov. That might very well mean something.', "We've got to get out of here.", "Well, let's assume that five thousand years ago creatures like our friend Apollo did indeed visit Earth and form the basis of the Greek classic myths.", 'Most mythology has its basis in fact. If I remember my ancient legends, the gods, after expending energy, required rest, even as we humans.', "Something like that. Remember, he's keeping a force field on the ship and he's expending energy down here. You said he looked pained and tired when he disappeared. If we can wear him out, overwork him, that might do it.", "If we can provoke him so that he strikes one of us again, there's a chance that he'll be drained enough so the rest of us can jump him.", "Not all of us, Bones. When he comes back, it's a chance we'll have to take.", "You know nothing about our kind. You know only our remote ancestors who trembled before your tricks. Your tricks don't frighten us, neither do you. We've come a long way in five thousand years.", 'Mankind has no need for gods. We find the one quite adequate.', "We're busy. Look after the girl.", 'Go! Gather laurel leaves? You must be joking!', 'Lieutenant, get back.', "We're tired of your phony fireworks!", 'Lieutenant!', 'Lieutenant!', 'Lieutenant.', "And you will supply the herds of sheep, and the pipes we'll play, and the simple skins we'll wear for clothes.", 'We were doing something until our brave lady stepped in and saved us.', "Yes, I have. One more. And it depends on the lieutenant's loyalty. If she fails us, we'd better get used to herding goats.", 'Kirk to Enterprise, come in. Enterprise, come in. Kirk to Enterprise, come in. Kirk to', "Scotty, I'll find out.", 'How old are you?', "Then I'd better handle it. You all right?", 'Come over there. Well?', "All right, Lieutenant, you can come down from Mount Olympus now. You've got work to do.", 'He thrives on love, worship, attention.', "We can't give him that worship, none of us can. Especially you.", "Spurn him. Reject him. You must. You're special to him.", 'Lieutenant. All our lives, here and on the ship, depend on you.', 'On you, Lieutenant! Reject him, and we have a chance to save ourselves. Accept him, and you condemn all of us to slavery, nothing less than slavery. We might never get help this far out. Or perhaps the thought of spending an eternity bending knee and tending sheep appeals to you.', "Give me your hand. Your hand. Now feel that. Human flesh against human flesh. We're the same. We share the same history, the same heritage, the same lives. We're tied together beyond any untying. Man or woman, it makes no difference. We're human. We couldn't escape from each other even if we wanted to. That's how you do it, Lieutenant. By remembering who and what you are. A bit of flesh and blood afloat in a universe without end. The only thing that's truly yours is the rest of humanity. That's where our duty lies. Do you understand me?", 'Lieutenant. You have your orders and your duty.', 'Kirk here.', 'There is indeed, Mister Spock.', 'Very good. How are you doing on the force field?', "Well, that ought to do it. Have Sulu lock all phaser banks onto the structure. Fire on my order only. Cut it fine. We'll be standing nearby.", "I'd love to oblige you, Mister Spock, but we're not all together. Besides, we have Apollo to deal with.", 'If that structure is the source of his power, I want to know where he is when we attack it.', 'Kirk out.', "Bones, do you think that mysterious organ in Apollo's chest could have something to do with the transmission of energy?", "Yes, I know. I know. Scotty. We'll wait.", 'Kirk here.', 'Stand by your phasers, Mister Spock. Prepare to fire on my signal. Kirk out.', "We've got to be here when he comes back.", 'Scotty, just hold on!', "All right. The temple is his power source. Let's bring him back to it. Get to cover. Mister Spock, fire those phasers.", "Fire those phasers! That's an order, Mister Spock!", 'Scotty!', "We've out grown you. You asked for something we could no longer give.", 'So do I. They gave us so much. The Greek civilisation, much of our culture and philosophy came from a worship of those beings. In a way, they began the Golden Age. Would it have hurt us, I wonder, just to have gathered a few laurel leaves?']
