Title: The Doomsday Machine
Dialogue: ['The whole communication system looks to be shorted out, too, sir.', 'Come along, lads.', "I don't know, lad. But I want a full structural and control damage check, and I'm going to have a look at those engines.", "Captain, I've checked the engines. The warp drive is a hopeless pile of junk. The impulse engines are not too badly off. We ought to be able to do something with them.", "Exhausted. They didn't give up without a battle.", "Computer system is still intact. We can playback the duplicate Captain's Log from the auxiliary control room.", 'Ready with the duplicate log, sir.', 'Captain, Washburn has our report.', 'Aye, that all adds up. But what sort of a thing could do all that?', 'And paralysed. No power.', "I can't repair warp drive without a spacedock.", 'Aye, the impulse engines are still in fair shape. I might coax them.', 'Come on, lad.', "Captain, the impulse engines' control circuits are fused solid.", "Aye, we can cross-connect the controls, but it'll make the ship almost impossible for one man to handle.", 'Aye, sir.', 'Controls are all hooked up, sir. We should have some power for you soon.', "Coming, sir. If I push these impulse engines too hard in the condition they're in, they'll blow apart.", 'Aye, sir.', "You've got it, Captain. Just enough to move us. I can't do better.", "Captain, I still don't know what we're doing.", "Phasers? You've got 'em. I have one bank recharged.", 'Captain Kirk.', "I've hooked in ship's communication. The best I can give you on impulse is one third power. The shields are up but they won't last long.", 'Here, sir. The damage control party just beamed back to the Enterprise.', "Aye. The shape the thing's in, it's hard to keep her from blowing.", 'Aye, sir.', 'Right away.', "A cranky transporter's a mighty finicky piece of machinery to be gambling your life on, sir.", "I've linked it in with the impulse control system. It's armed now. Press this one. Thirty seconds later, poof! Once it's activated, there's no way to stop it.", 'Good luck, Captain.', "What's the matter with that thing?", "It'll never work like this. It's the main junction circuitry. I'll get it.", "Bridge, transporter operational, but this jury-rigging won't last for long. He's got to come off now.", "I'll stand by here.", "Och, what's wrong with it?", 'Try her now, Mister Kyle.']
Flattened Dialogue: The whole communication system looks to be shorted out, too, sir. Come along, lads. I don't know, lad. But I want a full structural and control damage check, and I'm going to have a look at those engines. Captain, I've checked the engines. The warp drive is a hopeless pile of junk. The impulse engines are not too badly off. We ought to be able to do something with them. Exhausted. They didn't give up without a battle. Computer system is still intact. We can playback the duplicate Captain's Log from the auxiliary control room. Ready with the duplicate log, sir. Captain, Washburn has our report. Aye, that all adds up. But what sort of a thing could do all that? And paralysed. No power. I can't repair warp drive without a spacedock. Aye, the impulse engines are still in fair shape. I might coax them. Come on, lad. Captain, the impulse engines' control circuits are fused solid. Aye, we can cross-connect the controls, but it'll make the ship almost impossible for one man to handle. Aye, sir. Controls are all hooked up, sir. We should have some power for you soon. Coming, sir. If I push these impulse engines too hard in the condition they're in, they'll blow apart. Aye, sir. You've got it, Captain. Just enough to move us. I can't do better. Captain, I still don't know what we're doing. Phasers? You've got 'em. I have one bank recharged. Captain Kirk. I've hooked in ship's communication. The best I can give you on impulse is one third power. The shields are up but they won't last long. Here, sir. The damage control party just beamed back to the Enterprise. Aye. The shape the thing's in, it's hard to keep her from blowing. Aye, sir. Right away. A cranky transporter's a mighty finicky piece of machinery to be gambling your life on, sir. I've linked it in with the impulse control system. It's armed now. Press this one. Thirty seconds later, poof! Once it's activated, there's no way to stop it. Good luck, Captain. What's the matter with that thing? It'll never work like this. It's the main junction circuitry. I'll get it. Bridge, transporter operational, but this jury-rigging won't last for long. He's got to come off now. I'll stand by here. Och, what's wrong with it? Try her now, Mister Kyle.

Title: The Doomsday Machine
Dialogue: ['Commodore? Commodore Decker?', "Jim, give him a minute. He's in a state of shock.", "This whole thing's incredible. A robot? A machine like that, who would build it?", 'But why?', "No. I'm a doctor, not a mechanic.", "The first thing we're going to do is get you back to the Enterprise.", 'Come on.', 'No casualties, Mister Spock. How are we doing?', "In plain, non-Vulcan English, we've been lucky.", "You can't let him do this, Spock.", 'So are you, sir. Well, Spock?', "To blazes with regulations! You can't let him take command when you know he's wrong!", "I'll certify that right now.", "Now, you know I haven't had time to run an examination on him.", "What about the Captain? We can't leave", 'Spock, do something!']
Flattened Dialogue: Commodore? Commodore Decker? Jim, give him a minute. He's in a state of shock. This whole thing's incredible. A robot? A machine like that, who would build it? But why? No. I'm a doctor, not a mechanic. The first thing we're going to do is get you back to the Enterprise. Come on. No casualties, Mister Spock. How are we doing? In plain, non-Vulcan English, we've been lucky. You can't let him do this, Spock. So are you, sir. Well, Spock? To blazes with regulations! You can't let him take command when you know he's wrong! I'll certify that right now. Now, you know I haven't had time to run an examination on him. What about the Captain? We can't leave Spock, do something!

Title: Catspaw
Dialogue: ['Still no response, sir.', 'Contact established, Captain.', "I'm sorry. I can't clear it, Captain.", 'Yes, sir.', 'Enterprise. Lieutenant Uhura here.', 'Captain, we are only registering on you. Captain? Captain Kirk?', "Mister DeSalle, that's exactly what happened to Mister Scott and his party. They, they just disappeared.", 'Aye, aye, sir.', 'Captain, are you all right? Where are you? Are the others all right, sir?', "Enterprise to Captain Kirk. Come in, please. Enterprise to Captain Kirk. Acknowledge. We've lost him again, Mister DeSalle.", "I don't see any change.", 'Standing by, Captain.']
Flattened Dialogue: Still no response, sir. Contact established, Captain. I'm sorry. I can't clear it, Captain. Yes, sir. Enterprise. Lieutenant Uhura here. Captain, we are only registering on you. Captain? Captain Kirk? Mister DeSalle, that's exactly what happened to Mister Scott and his party. They, they just disappeared. Aye, aye, sir. Captain, are you all right? Where are you? Are the others all right, sir? Enterprise to Captain Kirk. Come in, please. Enterprise to Captain Kirk. Acknowledge. We've lost him again, Mister DeSalle. I don't see any change. Standing by, Captain.

Title: Catspaw
Dialogue: ["No, keep it open. I don't like this. Nothing since the first check in. Scott and Sulu should've contacted us again a half an hour ago.", "Both those men are well aware of landing party procedure. They should've checked in with us by now.", 'Enterprise. Kirk here.', 'One? Jackson, where are Scott and Sulu?', 'Jackson!', 'Notify Transporter room to prepare to beam up one member of the landing party. Then have Doctor McCoy report to me in the Transporter room on the double.', 'Energise.', 'Trouble. Jackson, where are the others?', "Odd. Our probe data didn't indicate fog.", 'Readings, Mister Spock.', 'Kirk to Enterprise.', "What are the ship's sensors reading now, Lieutenant?", 'Lieutenant, can you hear me?', "I don't know. There has to be some explanation for the fact that the ship's sensors can't register anything but us, while we're picking up readings of multiple life forms. Are they still there, Spock?", 'Stand-by alert.', 'Quiet.', 'Who are you?', 'Spock. Comment?', 'A more useful comment, Mister Spock.', "That's useful.", "That's where we're going.", 'Kirk to Enterprise. Enterprise, come in.', 'What about it, Spock? Does this structure have anything to do with communicator interference?', "And it doesn't pick up on our ship's sensors.", 'Could it be exerting a force field of some kind that cuts into our sensor scan.', "If we weren't missing two officers and a third one dead I'd say someone was playing an elaborate trick or treat on us.", "Yes, Mister Spock. You'd be a natural. I'll explain it to you one day. Shall we have a look around?", 'Bones. Spock.', 'Straight ahead, Mister Spock?', 'Spock. Are you all right?', 'Bones? Doc?', "Dungeons, curses, skeletons and iron maidens. They're all Earth manifestations. Why?", "None of this parallels any human development. It's more like a human nightmare.", 'Ghost stories, ogres, demons. The whole', 'Scotty, Sulu. Scotty. Put down the phaser. Scotty!', "These two are alive. Scotty, do you hear me? Sulu, do you know who I am? What's happened to you?", "Whoever you are, you've proven your skill at creating illusion. Now I want to know why and what you've done to my men.", 'Not when one of my men is dead because of it and two others turned into mindless', 'Who are you? Why did you bring us here?', 'Why? For what reason? Why all the mumbo-jumbo?', 'That cat.', 'Superstition.', 'All right, Korob. What do you want from us?', "You'll find us most unco-operative unless you start explaining yourself.", 'We could manufacture a ton of these on our ship. They mean nothing to us.', "Whatever it is you read, you read it wrong. As for leaving, we'll leave when we're ready.", "Don't move! Cover them. Now, I want the rest of our weapons and our equipment. I want some answers.", "You can't think a man to death.", 'Kirk to Enterprise. Come in. Come in.', 'Enterprise. From Captain Kirk. Come in.', "Never mind about us. What's happening up there?", 'DeSalle, channel bypass power into your heat dissipation units.', "All right. I'll handle it down here. Kirk out. You've won.", "You seem to be singing a different tune. I'd rather know more about yours. You call it magic, you call it science. It seems unrelated to both of them.", "I wouldn't attempt to name it, but you seem to do with your mind what we do with tools. You alter matter, move it about by telekinesis.", "It's too late for threats. You let me contact the ship. How long do you think it will it be before a search party arrives?", 'We have nothing to discuss.', 'How long has it been?', "Thanks. I wonder what they're doing to Doc.", 'Familiar. Startling. Not rational.', 'Ghosts, witches.', 'They tried to tap our conscious mind.', "He expected me to react as though it were all normal. Well, he admitted that they weren't native to this planet.", "They refer to us as creatures, as though we were some species that they were unfamiliar with. If we're creatures, I wonder what they're really like.", "Agreed. Totally alien. And I don't like hostile strangers showing such an acute interest in our galaxy, our world, Spock. Not at all like friendly visitors. We're going to have to stop them, cold. But at the moment", 'Oh, Bones. Doc.', 'What now? You wave your magic wand and destroy my mind, too?', "You don't call that damage?", "You'd know if you had compassion. A woman should have compassion, but I forget you're not a woman.", 'You seem to need us. Why?', 'What about Korob?', "Why don't you simply probe my mind and get what you want?", "You're very persuasive. What happens if I go along?", "For the same reasons you excite me. You're a very beautiful woman.", 'You have a knack for giving me difficult choices. You have nothing like that where you come from?', 'Your people, when they come here', 'Transmuter?', "Then it's a device. You do use tools.", "You haven't changed your mind? You won't return home?", "And why not? You've been using me and my crew.", "I'm not leaving without my men.", 'Transmuter. Yes, she mentioned that.', 'Why a cat?', "You'd better let us. It's out of energy. She must have drained it. We could have jumped Scott and Sulu at any time. We didn't know. No way out.", 'Do you think you can make it?', 'Get ready.', "Korob, that door won't last.", 'Korob seemed to think this was important. Said something about a transmuter.', 'Doc.', 'Well, at least we found them.', "Maybe we do. Sylvia, I have the transmuter. It's mine now.", "Don't you get tired of these games?", "I wasn't sure before, but I am now. This is the source of your power, isn't it. The transmuter.", 'I catch on quickly.', 'Why? Because your people have nothing of your own? Is that why you need us?', 'No.', "I don't know what you are but you're not a woman. You've tortured my men and taken their minds from them. You ask for love and return pain instead.", "That'll take some explaining, Bones.", 'Not everything.', 'Korob and Sylvia as they really are. Their forms were an illusion, just like the castle and everything else. Only the power pack gave them reality.', 'No illusion. Jackson is dead. Kirk to Enterprise. Come in.', 'Five to beam up.']
Flattened Dialogue: No, keep it open. I don't like this. Nothing since the first check in. Scott and Sulu should've contacted us again a half an hour ago. Both those men are well aware of landing party procedure. They should've checked in with us by now. Enterprise. Kirk here. One? Jackson, where are Scott and Sulu? Jackson! Notify Transporter room to prepare to beam up one member of the landing party. Then have Doctor McCoy report to me in the Transporter room on the double. Energise. Trouble. Jackson, where are the others? Odd. Our probe data didn't indicate fog. Readings, Mister Spock. Kirk to Enterprise. What are the ship's sensors reading now, Lieutenant? Lieutenant, can you hear me? I don't know. There has to be some explanation for the fact that the ship's sensors can't register anything but us, while we're picking up readings of multiple life forms. Are they still there, Spock? Stand-by alert. Quiet. Who are you? Spock. Comment? A more useful comment, Mister Spock. That's useful. That's where we're going. Kirk to Enterprise. Enterprise, come in. What about it, Spock? Does this structure have anything to do with communicator interference? And it doesn't pick up on our ship's sensors. Could it be exerting a force field of some kind that cuts into our sensor scan. If we weren't missing two officers and a third one dead I'd say someone was playing an elaborate trick or treat on us. Yes, Mister Spock. You'd be a natural. I'll explain it to you one day. Shall we have a look around? Bones. Spock. Straight ahead, Mister Spock? Spock. Are you all right? Bones? Doc? Dungeons, curses, skeletons and iron maidens. They're all Earth manifestations. Why? None of this parallels any human development. It's more like a human nightmare. Ghost stories, ogres, demons. The whole Scotty, Sulu. Scotty. Put down the phaser. Scotty! These two are alive. Scotty, do you hear me? Sulu, do you know who I am? What's happened to you? Whoever you are, you've proven your skill at creating illusion. Now I want to know why and what you've done to my men. Not when one of my men is dead because of it and two others turned into mindless Who are you? Why did you bring us here? Why? For what reason? Why all the mumbo-jumbo? That cat. Superstition. All right, Korob. What do you want from us? You'll find us most unco-operative unless you start explaining yourself. We could manufacture a ton of these on our ship. They mean nothing to us. Whatever it is you read, you read it wrong. As for leaving, we'll leave when we're ready. Don't move! Cover them. Now, I want the rest of our weapons and our equipment. I want some answers. You can't think a man to death. Kirk to Enterprise. Come in. Come in. Enterprise. From Captain Kirk. Come in. Never mind about us. What's happening up there? DeSalle, channel bypass power into your heat dissipation units. All right. I'll handle it down here. Kirk out. You've won. You seem to be singing a different tune. I'd rather know more about yours. You call it magic, you call it science. It seems unrelated to both of them. I wouldn't attempt to name it, but you seem to do with your mind what we do with tools. You alter matter, move it about by telekinesis. It's too late for threats. You let me contact the ship. How long do you think it will it be before a search party arrives? We have nothing to discuss. How long has it been? Thanks. I wonder what they're doing to Doc. Familiar. Startling. Not rational. Ghosts, witches. They tried to tap our conscious mind. He expected me to react as though it were all normal. Well, he admitted that they weren't native to this planet. They refer to us as creatures, as though we were some species that they were unfamiliar with. If we're creatures, I wonder what they're really like. Agreed. Totally alien. And I don't like hostile strangers showing such an acute interest in our galaxy, our world, Spock. Not at all like friendly visitors. We're going to have to stop them, cold. But at the moment Oh, Bones. Doc. What now? You wave your magic wand and destroy my mind, too? You don't call that damage? You'd know if you had compassion. A woman should have compassion, but I forget you're not a woman. You seem to need us. Why? What about Korob? Why don't you simply probe my mind and get what you want? You're very persuasive. What happens if I go along? For the same reasons you excite me. You're a very beautiful woman. You have a knack for giving me difficult choices. You have nothing like that where you come from? Your people, when they come here Transmuter? Then it's a device. You do use tools. You haven't changed your mind? You won't return home? And why not? You've been using me and my crew. I'm not leaving without my men. Transmuter. Yes, she mentioned that. Why a cat? You'd better let us. It's out of energy. She must have drained it. We could have jumped Scott and Sulu at any time. We didn't know. No way out. Do you think you can make it? Get ready. Korob, that door won't last. Korob seemed to think this was important. Said something about a transmuter. Doc. Well, at least we found them. Maybe we do. Sylvia, I have the transmuter. It's mine now. Don't you get tired of these games? I wasn't sure before, but I am now. This is the source of your power, isn't it. The transmuter. I catch on quickly. Why? Because your people have nothing of your own? Is that why you need us? No. I don't know what you are but you're not a woman. You've tortured my men and taken their minds from them. You ask for love and return pain instead. That'll take some explaining, Bones. Not everything. Korob and Sylvia as they really are. Their forms were an illusion, just like the castle and everything else. Only the power pack gave them reality. No illusion. Jackson is dead. Kirk to Enterprise. Come in. Five to beam up.

Title: Catspaw
Dialogue: ['They may have nothing to report. Our sensors indicate no life forms except our landing party.', 'No cloud formations, no bodies of water, no changes in surface temperature. Under these conditions, fog is highly unlikely, Captain. According to our transporter co-ordinates this is the exact location from which Jackson was beamed up to the ship.', 'No indications of. A moment, Captain. Picking up life form readings. Twenty four degrees mark seven. Range one thirty seven point one six metres. Multiple readings, Captain.', 'No change, Captain.', 'Very bad poetry, Captain.', "What we've just seen is not real.", 'However, on azimuth twenty four, at just over one hundred metres, there are definitely life forms. Erratic, confused, but definitely registering.', "This is the source of the life form readings, Captain. They're inside, somewhere.", "I would say not, Captain. There's no indication of anything that would cause such interference.", 'Nor do our sensors register the life forms inside.', 'Trick or treat, Captain?', 'That would seem to be in order.', 'The readings would so indicate.', 'Yes. I am undamaged, Captain.', 'I do not know, Captain, but these things do exist. They are real.', 'As if someone knew what it was that terrifies man most on an instinctive level.', 'Neither did Jackson just before he collapsed.', 'Mapping expeditions have charted this solar system before. There never have been any life forms on Pyris Seven.', 'There are ancient Earth legends about wizards and their familiars.', 'Demons in animal forms sent by Satan to serve the wizard.', 'I do not create the legend, Captain. I merely report it.', 'Ingenious.', 'Mind probing? Hypnosis?', 'Telepathy?', "Not entirely, no. Telepathy doesn't imply control and I assure you that I have full control over your friends.", 'Twenty two minutes, seventeen seconds.', "I'm sure we'll find out shortly. Jim, all of these things that we've seen. To an Earthman like yourself, they must seem quite familiar.", 'Precisely. I refer you to the psychological theory of the racial subconscious. The universal myths, symbols.', 'And dungeons and castles and black cats. They all belong to the twilight world of consciousness.', "And they missed. They reached basically only the subconscious. Korob seemed puzzled by your reaction to the environment he'd provided.", "And not to have a knowledge of our scientific methods is most unlikely for any life form we've met in this galaxy.", 'Evidently something totally alien in all respects.', 'I, too, am at a loss at this time to suggest a course of action.', 'You came in a ship?', 'Fascinating.', 'Racial memories. The cat is the most ruthless, most terrifying of animals, as far back as the sabre-toothed tiger.', 'Ready when you are, Captain.', 'Quickly, Captain.', 'Captain, a bit more alacrity, if you please.', 'Captain.', 'Jim!', 'Fortuitous, Captain. And now that we have them all together? A most unpleasant situation, Captain. If only your phaser had some power.', "Don't let her touch the wand, Captain.", 'Jim!', 'Fascinating. A life form totally alien to our galaxy. If we could preserve and study this']
Flattened Dialogue: They may have nothing to report. Our sensors indicate no life forms except our landing party. No cloud formations, no bodies of water, no changes in surface temperature. Under these conditions, fog is highly unlikely, Captain. According to our transporter co-ordinates this is the exact location from which Jackson was beamed up to the ship. No indications of. A moment, Captain. Picking up life form readings. Twenty four degrees mark seven. Range one thirty seven point one six metres. Multiple readings, Captain. No change, Captain. Very bad poetry, Captain. What we've just seen is not real. However, on azimuth twenty four, at just over one hundred metres, there are definitely life forms. Erratic, confused, but definitely registering. This is the source of the life form readings, Captain. They're inside, somewhere. I would say not, Captain. There's no indication of anything that would cause such interference. Nor do our sensors register the life forms inside. Trick or treat, Captain? That would seem to be in order. The readings would so indicate. Yes. I am undamaged, Captain. I do not know, Captain, but these things do exist. They are real. As if someone knew what it was that terrifies man most on an instinctive level. Neither did Jackson just before he collapsed. Mapping expeditions have charted this solar system before. There never have been any life forms on Pyris Seven. There are ancient Earth legends about wizards and their familiars. Demons in animal forms sent by Satan to serve the wizard. I do not create the legend, Captain. I merely report it. Ingenious. Mind probing? Hypnosis? Telepathy? Not entirely, no. Telepathy doesn't imply control and I assure you that I have full control over your friends. Twenty two minutes, seventeen seconds. I'm sure we'll find out shortly. Jim, all of these things that we've seen. To an Earthman like yourself, they must seem quite familiar. Precisely. I refer you to the psychological theory of the racial subconscious. The universal myths, symbols. And dungeons and castles and black cats. They all belong to the twilight world of consciousness. And they missed. They reached basically only the subconscious. Korob seemed puzzled by your reaction to the environment he'd provided. And not to have a knowledge of our scientific methods is most unlikely for any life form we've met in this galaxy. Evidently something totally alien in all respects. I, too, am at a loss at this time to suggest a course of action. You came in a ship? Fascinating. Racial memories. The cat is the most ruthless, most terrifying of animals, as far back as the sabre-toothed tiger. Ready when you are, Captain. Quickly, Captain. Captain, a bit more alacrity, if you please. Captain. Jim! Fortuitous, Captain. And now that we have them all together? A most unpleasant situation, Captain. If only your phaser had some power. Don't let her touch the wand, Captain. Jim! Fascinating. A life form totally alien to our galaxy. If we could preserve and study this

Title: Catspaw
Dialogue: ["What's on, Jim?", 'The man is dead.', 'Scott and Sulu?', "Whatever this stuff is, it's getting thicker. Suppose that has anything to do with the interference?", 'Listen. Now, what do you think that', 'That was a pretty real illusion, Mister Spock.', 'Jim.', 'Is this how we lost contact with the first landing party?', "Then it would affect Spock's tricorder too, wouldn't it?", 'Three witches, what appears to be a castle and a black cat.', 'Dust, cobwebs. Halloween is right.', 'You were saying something about trick or treat.', 'Could this be an Earth parallel development of some sort?', 'They appear to be drugged, Jim. Look at their eyes. Hardly blink at all.', "They're going to release us.", 'That cat.', 'Familiars?', "He doesn't know about trick or treat.", "We're not hungry.", 'These look real.', 'Tests?', "You kept Scott and Sulu as catspaws to lure us down here. How'd you know we'd come?", 'What happened, Jim?', 'Too late. All of this, just an illusion.']
Flattened Dialogue: What's on, Jim? The man is dead. Scott and Sulu? Whatever this stuff is, it's getting thicker. Suppose that has anything to do with the interference? Listen. Now, what do you think that That was a pretty real illusion, Mister Spock. Jim. Is this how we lost contact with the first landing party? Then it would affect Spock's tricorder too, wouldn't it? Three witches, what appears to be a castle and a black cat. Dust, cobwebs. Halloween is right. You were saying something about trick or treat. Could this be an Earth parallel development of some sort? They appear to be drugged, Jim. Look at their eyes. Hardly blink at all. They're going to release us. That cat. Familiars? He doesn't know about trick or treat. We're not hungry. These look real. Tests? You kept Scott and Sulu as catspaws to lure us down here. How'd you know we'd come? What happened, Jim? Too late. All of this, just an illusion.

Title: Catspaw
Dialogue: ["I am only picking up physical impulses from the three of them. As far as instruments can make out, there is nothing else down there that's alive.", "They're gone, Mister DeSalle. The captain and the others simply stopped registering.", 'I did, sir, as soon as it happened.', "I can do it, sir. I'm not that green.", "It's up sixty degrees in the past thirty seconds. We're burning up, sir.", 'Temperature is almost back to normal, dropping down fast.', "It's some kind of a force field, sir, but not like any other I've ever heard of before. It's not coming from anywhere. It's simply all around us.", 'It will not analyse, sir.', "It was that electrical field we set up, Mister DeSalle, that dent you wanted. It's not much, but it is a start."]
Flattened Dialogue: I am only picking up physical impulses from the three of them. As far as instruments can make out, there is nothing else down there that's alive. They're gone, Mister DeSalle. The captain and the others simply stopped registering. I did, sir, as soon as it happened. I can do it, sir. I'm not that green. It's up sixty degrees in the past thirty seconds. We're burning up, sir. Temperature is almost back to normal, dropping down fast. It's some kind of a force field, sir, but not like any other I've ever heard of before. It's not coming from anywhere. It's simply all around us. It will not analyse, sir. It was that electrical field we set up, Mister DeSalle, that dent you wanted. It's not much, but it is a start.

Title: Catspaw
Dialogue: ["Everything's vanished."]
Flattened Dialogue: Everything's vanished.

Title: I, Mudd
Dialogue: ['Something wrong?', "Perhaps you're making a rather hasty judgment. Mister Norman has only been aboard seventy two hours.", 'Specifics, Doctor. Labels do not make arguments.', 'I see.', 'I find your argument strewn with gaping defects in logic.', "That's not at all surprising, Doctor. He's probably terrified of your beads and rattles.", 'Interesting.', "Confirmed, Captain. He's taken out all the override controls. If we tamper without knowing where the trigger relay is, we could extinguish ourselves.", 'And most sophisticated.', 'He simply appears to have turned himself off, Captain. And since we cannot repair the damage he has done without destroying the ship', 'Five hundred of the same model? That seems rather redundant.', 'He did not pay royalties.', 'The guilty party has his choice. Death by electrocution, death by gas, death by phaser, death by hanging.', 'You went to substantial risk and effort to bring a starship here. Logically, you must have a compelling motive.', "Then I'm unable to discern your problem.", 'Whom do you serve now?', 'We are, and we must direct our attack to the heart of the matter. Obviously this many androids cannot operate independently. There must be a central control system which guides the entire android population.', 'Very interesting. Very interesting. This is a most unusual device.', 'Did I understand there are more than two hundred thousand of you?', 'This would seem to be a simple relay centre. Are all of you controlled through this device?', "Oh, that's quite understandable.", "Captain, I've just had a most fascinating meeting with Norman, and I'm convinced I've discovered a very important inconsistency.", "He could successfully accomplish it, Captain. I've questioned a number of the androids, and they're totally loyal to Mudd. Perhaps of more concern is the fact that this android population can literally provide anything a human being could ask for in unlimited quantity.", 'Unhappiness is the state which occurs in the human when wants and desires are not fulfilled.', 'Fascinating.', "I'm curious, Norman. Just how do you intend to stop them?", 'Eminently practical.', 'Indeed, it is not. They may quite possibly be able to accomplish it.', "Whatever method we use to stop them, we must make haste. They have only to install some cybernetic devices aboard the Enterprise and they'll be able to leave orbit.", 'I asked them.', 'Yet the device that Norman claims to be their central control is totally inadequate to the task of directing more than two hundred thousand of them.', 'There are a large number of Alices and Trudies, Maisies, Annabels, and according to my research, a Herman series, an Oscar series, a whole plethora of series in fact. But only one Norman.', 'To function as they do, each android mind must be one component of a mass brain linked through a central locus.', 'That would seem logical.', 'What would seem to be a sound, and perhaps our only, opportunity.', 'I fail to understand why I should care to induce my mother to purchase falsified patents.', 'Of course. Your computations would inevitably lead to a total description of the parabolic intersection of dimension with dimension.', 'Thank you.', 'I love you. However, I hate you.', 'Yes, of course. That is exactly why I hate you. Because you are identical.', 'Fascinating.', "Success, Captain. We've been pruning the leaves and branches of the tree. Now it is time to get to work on the root.", 'Affirmative.', 'Logic is a little tweeting bird chirping in a meadow. Logic is a wreath of pretty flowers which smell bad. Are you sure your circuits are registering correctly? Your ears are green.', 'Very well, Captain.', 'I believe that is the correct amount, Captain. Mister Mudd, are you ready?', 'Be careful. I would not want you to drop it.', 'I believe they are all immobilised, Captain.', 'That is a human emotion, Doctor, with which I am totally unfamiliar. How could I be unhappy?', 'Which I find eminently satisfactory, Doctor, for nowhere am I so desperately needed as among a shipload of illogical humans.', "The androids are being reprogrammed. Their original purpose was to adapt this planet for productive use. They'll begin that work again."]
Flattened Dialogue: Something wrong? Perhaps you're making a rather hasty judgment. Mister Norman has only been aboard seventy two hours. Specifics, Doctor. Labels do not make arguments. I see. I find your argument strewn with gaping defects in logic. That's not at all surprising, Doctor. He's probably terrified of your beads and rattles. Interesting. Confirmed, Captain. He's taken out all the override controls. If we tamper without knowing where the trigger relay is, we could extinguish ourselves. And most sophisticated. He simply appears to have turned himself off, Captain. And since we cannot repair the damage he has done without destroying the ship Five hundred of the same model? That seems rather redundant. He did not pay royalties. The guilty party has his choice. Death by electrocution, death by gas, death by phaser, death by hanging. You went to substantial risk and effort to bring a starship here. Logically, you must have a compelling motive. Then I'm unable to discern your problem. Whom do you serve now? We are, and we must direct our attack to the heart of the matter. Obviously this many androids cannot operate independently. There must be a central control system which guides the entire android population. Very interesting. Very interesting. This is a most unusual device. Did I understand there are more than two hundred thousand of you? This would seem to be a simple relay centre. Are all of you controlled through this device? Oh, that's quite understandable. Captain, I've just had a most fascinating meeting with Norman, and I'm convinced I've discovered a very important inconsistency. He could successfully accomplish it, Captain. I've questioned a number of the androids, and they're totally loyal to Mudd. Perhaps of more concern is the fact that this android population can literally provide anything a human being could ask for in unlimited quantity. Unhappiness is the state which occurs in the human when wants and desires are not fulfilled. Fascinating. I'm curious, Norman. Just how do you intend to stop them? Eminently practical. Indeed, it is not. They may quite possibly be able to accomplish it. Whatever method we use to stop them, we must make haste. They have only to install some cybernetic devices aboard the Enterprise and they'll be able to leave orbit. I asked them. Yet the device that Norman claims to be their central control is totally inadequate to the task of directing more than two hundred thousand of them. There are a large number of Alices and Trudies, Maisies, Annabels, and according to my research, a Herman series, an Oscar series, a whole plethora of series in fact. But only one Norman. To function as they do, each android mind must be one component of a mass brain linked through a central locus. That would seem logical. What would seem to be a sound, and perhaps our only, opportunity. I fail to understand why I should care to induce my mother to purchase falsified patents. Of course. Your computations would inevitably lead to a total description of the parabolic intersection of dimension with dimension. Thank you. I love you. However, I hate you. Yes, of course. That is exactly why I hate you. Because you are identical. Fascinating. Success, Captain. We've been pruning the leaves and branches of the tree. Now it is time to get to work on the root. Affirmative. Logic is a little tweeting bird chirping in a meadow. Logic is a wreath of pretty flowers which smell bad. Are you sure your circuits are registering correctly? Your ears are green. Very well, Captain. I believe that is the correct amount, Captain. Mister Mudd, are you ready? Be careful. I would not want you to drop it. I believe they are all immobilised, Captain. That is a human emotion, Doctor, with which I am totally unfamiliar. How could I be unhappy? Which I find eminently satisfactory, Doctor, for nowhere am I so desperately needed as among a shipload of illogical humans. The androids are being reprogrammed. Their original purpose was to adapt this planet for productive use. They'll begin that work again.

Title: I, Mudd
Dialogue: ["Yes. There's something odd about that man, and I can't quite pinpoint it.", "I know when something doesn't strike me right, and he doesn't.", "All right. There's something wrong about a man who never smiles, whose conversation never varies from the routine of the job, and who won't talk about his background.", "Spock, I mean that it's odd for a non-Vulcan. The ears make all the difference.", "Maybe, but you can't evaluate a man by logic alone. Besides, he has avoided two appointments that I've made for his physical exam without reason.", 'Oh, I find that shocking.', "Harry, what's this?", 'Dead?', "That's very interesting. You leave your wife and then bring her along.", "Then your makers weren't humanoid?", "I think Mister Chekov's right. We are in a lot of trouble.", "Jim, you should see the research facilities. They've got a lab down there that. Well, I could spend the rest of my life studying it.", "I wouldn't be bored, I can tell you that.", "I did. And you can forget it. They're perfect, flawless, mentally and physically. No weaknesses, perfectly disciplined. No vices, no fears, no faults. Just a sense of purpose. Believe me, there's nothing tougher to overcome, even among humans.", 'How do you know so much?', 'Oh.', 'You wanted to leave us on this ruddy rock and leave by yourself.', 'He is dying.', 'Completely inner directed. Oblivious to everything.', "All right, it's worked so far, but we're not out yet.", 'You offer us only well-being.', 'Suffering, in torment and pain. Labouring without end.', "He's dead.", "Easy now. Oh, he's caught it!", 'Well, you must be very unhappy, Mister Spock.', "Well, we found a whole world of minds that work just like yours. Logical, unemotional, completely pragmatic. And we poor, irrational humans whipped them in a fair fight. Now you'll find yourself back among us illogical humans again."]
Flattened Dialogue: Yes. There's something odd about that man, and I can't quite pinpoint it. I know when something doesn't strike me right, and he doesn't. All right. There's something wrong about a man who never smiles, whose conversation never varies from the routine of the job, and who won't talk about his background. Spock, I mean that it's odd for a non-Vulcan. The ears make all the difference. Maybe, but you can't evaluate a man by logic alone. Besides, he has avoided two appointments that I've made for his physical exam without reason. Oh, I find that shocking. Harry, what's this? Dead? That's very interesting. You leave your wife and then bring her along. Then your makers weren't humanoid? I think Mister Chekov's right. We are in a lot of trouble. Jim, you should see the research facilities. They've got a lab down there that. Well, I could spend the rest of my life studying it. I wouldn't be bored, I can tell you that. I did. And you can forget it. They're perfect, flawless, mentally and physically. No weaknesses, perfectly disciplined. No vices, no fears, no faults. Just a sense of purpose. Believe me, there's nothing tougher to overcome, even among humans. How do you know so much? Oh. You wanted to leave us on this ruddy rock and leave by yourself. He is dying. Completely inner directed. Oblivious to everything. All right, it's worked so far, but we're not out yet. You offer us only well-being. Suffering, in torment and pain. Labouring without end. He's dead. Easy now. Oh, he's caught it! Well, you must be very unhappy, Mister Spock. Well, we found a whole world of minds that work just like yours. Logical, unemotional, completely pragmatic. And we poor, irrational humans whipped them in a fair fight. Now you'll find yourself back among us illogical humans again.

Title: I, Mudd
Dialogue: ['Yes, Mister Sulu?', 'Correct it.', "Auxiliary control, this is the captain. Title: I, Mudd
Dialogue: ['Aye, sir.', 'I should say so.', 'How long does a body like that last?', 'Five hundred thousand years?', 'And it is a very pleasant place, Captain.', 'Oh, nothing really important. Just immortality.', "No, they're lying. It's a trick. Doctor McCoy injected something into Harry Mudd to make him look sick. It's a trick to get back on board and sabotage the ship.", "Because I want an android body. I want immortality. I'll live forever, Captain. I'll be young and beautiful.", 'Thank you.', 'I half believed it myself.', 'Thank you, kind sir.']
Flattened Dialogue: Aye, sir. I should say so. How long does a body like that last? Five hundred thousand years? And it is a very pleasant place, Captain. Oh, nothing really important. Just immortality. No, they're lying. It's a trick. Doctor McCoy injected something into Harry Mudd to make him look sick. It's a trick to get back on board and sabotage the ship. Because I want an android body. I want immortality. I'll live forever, Captain. I'll be young and beautiful. Thank you. I half believed it myself. Thank you, kind sir.

Title: I, Mudd
Dialogue: ["Here, you're not allowed", "Captain, he's here.", 'Let go of me! Now what are you doing? What kind of a woman', "Harry Mudd! Oh, you bogus frat, you. You're the cause of all this, are you?", 'Aye, sir. And I stayed until that female gargantua threw me into the transporter beams.', "Absolutely fantastic. Hand-worked to the finest tolerances, microvision, and a nanopulse laser. I've never seen the like before.", "Captain, you should see this shop! Why, they have facilities we've never even thought of.", 'What did they offer you, Uhura?', "Well, Captain, androids and robots, they're just not capable of independent, creative thought.", 'How does it look?', 'Food and drink and happiness mean nothing to us. We must be about our job.', 'Dying and crying and lamenting over our burdens.', "I canna go on! I'm tired of happiness. I'm tired of comfort and pleasure. I'm ready! Kill me! Kill me!", 'Goodbye, cruel universe.', 'Explosive!']
Flattened Dialogue: Here, you're not allowed Captain, he's here. Let go of me! Now what are you doing? What kind of a woman Harry Mudd! Oh, you bogus frat, you. You're the cause of all this, are you? Aye, sir. And I stayed until that female gargantua threw me into the transporter beams. Absolutely fantastic. Hand-worked to the finest tolerances, microvision, and a nanopulse laser. I've never seen the like before. Captain, you should see this shop! Why, they have facilities we've never even thought of. What did they offer you, Uhura? Well, Captain, androids and robots, they're just not capable of independent, creative thought. How does it look? Food and drink and happiness mean nothing to us. We must be about our job. Dying and crying and lamenting over our burdens. I canna go on! I'm tired of happiness. I'm tired of comfort and pleasure. I'm ready! Kill me! Kill me! Goodbye, cruel universe. Explosive!

Title: I, Mudd
Dialogue: ['You know this man, Captain?', "I think we're in a lot of trouble.", "Oh, yes, thank you. You're Alice", "And you're Alice", "Oh, well, it doesn't make much difference. You're both lovely.", "What a shame you're not real.", 'Oh, I mean real girls.', 'You are?', 'Harry Mudd programmed you?', 'That unprincipled, evil-minded, lecherous kulak Harry Mudd programmed you?', 'This place is even better than Leningrad.', "I don't know, sir, but it's a very nice gilded cage.", "What's next, Captain?", 'Thank you, gentlemen. Thank you, lovely lady. You dance divinely.', 'Yes, Captain.']
Flattened Dialogue: You know this man, Captain? I think we're in a lot of trouble. Oh, yes, thank you. You're Alice And you're Alice Oh, well, it doesn't make much difference. You're both lovely. What a shame you're not real. Oh, I mean real girls. You are? Harry Mudd programmed you? That unprincipled, evil-minded, lecherous kulak Harry Mudd programmed you? This place is even better than Leningrad. I don't know, sir, but it's a very nice gilded cage. What's next, Captain? Thank you, gentlemen. Thank you, lovely lady. You dance divinely. Yes, Captain.

Title: Metamorphosis
Dialogue: ['We have reached projected point three, Captain. Adjust to new course two oh one mark one five.', 'Captain.', 'Will you check your automatic scanner, please?', 'Nor have I.', 'Heading directly toward us at warp speed.', 'Vaguely like a cloud of ionised hydrogen, but with strong erratic electrical impulses.', 'Helm does not answer, Captain.', 'Cut, Captain.', 'Now on course nine eight mark one two, heading directly toward Gamma Canaris region.', 'Gravity is similar to Earth. Most unusual in view of its size. The bulk of the body seems to be iron and nickel. More than an asteroid. Like a small planetoid, I should say. Possibly a remnant of a planet breakup. Totally suitable for human life.', 'Most unusual. Unlikely. In fact, Captain, I would say quite impossible.', 'Precisely.', 'Obviously.', 'The ionised cloud.', 'Fascinating.', 'Correct.', 'Which seems to be on the surface of this body at the moment.', "You say we'll be unable to get the ship to function again?", "You don't mind if we continue to try?", 'You built this, Mister Cochrane?', 'Not bad.', 'Captain, Doctor.', 'We imagined nothing, Mister Cochrane. There was an entity out there and I suspect it was the same entity which brought us here. Please explain.', 'You were injured?', 'I prefer to reserve judgment on that part of your story, sir. Meanwhile, would you please explain exactly what this Companion of yours is?', 'The name of Zefram Cochrane is revered throughout the known galaxy. Planets were named after him. Great universities, cities.', 'True, his body was never found.', 'If so, you wear your age very well.', 'Captain. These instruments, they date from the time indicated. From your ship, Mister Cochrane?', 'You ask me to find a weapon. Do you intend to destroy it?', 'Quite clear, Captain.', 'Yes. Quite all right, Doctor. A most fascinating thing happened. Apparently, the Companion imparted to me a rather quaint, old-fashioned electric shock of respectable voltage.', 'Evidently. Unquestionably, a large part of its substance is simple electricity.', 'Quite correct, Doctor.', 'Put this in the proximity of the Companion, throw this switch, and it will scramble every electrical impulse the creature can produce. It cannot fail.', 'We may simply render it powerless.', 'There is some risk, Captain. We do not know the extent of its powers.', 'All right.', 'Yes, Captain?', 'The translator is for use with more congruent life forms.', 'It is possible. If I could widen its pattern of reception', 'Then it translates its findings into English.', 'Quite ready, Captain.', 'Yes. The matter of gender could change the entire situation.', 'Then it is not a zookeeper.', 'This is a marvellous opportunity to add to our knowledge. Ask it about its nature, its history.', 'A chance like this may never come again. It could tell us so much.', 'Her attitude when she approaches you is profoundly different than when she contacts us. Her appearance is soft, gentle. Her voice is melodic, pleasing. I do not totally understand the emotion, but it obviously exists. The Companion loves you.', 'Your highly emotional reaction is most illogical. Your relationship with the Companion has for one hundred and fifty years been emotionally satisfying, eminently practical, and totally harmless. It may indeed have been quite beneficial.', 'Fascinating. A totally parochial attitude.', 'But she or it is inhuman, Captain. You cannot expect her to react like a human.', 'Companion, you do not have the power to create life.', 'Commissioner Hedford was dying.', 'Then you are both here, in the one body?', 'Not coming from a human being. You are, after all, essentially irrational.', "But you will age, both of you. There will be no immortality. You'll both grow old here and finally die."]

In fact, Captain, I would say quite impossible. Precisely. Obviously. The ionised cloud. Fascinating. Correct. Which seems to be on the surface of this body at the moment. You say we'll be unable to get the ship to function again? You don't mind if we continue to try? You built this, Mister Cochrane? Not bad. Captain, Doctor. We imagined nothing, Mister Cochrane. There was an entity out there and I suspect it was the same entity which brought us here. Please explain. You were injured? I prefer to reserve judgment on that part of your story, sir. Meanwhile, would you please explain exactly what this Companion of yours is? The name of Zefram Cochrane is revered throughout the known galaxy. Planets were named after him. Great universities, cities. True, his body was never found. If so, you wear your age very well. Captain. These instruments, they date from the time indicated. From your ship, Mister Cochrane? You ask me to find a weapon. Do you intend to destroy it? Quite clear, Captain. Yes. Quite all right, Doctor. A most fascinating thing happened. Apparently, the Companion imparted to me a rather quaint, old-fashioned electric shock of respectable voltage. Evidently. Unquestionably, a large part of its substance is simple electricity. Quite correct, Doctor. Put this in the proximity of the Companion, throw this switch, and it will scramble every electrical impulse the creature can produce. It cannot fail. We may simply render it powerless. There is some risk, Captain. We do not know the extent of its powers. All right. Yes, Captain? The translator is for use with more congruent life forms. It is possible. If I could widen its pattern of reception Then it translates its findings into English. Quite ready, Captain. Yes. The matter of gender could change the entire situation. Then it is not a zookeeper. This is a marvellous opportunity to add to our knowledge. Ask it about its nature, its history. A chance like this may never come again. It could tell us so much. Her attitude when she approaches you is profoundly different than when she contacts us. Her appearance is soft, gentle. Her voice is melodic, pleasing. I do not totally understand the emotion, but it obviously exists. The Companion loves you. Your highly emotional reaction is most illogical. Your relationship with the Companion has for one hundred and fifty years been emotionally satisfying, eminently practical, and totally harmless. It may indeed have been quite beneficial. Fascinating. A totally parochial attitude. But she or it is inhuman, Captain. You cannot expect her to react like a human. Companion, you do not have the power to create life. Commissioner Hedford was dying. Then you are both here, in the one body? Not coming from a human being. You are, after all, essentially irrational. But you will age, both of you. There will be no immortality.
