Title: Patterns of Force
Dialogue: ['Aye, sir.', 'Spacecraft approaching from inner planet.', 'Phasers ready.', 'Two thousand kilometres, closing fast.', 'Orbit computed and locked in, sir.']
Flattened Dialogue: Aye, sir. Spacecraft approaching from inner planet. Phasers ready. Two thousand kilometres, closing fast. Orbit computed and locked in, sir.

Title: Patterns of Force
Dialogue: ['Aye, aye, sir.', 'Captain, no response on any Starfleet channel.', 'Nothing, sir.', 'Captain, no response from John Gill on any channel.', 'Enterprise. Lieutenant Uhura.', "Yes, sir. Captain, we're not reading you well. You're nine points into the low-frequency band.", 'Yes, sir.', 'Doctor McCoy is having difficulty with that uniform, sir.', 'Enterprise here, Captain.']
Flattened Dialogue: Aye, aye, sir. Captain, no response on any Starfleet channel. Nothing, sir. Captain, no response from John Gill on any channel. Enterprise. Lieutenant Uhura. Yes, sir. Captain, we're not reading you well. You're nine points into the low-frequency band. Yes, sir. Doctor McCoy is having difficulty with that uniform, sir. Enterprise here, Captain.

Title: Patterns of Force
Dialogue: ["Starfleet's been trying for six months. If he's alive, isn't it unlikely that he'd receive us now?", "That's generations ahead of where these people should be technically. How'd they manage that?", "He must be dead. And what's going on down there on Ekos?", 'What have you got, Jim?', "Stupid computer made a mistake in the measurements. The right boot's too tight.", 'How do you do? What in blazes is this?', 'He looks drugged, Jim. Almost at a cataleptic state.', 'I have to have a close look at him.', 'Definitely drugged, almost comatose.', "I can't identify it without a medi-comp. Without knowing, an antidote would be dangerous.", 'I can give him a general stimulant, but it would be risky.', "I'm working in the dark. I could kill him.", "The stimulant's working.", "He's reaching a level of consciousness. It's almost like he's in a light sleep. Now, that's as much as I dare do.", "He's still alive, but the drug they use is too strong. If I give him another shot", "I don't dare.", "What he's saying, Spock, is that a man who holds that much power, even with the best intentions, just can't resist the urge to play God.", "It also proves another Earth saying. Absolute power corrupts absolutely. Darn clever, these Earthmen, wouldn't you say?", "Spock, you obviously don't understand"]
Flattened Dialogue: Starfleet's been trying for six months. If he's alive, isn't it unlikely that he'd receive us now? That's generations ahead of where these people should be technically. How'd they manage that? He must be dead. And what's going on down there on Ekos? What have you got, Jim? Stupid computer made a mistake in the measurements. The right boot's too tight. How do you do? What in blazes is this? He looks drugged, Jim. Almost at a cataleptic state. I have to have a close look at him. Definitely drugged, almost comatose. I can't identify it without a medi-comp. Without knowing, an antidote would be dangerous. I can give him a general stimulant, but it would be risky. I'm working in the dark. I could kill him. The stimulant's working. He's reaching a level of consciousness. It's almost like he's in a light sleep. Now, that's as much as I dare do. He's still alive, but the drug they use is too strong. If I give him another shot I don't dare. What he's saying, Spock, is that a man who holds that much power, even with the best intentions, just can't resist the urge to play God. It also proves another Earth saying. Absolute power corrupts absolutely. Darn clever, these Earthmen, wouldn't you say? Spock, you obviously don't understand

Title: Patterns of Force
Dialogue: ['Aye, sir. Whatever your condition.']
Flattened Dialogue: Aye, sir. Whatever your condition.

Title: By Any Other Name
Dialogue: ['No life form readings, Captain. Continuing scan.', 'I am getting readings on small metallic objects, Captain. It is possible the ship was destroyed in space and the survivors proceeded here in a shuttle craft.', 'Confirmed.', 'Interesting. A neural field?', 'What brings you here?', 'Why use our vessel? Why not transmit a message to your galaxy?', 'Fascinating material. Similar to diburnium, but considerably more dense. I doubt even phaser fire could disturb its molecular structure.', 'No, Doctor. More than that. They registered as perfect human life forms. I recall noting the readings were almost classic textbook responses. Most curious.', 'The chances are very much against it.', "Gentlemen, I'm constrained to point out we do not even know what this projector looks like.", 'Possible. I would have to have one to examine.', 'Yes, I recall, Captain. I led him to believe we had escaped.', 'I shall attempt it.', 'Yes, I will be all right, Captain. We must hurry.', 'Yes, quite all right, Doctor.', "I did not break it, Doctor. I was thrown away by something I've never experienced before.", "A series of bizarre and exotic images bursting on my mind and consciousness. Colours, shapes, mathematical equations fused and blurred. I've been attempting to isolate them, but so far I've been able to recall clearly only one. Immense beings, a hundred limbs which resemble tentacles. Minds of such control and capacity that each limb is capable of performing a different function.", 'Undoubtedly.', "I'm dubious of the possibilities of success, Captain. The medical equipment is not designed to put out a great deal of power. The polarized elements would burn out quickly.", 'A small one.', 'I assure you, Captain, I am in perfect health.', 'We find it more restful to the body than your so-called vacation.', 'It will take me a moment to prepare.', "I've located their power source, captain. It's installed in Engineering.", 'Whatever it is we must do, it is impossible.', 'This material surrounding the projector is the same as I discovered on the planet. Readings indicate it is impervious to any of our weapons. We cannot penetrate the casing to get to the machine.', "There is one other possibility, Mister Scott. The final decision, of course, must be the captain's, but I believe we must have it ready for him. The Enterprise is propelled by matter-anti-matter reactors. The barrier we must traverse is negative energy.", 'Nor I. But it must be made available to the captain.', 'Impossible, Captain. The power source is protected by a material we cannot breach even with our phasers. Mister Scott and I have prepared the means for the only logical alternative available to us.', 'The barrier we must penetrate is composed of negative energy.', 'When we engage the barrier, the ship will explode. The Kelvans will be stopped here.', 'Sensors indicate density negative, radiation negative, energy negative. All instruments off the dials, Captain. We are in contact with the barrier.', 'Instruments returning to normal, Captain.', 'Life support systems sustaining on emergency.', "I have reviewed ship's personnel, Captain. It appears we four are the only ones the Kelvans consider essential.", 'Captain?', 'Most curious.', "The isolated glimpses of things I saw when I touched Kelinda's mind are beginning to coalesce in my consciousness. The Kelvans have superior intellectual capacity. To achieve it, they have apparently sacrificed anything which would tend to distract them. Perceptive senses such as taste, touch, smell, and, of course, emotions.", 'Yes. Quite correct, Captain. But they have taken human form and are therefore having human reaction.', 'That seems reasonable.', 'Yes. Humans are very peculiar. I often find them unfathomable, but an interesting psychological study.', "I believe you're referring to a kiss. But it is my understanding that such apologies are usually exchanged between people who have some affection for each other.", 'Your game is off. Are you disturbed by the incident?', "You've known Kelinda for some time. She's a Kelvan as you are. Among humans, I've found the symptoms you're displaying usually indicate jealousy.", 'Captain Kirk seems to find her quite attractive.', 'You are not jealous?', 'Nor upset?', 'Checkmate.', 'Rojan has exhibited symptoms of jealousy.', "Doctor, I'm due for another injection of stokaline.", 'Stokaline.', 'Automatic sensors and various other recording devices require monitoring and periodic adjustments.', 'If you wish, I shall call him to the bridge.', 'I left him in the recreation room.', 'No, Kelinda was with him. She seemed anxious to speak to him.', 'It would appear, sir, that you have little control over her. Or perhaps Captain Kirk has more.', 'Rojan, you are only a link in a chain, following an order given three hundred years ago. This is an opportunity for you to establish a destiny of your own.', 'A robot ship could be sent to Kelva with the Federation proposal.']
Flattened Dialogue: No life form readings, Captain. Continuing scan. I am getting readings on small metallic objects, Captain. It is possible the ship was destroyed in space and the survivors proceeded here in a shuttle craft. Confirmed. Interesting. A neural field? What brings you here? Why use our vessel? Why not transmit a message to your galaxy? Fascinating material. Similar to diburnium, but considerably more dense. I doubt even phaser fire could disturb its molecular structure. No, Doctor. More than that. They registered as perfect human life forms. I recall noting the readings were almost classic textbook responses. Most curious. The chances are very much against it. Gentlemen, I'm constrained to point out we do not even know what this projector looks like. Possible. I would have to have one to examine. Yes, I recall, Captain. I led him to believe we had escaped. I shall attempt it. Yes, I will be all right, Captain. We must hurry. Yes, quite all right, Doctor. I did not break it, Doctor. I was thrown away by something I've never experienced before. A series of bizarre and exotic images bursting on my mind and consciousness. Colours, shapes, mathematical equations fused and blurred. I've been attempting to isolate them, but so far I've been able to recall clearly only one. Immense beings, a hundred limbs which resemble tentacles. Minds of such control and capacity that each limb is capable of performing a different function. Undoubtedly. I'm dubious of the possibilities of success, Captain. The medical equipment is not designed to put out a great deal of power. The polarized elements would burn out quickly. A small one. I assure you, Captain, I am in perfect health. We find it more restful to the body than your so-called vacation. It will take me a moment to prepare. I've located their power source, captain. It's installed in Engineering. Whatever it is we must do, it is impossible. This material surrounding the projector is the same as I discovered on the planet. Readings indicate it is impervious to any of our weapons. We cannot penetrate the casing to get to the machine. There is one other possibility, Mister Scott. The final decision, of course, must be the captain's, but I believe we must have it ready for him. The Enterprise is propelled by matter-anti-matter reactors. The barrier we must traverse is negative energy. Nor I. But it must be made available to the captain. Impossible, Captain. The power source is protected by a material we cannot breach even with our phasers. Mister Scott and I have prepared the means for the only logical alternative available to us. The barrier we must penetrate is composed of negative energy. When we engage the barrier, the ship will explode. The Kelvans will be stopped here. Sensors indicate density negative, radiation negative, energy negative. All instruments off the dials, Captain. We are in contact with the barrier. Instruments returning to normal, Captain. Life support systems sustaining on emergency. I have reviewed ship's personnel, Captain. It appears we four are the only ones the Kelvans consider essential. Captain? Most curious. The isolated glimpses of things I saw when I touched Kelinda's mind are beginning to coalesce in my consciousness. The Kelvans have superior intellectual capacity. To achieve it, they have apparently sacrificed anything which would tend to distract them. Perceptive senses such as taste, touch, smell, and, of course, emotions. Yes. Quite correct, Captain. But they have taken human form and are therefore having human reaction. That seems reasonable. Yes. Humans are very peculiar. I often find them unfathomable, but an interesting psychological study. I believe you're referring to a kiss. But it is my understanding that such apologies are usually exchanged between people who have some affection for each other. Your game is off. Are you disturbed by the incident? You've known Kelinda for some time. She's a Kelvan as you are. Among humans, I've found the symptoms you're displaying usually indicate jealousy. Captain Kirk seems to find her quite attractive. You are not jealous? Nor upset? Checkmate. Rojan has exhibited symptoms of jealousy. Doctor, I'm due for another injection of stokaline. Stokaline. Automatic sensors and various other recording devices require monitoring and periodic adjustments. If you wish, I shall call him to the bridge. I left him in the recreation room. No, Kelinda was with him. She seemed anxious to speak to him. It would appear, sir, that you have little control over her. Or perhaps Captain Kirk has more. Rojan, you are only a link in a chain, following an order given three hundred years ago. This is an opportunity for you to establish a destiny of your own. A robot ship could be sent to Kelva with the Federation proposal.

Title: By Any Other Name
Dialogue: ['Well, somebody sent a distress call.', "In other words, the galaxy isn't big enough for both of us.", 'They registered as human.', 'Yes. If we could put that out of operation, we might have a chance.', "Spock, are you sure you're all right?", "You didn't look very well when you broke that mind touch.", "Do you mean that's what the Kelvans really are?", 'Well, if they look that way normally, why did they adapt themselves to our bodies?', "Well, that's enough. One wrong move, and they jam all our neural circuits.", 'How?', "It's a good idea, Jim, but anyone looking at him can tell he's healthy.", 'Jim, his heartbeat really is slow. His pulse is practically non-existent.', "He may die. If I can get him up to sickbay, there's a chance he'll live.", 'Prepare two ccs of stokaline.', "Don't argue, nurse. Just get it. This may be the turning point. Prepare another shot.", 'Please, nurse, just follow orders, will you?', "There, that should do it. Just let him rest now. You see, it's a flare-up of Rigelian Kassaba Fever. He suffered from it about ten years ago, and it recurs every now and then. There's no danger if he gets medication in time. He'll be all right in a couple of hours.", "We're just going to jam it.", "Scotty tells me you could've destroyed the ship in the barrier. Why didn't you?", 'But that was our only chance to stop them', 'Jim', 'Jim, I saw them reduce four of my doctors and nurses into those little', 'Before you condemn it, why not try it?', "All right, I'll show you how to work the selector.", "I'm delighted.", "If he keeps reacting like that, he's going to need a diet.", "I don't know about that.", 'Well, that body of yours is a bit anaemic. Comes from taking food in pills instead of solid sustenance.', "I'm going to give you a shot. High-potency vitamin concentrate. You'll need three a day for a few days. And eat some solid food, will you?", "Well, now, let's see. You've had three shots. I think you better stay on them for a few days, and then we'll see how you're responding.", "We haven't seen Tomar either. But my man Hanar is getting more irritable by the minute. I'm giving him shots of formazine. That should have him climbing the walls.", 'Hmm?', 'Oh. You will pardon us.', 'Seems to me that little planet you were on is kind of nice.']
Flattened Dialogue: Well, somebody sent a distress call. In other words, the galaxy isn't big enough for both of us. They registered as human. Yes. If we could put that out of operation, we might have a chance. Spock, are you sure you're all right? You didn't look very well when you broke that mind touch. Do you mean that's what the Kelvans really are? Well, if they look that way normally, why did they adapt themselves to our bodies? Well, that's enough. One wrong move, and they jam all our neural circuits. How? It's a good idea, Jim, but anyone looking at him can tell he's healthy. Jim, his heartbeat really is slow. His pulse is practically non-existent. He may die. If I can get him up to sickbay, there's a chance he'll live. Prepare two ccs of stokaline. Don't argue, nurse. Just get it. This may be the turning point. Prepare another shot. Please, nurse, just follow orders, will you? There, that should do it. Just let him rest now. You see, it's a flare-up of Rigelian Kassaba Fever. He suffered from it about ten years ago, and it recurs every now and then. There's no danger if he gets medication in time. He'll be all right in a couple of hours. We're just going to jam it. Scotty tells me you could've destroyed the ship in the barrier. Why didn't you? But that was our only chance to stop them Jim Jim, I saw them reduce four of my doctors and nurses into those little Before you condemn it, why not try it? All right, I'll show you how to work the selector. I'm delighted. If he keeps reacting like that, he's going to need a diet. I don't know about that. Well, that body of yours is a bit anaemic. Comes from taking food in pills instead of solid sustenance. I'm going to give you a shot. High-potency vitamin concentrate. You'll need three a day for a few days. And eat some solid food, will you? Well, now, let's see. You've had three shots. I think you better stay on them for a few days, and then we'll see how you're responding. We haven't seen Tomar either. But my man Hanar is getting more irritable by the minute. I'm giving him shots of formazine. That should have him climbing the walls. Hmm? Oh. You will pardon us. Seems to me that little planet you were on is kind of nice.

Title: By Any Other Name
Dialogue: ['No sign of the spaceship. No sign of debris.', 'But where are they?', "I'm Captain James T. Kirk, of the starship Enterprise. We came in answer to your distress call.", 'You have a very strange sense of humour, Mister', 'Stay there.', "It's all right.", 'What do you want?', 'Voyage? Where?', 'Andromeda? Why?', 'Well, sorry. This galaxy is already occupied.', "What's the point of capturing my ship? Even at maximum warp, the Enterprise couldn't get to Andromeda galaxy for thousands of years.", 'What happened to your ship?', "Yes, I know. We've been there.", "Rojan, there's no reason to do this by force. Let's take your problem to the Federation. Research expeditions have catalogued hundreds of uninhabited planets in this galaxy suitable for colonization.", 'The Federation has handled foreign invasions before.', "All right. We can't break out. There must be another way.", "That's a very good question.", 'Spock, what are the odds in such absolute duplication of life forms in another galaxy?', 'They have the paralysis field. Rojan mentioned something about a central projector.', 'Those devices on their belts might indicate the source of the force field.', "You'll get your chance, but you'll do it under orders.", 'On Eminiar Seven, you were able to trick the guard by a Vulcan mind probe.', 'Do you think you can do it again?', 'Are you all right?', "I'm responsible. Let them go.", 'What was it?', "Perhaps practicality. They chose the Enterprise as the best vessel for the trip. Immense beings with a hundred tentacles would have difficulty with the turbolift. We've got to stop them. We outnumber them. Their only hold on us is the paralysis field.", "Jam. Spock, if you reverse the circuits on McCoy's neuro-analyser, can you set up a counter field to jam the paralysis projector?", 'Is there a chance at all?', "We'll take it. You and Bones have to get to the ship.", "Yes. Mister Spock, you're sick.", "No, you're not. Doctor McCoy has given you an thorough examination, and you're ill. In fact, if you don't get to the sickbay, you're going to die.", 'Vulcans have the ability to place themselves in a kind of trance, complete relaxation of every part of the mind and body.', 'Can you do it now and come out of it in the sickbay, say in half an hour?', 'Go ahead.', 'Hanar? Hanar.', 'Mister Spock is ill. The doctor thinks he may be dying.', "He's a Vulcan. They don't react like humans.", 'Do what you can with him, Bones.', 'What do you want from me now?', 'My duty is to stop you in any way I can.', 'Or you will kill more of my people?', "Flowers. I don't know the variety.", 'A rose by any other name.', 'A quote from a great human poet, Shakespeare. That which we call a rose by any other name would smell as sweet.', 'Increase speed to warp eleven, Mister Chekov.', "Rojan, I'm going to sickbay. My first officer was taken ill.", 'Anything?', 'Well?', 'What alternative?', 'What?', "Are you mad? I can't just", 'Reading, Spock.', 'Hold your position.', 'Thank you. So are yours.', 'What neutralising operation?', 'No!', 'Is this all?', "I couldn't.", "I didn't think it was.", "Bones, that's enough!", "They've reduced the whole crew!", "It's your idea, Doctor. Go ahead.", "Even if we could, it's out of the question. We need that projector to bring our people back to human form.", 'What is?', "But then Tomar shouldn't be enjoying the taste of his food.", "If they all respond to stimulation of the senses, then maybe we can distract them. They can't have been able to handle the senses yet. If we can confuse them enough, we can get those devices from their belts.", 'All right. It may be our only chance. Look for any way to stimulate the senses.', 'Am I disturbing you?', 'I wish to apologise.', "For hitting you. I'm sorry.", "Yes, well, I don't usually go around beating up beautiful women.", 'Well, there are better things for men and women to do.', 'Is this where I hit you?', "Oh. I'm sorry. Is that better?", 'This is.', "Well, among humans, it's meant to express warmth and love.", 'Me?', 'We enjoy it.', "Kelinda, I'm sorry I brought up the whole subject.", 'I did.', 'Not when I came in.', "The thing is, I can't tell if we're getting anywhere. And I haven't seen Scotty in hours.", 'You had something to say?', 'Yes?', 'Yes. We do think a great deal about it.', 'You have a question?', "Yes, that's too bad. Why do you defy him?", "Huh. And how's the research going?", "That's not enough, Rojan.", "If you can't keep her, that's not my problem.", "Why don't you use your paralyser? You thought I was taking your woman away from you. You're jealous! You tried to kill me with your bare hands. Would a Kelvan do that? Would he have to? You're reacting with the emotions of a human. You are a human.", "I'm stimulating him. You have no choice. To use this ship, you have to use our form and now you're stuck with it, you and your descendants, for the next three hundred years.", "Look what's happened in the short time you've been exposed to us. Title: By Any Other Name

Title: By Any Other Name
Dialogue: ['Increase power to shields.', 'Sound Red Alert.', 'Engineering, come in.', "I've tied in all the lab computers. That will give it a bit more power to push with.", 'This is it. Now all we have to do', 'Why?', "That's it, then.", "I see what you're getting at. I can't say I like it.", 'I have opened the control valves to the matter-anti-matter nacelles. On your signal, I will flood them with positive energy.', 'And so will we.', "Outside hull temperatures rising, sir. It's over two thousand degrees now. Sir?", 'Several systems out, sir. Operating on emergency backup. None affect flight procedure.', "Sir, why don't we try again to knock out the paralysis projector? I know the casing looks impenetrable, but I may be able to do something.", 'Then how will we stop the Kelvans?', "I can think of one way right off. Lad, you're going to need something to wash that down with. Have you ever tried any Saurian brandy?", 'Not of this.', 'I found this on Ganymood, er, Ganymede.', "Well, it's, er. On your signal, I will flood them with positive energy. And so will we. Outside hull temperatures rising, sir. It's over two thousand degrees now. Sir? Several systems out, sir. Then how will we stop the Kelvans? I can think of one way right off. Lad, you're going to need something to wash that down with. Have you ever tried any Saurian brandy? Not of this. I found this on Ganymood, er, Ganymede. Well, it's, er. It's green. All I have is a bottle of very, very, very old Scotch. Whisky! I'll get it! I was saving you for Never mind. Gie us your glass. Title: The Omega Glory
Dialogue: ['Approaching planet Omega Four, sir. Object ahead. Another vessel in planet orbit, Captain.', "It's the USS Exeter, sir.", 'The sensors indicate no damage to the vessel, Captain.', 'Sir, this is Lieutenant Sulu in temporary command of the Enterprise.', 'Our whole medical staff will volunteer to beam down', 'Repeat your message. Come in, landing party. Repeat your message.', 'I understand, sir. When he regains consciousness, assure him that we have no problems here.', "Captain, this is Sulu. We read you, but surely you know that can't be done", 'Without verification.', 'Captain, we have volunteers standing by to beam down. What is your situation?', 'Sir, we picked up communicator signals, but', 'Aye, sir.']

Sir, this is Lieutenant Sulu in temporary command of the Enterprise. Our whole medical staff will volunteer to beam down Repeat your message. Come in, landing party. Repeat your message. Title: The Omega Glory
Dialogue: ['Lieutenant, sound alert.', 'Long range sensor scan, Mister Sulu.', 'Try to contact her, Lieutenant.', "The Exeter. she was patrolling in this area six months ago. I hadn't heard of any trouble.", 'I see. Magnification factor three, Mister Sulu.', "Hold our position out here, Mister Sulu. Lieutenant, have Mister Spock, Doctor McCoy, and Lieutenant Galloway report to the transporter room. We'll board and investigate.", 'Phasers on heavy stun. Energise.', 'Just their uniforms left.', 'Exactly. When what?', 'This is Captain Kirk of the USS Enterprise. Is anyone on board? If there is, and you can hear me, please respond by intercom to the engineering section. Is there anyone on board?', 'What about the shuttlecraft?', 'Doctor McCoy and I are going to the Bridge. Meet us there.', 'Spock, play the last log tape. Maybe they had time to record what happened to them.', 'What do you mean?', 'Prepare to beam down to the planet surface fast.', "That's Ron Tracey. Ron.", 'You were left alone down here, Ron. What happened?', 'Yes, I know. We saw it.', "I don't think we're going to have time to isolate it, Bones.", 'Are you all right?', 'Spock, do you see any hope that these Yangs can be reasoned with? A truce, a parley, a', 'Phaser power packs.', 'The fool.', 'The fool. Starfleet should be made aware.', 'Sulu!', 'Captain Ronald Tracey, as per Starfleet Command, regulation seven, paragraph four', 'Which is, why?', 'McCoy could verify all that.', 'For sale by', 'Yes, I suppose they would.', "It's a very interesting proposition. Let me think it over.", "I don't think we have the right or the wisdom to interfere, however a planet is evolving.", "Don't they ever rest?", 'Thank you, Spock. At least tell me why you want to kill me.', "No point in repeating that it's illogical, Spock. I'm quite aware of it.", "Pity you can't teach me that.", "I can't even get at it. He'd be on me in a moment. Keep talking, Spock. Don't let me doze off.", "That's a very interesting theory. The yellow civilisation is almost destroyed, the white civilisation is destroyed. Keep working on the window if we're ever going to regain our freedom.", 'Spock.', 'Well, well, well. It is our worship word, too.', 'Am I not now a prisoner of the Kohms as you are?', 'Why did you not speak until now?', "Spock, we'll have you out in a minute.", 'Spock. How long?', "Seven hours and eight. Spock. Keys. I'll have you out in a minute.", 'Good morning.', 'Good. Did you find out anything?', 'There is a disease here, something that affected the Exeter landing party and us.', 'Then we can leave any time we want to. Tracey is of the opinion these immunising agents can become a fountain of youth. There are people here over a thousand years old, Bones.', 'Then anything you develop here as a result of all this is useless.', "All that bloodshed for nothing. That'll be sufficient, Mister Spock.", 'We can beam up at any time. Any of us.', "There's no serum! There are no miracles! There's no immortality here! All this is for nothing!", 'Do what you can for him, Doctor.', 'Where is everybody?', 'We can beam up, Tracey. All of us.', 'All right. Kirk to Enterprise.', "Yes, quite all right. I'd like ten phasers beamed down with three extra power packs, please. Have you got that?", 'Enterprise, do you read me?', "Not even if we're in danger, Mister Sulu?", 'The situation is not immediately dangerous. Have the volunteers stand by. Kirk out.', 'Spock?', 'If my ancestors were forced out of the cities into the deserts, the hills', 'Living like the Indians, and finally even looking like the American Indian. American. Yangs? Yanks? Spock, Yankees!', 'But if it were true, all these generations of Yanks fighting to regain their land.', 'And to the republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.', 'In my land we have a tribe like you.', 'Up there. One of those points of light that you see at night.', "You're confusing the stars with heaven.", "We're not gods! We're not evil ones. We're men, like yourselves.", 'Those words are familiar. Wait a moment.', "No, wait! There's a better way. Does not your sacred book promise that good is stronger than evil?", "We'll discuss that later, Lieutenant. Leslie, free Doctor McCoy and Mister Spock. Put Captain Tracey under arrest.", 'Now, Cloud William.', 'I did not recognise those words, you said them so badly, Without meaning.', "This was not written for chiefs. Hear me! Hear this! Among my people, we carry many such words as this from many lands, many worlds. Many are equally good and are as well respected, but wherever we have gone, no words have said this thing of importance in quite this way. Look at these three words written larger than the rest, with a special pride never written before or since. Tall words proudly saying We the People. That which you call Ee'd Plebnista was not written for the chiefs or the kings or the warriors or the rich and powerful, but for all the people! Down the centuries, you have slurred the meaning of the words, 'We, the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union, establish justice, ensure domestic tranquillity, provide for the common defence, promote the general welfare, and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity, do ordain and establish this constitution.' These words and the words that follow were not written only for the Yangs, but for the Kohms as well!", 'They must apply to everyone or they mean nothing! Do you understand?', 'We merely showed them the meaning of what they were fighting for. Liberty and freedom have to be more than just words.', 'Gentlemen, the fighting is over here. I suggest we leave them to discover their history and their liberty.']

Keys. I'll have you out in a minute. Good morning. Good. Did you find out anything? There is a disease here, something that affected the Exeter landing party and us. Then we can leave any time we want to. Tracey is of the opinion these immunising agents can become a fountain of youth. There are people here over a thousand years old, Bones. Then anything you develop here as a result of all this is useless. All that bloodshed for nothing. That'll be sufficient, Mister Spock. We can beam up at any time. Any of us. There's no serum! There are no miracles! There's no immortality here! All this is for nothing! Do what you can for him, Doctor. Where is everybody? We can beam up, Tracey. All of us. All right. Kirk to Enterprise. Yes, quite all right. I'd like ten phasers beamed down with three extra power packs, please. Have you got that? Enterprise, do you read me? Not even if we're in danger, Mister Sulu? The situation is not immediately dangerous. Have the volunteers stand by. Kirk out. Spock? If my ancestors were forced out of the cities into the deserts, the hills Living like the Indians, and finally even looking like the American Indian. American. Yangs? Yanks? Spock, Yankees! But if it were true, all these generations of Yanks fighting to regain their land. And to the republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all. In my land we have a tribe like you. Up there. One of those points of light that you see at night. You're confusing the stars with heaven. We're not gods! We're not evil ones. Title: The Omega Glory
Dialogue: ['Aye, sir. All decks report ready, sir.', 'Aye, sir.', 'Receiving no response to our signal, sir.', "We'll beam it down shortly, Doctor.", 'Enterprise out.', 'Enterprise bridge. Lieutenant Uhura.', 'Yes, sir. Captain Kirk informed us earlier you had survived.', 'Captain, are you all right now?']
Flattened Dialogue: Aye, sir. All decks report ready, sir. Aye, sir. Receiving no response to our signal, sir. We'll beam it down shortly, Doctor. Enterprise out. Enterprise bridge. Lieutenant Uhura. Yes, sir. Captain Kirk informed us earlier you had survived. Captain, are you all right now?

Title: The Omega Glory
Dialogue: ["We're locked onto the Exeter's engineering section, Captain.", 'Captain.', 'As if they were in them when', 'Spock here, Captain.', 'Lieutenant Galloway and I are checking out the lower levels. There seems to be no one aboard. Only uniforms.', 'Fascinating.', 'Aye, sir.', "I have their surgeon's log, Captain. Their last log entry, Captain, on screen.", 'Interesting that the villagers know about phasers.', 'A Yang lance, Doctor.', 'Bruised only. We were approximately one hundred metres from the village when five of the savages ambushed us. We managed to escape without firing.', 'Captain Tracey is being quite factual in several statements. One, the Yangs are totally contemptuous of death. They seem incredibly vicious. Two, he is also being factual in that the Yangs are massing for an attack. There are signs of thousands of them in the foothills beyond. However, he was less than truthful in one very important matter.', "Captain Tracey's reserve belt packs. Empty. Found among the remains of several hundred Yang bodies.", 'A smaller attack on this village a week ago, driven off by Captain Tracey with his phaser. I have found villagers who will corroborate it.', "Regulations are quite harsh, but they're also quite clear, Captain. If you do not act, you will be considered equally guilty.", 'I agree that formal charges have little meaning now. However, you must at least confiscate his phaser.', 'Not that I have observed, Captain. Of course, should they wish to do so, one could always rest while the other keeps you occupied.', 'Good, Captain. Try to reason with them. Keep trying, Captain. Their behaviour is highly illogical.', 'I have tried, Captain.', 'Captain, I have managed to loosen this grill somewhat. If the mortar on yours is as old.', 'Captain Tracey mentioned there was once a considerable civilisation here. The only reasonable explanation would be a war. Nuclear devastation or a bacteriological holocaust.', 'Yes, I heard, Captain.', 'Captain? Captain? Captain, are you able to respond?', 'Seven hours and eight minutes, Captain.', 'We can contact the ship in a few moments, Captain, if I can cross-circuit this unit.', 'War created an imbalance and nature counterbalanced it.', 'Ready, Captain. Quite crude. Voice communication will not be possible, but we can signal the ship.', "I'm weak, Captain, but not in difficulty.", 'My need for attention is vital, Doctor, but our need for departure is even more immediate.', "Yes. I see, Captain. They would've learned to wear skins, adopted stoic mannerisms, learned the bow and the lance.", 'Kohms? Communists? The parallel is almost too close, Captain. It would mean they fought the war your Earth avoided, and in this case, the Asiatics won and took over this planet.', 'I am open to suggestions, Doctor.', "I'm making a suggestion.", "There's no question about his guilt, Captain, but does our involvement here also constitute a violation of the Prime Directive?", '']

We were approximately one hundred metres from the village when five of the savages ambushed us. We managed to escape without firing. Captain Tracey is being quite factual in several statements. One, the Yangs are totally contemptuous of death. They seem incredibly vicious. Two, he is also being factual in that the Yangs are massing for an attack. There are signs of thousands of them in the foothills beyond. However, he was less than truthful in one very important matter. Captain Tracey's reserve belt packs. Empty. Found among the remains of several hundred Yang bodies. A smaller attack on this village a week ago, driven off by Captain Tracey with his phaser. I have found villagers who will corroborate it. Regulations are quite harsh, but they're also quite clear, Captain. If you do not act, you will be considered equally guilty. I agree that formal charges have little meaning now. However, you must at least confiscate his phaser. Not that I have observed, Captain. Of course, should they wish to do so, one could always rest while the other keeps you occupied. Good, Captain. Try to reason with them. Keep trying, Captain. Their behaviour is highly illogical. I have tried, Captain. Captain, I have managed to loosen this grill somewhat. If the mortar on yours is as old. Captain Tracey mentioned there was once a considerable civilisation here. The only reasonable explanation would be a war. Nuclear devastation or a bacteriological holocaust. Yes, I heard, Captain. Captain? Captain? Captain, are you able to respond? Seven hours and eight minutes, Captain. We can contact the ship in a few moments, Captain, if I can cross-circuit this unit. War created an imbalance and nature counterbalanced it. Ready, Captain. Quite crude. Voice communication will not be possible, but we can signal the ship. I'm weak, Captain, but not in difficulty. Title: The Omega Glory
Dialogue: ["Jim, the analysis of this so far is potassium thirty five percent, carbon eighteen percent, phosphorous one point zero, calcium one point five. Jim, the crew didn't leave. They're still here.", "These white crystals. That's what's left of the human body when you take the water away, which makes up ninety six percent of our bodies. Without water, we're all just three or four pounds of chemicals. Something crystallised them down to this.", "Lucky we found that log. If we'd gone back to the Enterprise.", 'Tell the lab the final reading on our tissue is Y three X point zero zero four. And I could use a second blood analyser unit.', "Our tissues definitely show a massive infection, Jim, but something is immunising us down here, thank heavens, or we'd have been dead hours ago.", "The problem is, it could be anything Some spores or pollen in the air, some chemical. Just finding it could take months, maybe even years. And I've only got one lead. The infection resembles one developed by Earth during their bacteriological warfare experiments in the 1990s. Hard to believe we were once foolish enough to play around with that.", 'Now wait a minute. He lost his ship and his crew, and he found himself the only thing standing between an entire village of peaceful people.', "Without a serum, we're trapped here with the villagers. Now why destroy what's left of the man by arresting him?", 'Oh, thank you. Thank you very much.', 'Good morning, Jim.', "Yes. I'm convinced that once there was a frightening biological war that existed here. The virus still exists. Then over the years, nature built up these natural immunising agents in the food, the water, and the soil.", "That's right. These immunising agents take time, and that's the real tragedy. Had the Exeter landing party stayed here just a few hours longer, they never would have died.", "Survival of the fittest, because their ancestors who survived had to have a superior resistance. Then they built up these powerful protective antibodies in the blood during the wars. Now, if you want to destroy a civilisation or a whole world, your descendants might develop a longer life, but I hardly think it's worth it.", 'Who knows? It might eventually cure the common cold, but lengthen lives? Poppycock. I can do more for you if you just eat right and exercise regularly.', "He'll live, but I'll have to get him to better facilities than this.", "He's fully immunised now. We all are.", "Leave medicine to medical men, Captain. You found no fountain of youth here. People live longer here now because it's natural for them to.", 'He must have attention soon.', "You're a romantic, Jim.", 'His heart is different! The internal organs of a Vulcan are', "Spock, I've found that evil usually triumphs unless good is very, very careful.", "Spock, we've got to do something!", 'What are you doing?']
Flattened Dialogue: Jim, the analysis of this so far is potassium thirty five percent, carbon eighteen percent, phosphorous one point zero, calcium one point five. Jim, the crew didn't leave. They're still here. These white crystals. That's what's left of the human body when you take the water away, which makes up ninety six percent of our bodies. Without water, we're all just three or four pounds of chemicals. Something crystallised them down to this. Lucky we found that log. If we'd gone back to the Enterprise. Tell the lab the final reading on our tissue is Y three X point zero zero four. And I could use a second blood analyser unit. Our tissues definitely show a massive infection, Jim, but something is immunising us down here, thank heavens, or we'd have been dead hours ago. The problem is, it could be anything Some spores or pollen in the air, some chemical. Just finding it could take months, maybe even years. And I've only got one lead. The infection resembles one developed by Earth during their bacteriological warfare experiments in the 1990s. Hard to believe we were once foolish enough to play around with that. Now wait a minute. He lost his ship and his crew, and he found himself the only thing standing between an entire village of peaceful people. Without a serum, we're trapped here with the villagers. Now why destroy what's left of the man by arresting him? Oh, thank you. Thank you very much. Good morning, Jim. Yes. I'm convinced that once there was a frightening biological war that existed here. The virus still exists. Then over the years, nature built up these natural immunising agents in the food, the water, and the soil. That's right. These immunising agents take time, and that's the real tragedy. Had the Exeter landing party stayed here just a few hours longer, they never would have died. Survival of the fittest, because their ancestors who survived had to have a superior resistance. Then they built up these powerful protective antibodies in the blood during the wars. Now, if you want to destroy a civilisation or a whole world, your descendants might develop a longer life, but I hardly think it's worth it. Who knows? It might eventually cure the common cold, but lengthen lives? Poppycock. I can do more for you if you just eat right and exercise regularly. He'll live, but I'll have to get him to better facilities than this. He's fully immunised now. We all are. Leave medicine to medical men, Captain. You found no fountain of youth here. People live longer here now because it's natural for them to. He must have attention soon. You're a romantic, Jim. His heart is different! The internal organs of a Vulcan are Spock, I've found that evil usually triumphs unless good is very, very careful. Spock, we've got to do something! What are you doing?

Title: The Ultimate Computer
Dialogue: ['Standard orbit, Captain.', "We're coming back on our original course, Captain.", 'Captain, the M-5 has calculated that. The orbit is already plotted.', 'Standard orbit achieved, Captain.', 'Phasers one one hundredth power, sir.', 'Speed increasing to warp three. Turning now to one one two mark five. Phasers locking on target, sir.', 'Main phasers firing. A hit, sir. Two more.', 'Phasers firing again.', 'Firing again.', 'Captain, deflector shields just came on.', "She won't respond, sir. She's maintaining course.", 'I already tried, sir.', 'Lieutenant Sulu here, sir.', 'Right away, sir. You heard him.', 'Helm to Captain Kirk.', "Captain, helm doesn't respond. Navigational controls still locked in by M-5.", 'Phasers locking on lead ship, sir. Power levels at full strength.', 'Our phasers are firing, sir.', "We're firing again, sir.", 'Phasers firing, Captain.', 'Phasers locked on.', 'Phasers firing.', 'Phasers firing. A hit.', 'The other three ships are holding station out of range. The Excalibur looks dead.', 'All phaser power gone, sir.']
Flattened Dialogue: Standard orbit, Captain. We're coming back on our original course, Captain. Captain, the M-5 has calculated that. The orbit is already plotted. Standard orbit achieved, Captain. Phasers one one hundredth power, sir. Speed increasing to warp three. Turning now to one one two mark five. Phasers locking on target, sir. Main phasers firing. A hit, sir. Two more. Phasers firing again. Firing again. Captain, deflector shields just came on. She won't respond, sir. She's maintaining course. I already tried, sir. Lieutenant Sulu here, sir. Right away, sir. You heard him. Helm to Captain Kirk. Captain, helm doesn't respond. Navigational controls still locked in by M-5. Phasers locking on lead ship, sir. Power levels at full strength. Our phasers are firing, sir. We're firing again, sir. Phasers firing, Captain. Phasers locked on. Phasers firing. Phasers firing. A hit. The other three ships are holding station out of range. The Excalibur looks dead. All phaser power gone, sir.

Title: The Ultimate Computer
Dialogue: ['Not now, Leslie. Lieutenant, contact the space station.', 'All right. Put them on.', "Yes, Commodore, I'd like an explanation", 'Spock.', 'Bob.', "I'll say. Spock, this is", 'All right, Ensign. You can go. Thank you very much. Would you mind telling me what this is all about?', "What's that?", 'An entire attack force against my ship?', "That's Doctor Richard Daystrom's device, isn't it? Tell me about that.", 'What has all this got to do with the Enterprise?', 'Why remove my crew?', 'How much security does this gadget require?', "Twenty? I can't run a starship with twenty crew.", 'And what am I supposed to do?', "What do you want me to say? M-5 is an honour, they tell me. Well, I'm honoured.", "Where is he? Scotty, where's Doctor Daystrom?", 'Doctor Daystrom, this is my first officer, Mister Spock.', 'Well, by all means, do so.', "Mister Scott, hook in the multitronic unit to the ship's main power banks.", "I wouldn't worry, Doctor. Doctor McCoy has clearance throughout the ship.", "I'm curious, Doctor. Why is it called M-5 and not M-1?", 'Total control?', 'There are certain things men must do to remain men. Your computer would take that away.', "You'll have to prove that to me, Doctor.", "I think that thing is wrong, and I don't know why.", "I don't mean that. I'm getting a Red Alert right here. That thing is dangerous. I feel. Only a fool would stand in the way of progress, if this is progress. You have my psychological profiles. Am I afraid of losing my job to that computer?", 'Under human control.', "Am I afraid of losing command to a computer? Daystrom's right. I can do a lot of other things. Am I afraid of losing the prestige and the power that goes with being a starship captain? Is that why I'm fighting it? Am I that petty?", 'The M-5 computer is now disengaged.', "All it's done is make the required course changes and some simple turns. Mister Sulu and Mister Chekov could've done that with their eyes closed.", "My orders are subject to my interpretation of how long the M-5 is in control. I'll run the ship in my own way, if you don't mind, Doctor Daystrom.", 'You seem to enjoy trusting yourself to the computer.', "If you don't mind, I'll make my own recommendations.", 'M-5 is committed.', 'Standard orbit, Mister Sulu.', 'Oh, yes.', 'Report, Mister Spock.', 'Check it out, Scotty.', "All right, my recommendations are as follows. We send down general survey party, avoiding contact of all intelligent life on the planet's surface. The survey party will consist of myself, Doctor McCoy, Astrobiologist Phillips, Geologist Rawlins and Science Officer Spock.", "Well, the only difference in reports and recommendations is the landing party personnel. That's only a matter of judgment.", 'Why pick Carstairs instead of Rawlins? Carstairs is an ensign, no experience. This is his first tour of duty. Rawlins is chief geologist.', 'Have you located the malfunction, Doctor?', "Yes, that's correct.", "Granted, it can work a thousand, a million times faster than the human brain, but it can't make a value judgment. It hasn't intuition. It can't think.", 'Kirk here. What is it?', "I'll be right up.", 'What are you doing here, Bones?', 'Identification.', 'Put it on audio.', 'Acknowledge, Lieutenant.', 'Then go to Red Alert.', 'Already sounded the Red Alert. All right, Mister Sulu, phasers one one hundredth power. No damage potential, just enough to nudge them.', 'Report on damage sustained in mock attack.', "Evaluation of M-5 performance. It'll be necessary for the log.", 'Machine over man, Spock? It was impressive. It might even be practical.', 'Put it on visual.', 'Secure from general quarters.', "I'm not interested in eating, Bones.", "I've, I've never felt this way before. At odds with the ship. I sat there and watched my ship perform for a mass of circuits and relays, and felt useless. Unneeded. To Captain Dunsel.", "Thank you, Doctor. That's one of your better prescriptions.", "Do you know the one, 'All I ask is a tall ship'?", "20th century Earth. '", 'Kirk here.', 'On my way.', 'Lieutenant, get Daystrom up here. Disengaging M-5 unit. Cut speed to warp one. Navigator, go to course one one three mark seven. I want that ship given a wide berth.', 'Scotty, reverse engines. Slow us down.', "These controls are locked. We can't disengage the computer.", 'Daystrom, release that computer control!', 'Disengage this computer now.', "But it shouldn't have destroyed anything. There might just as easily have been a crew aboard that ship.", 'Bones. Disengage the computer. Lieutenant, contact Starfleet Command. Tell them we are breaking off M-5 tests and returning to the space station. Come along, Doctor Daystrom, M-5 is out of a job.', "All right, Daystrom, let's turn this thing off.", 'Force field?', "You mean it's not going to let any of us turn it off.", 'All right, Doctor, you built this thing. How do you propose to turn it off?', 'Correct it after you release control of my ship.', 'No! Stay here. All right, Scotty. Turn it off.', "That wasn't a minor difficulty. That wasn't a robot. That thing murdered one of my crewman and you tell me you can't turn it off?", 'And how long will it be before all of us simply get in the way?', 'Spock, Scotty, come with me.', 'Report, Spock.', "We'll reach the rendezvous point for the war games within an hour. We must regain control of the ship by then.", 'Scotty?', 'How long?', 'Make it less.', "He's with the M-5 unit, watching it. I think it surprised even him.", 'Did you find anything?', 'Genius is an understatement. At the age of twenty four, he made the duotronic breakthrough that won him the Nobel and Zee-Magnes prizes.', "Isn't that enough for one lifetime?", "All right, it's difficult. What's your point?", "Genius doesn't work on an assembly line basis. Did Einstein, Kazanga, or Sitar of Vulcan produce new and revolutionary theories on a regular schedule? You can't simply say, today I will be brilliant. No matter how long it took, he came out with multitronics. The M-5.", "And he won't let Spock near it. What are you saying, that he's tampering with it, that he's making it act that way? Why?", "Now he's got you talking about that machine like a personality.", 'Kirk here.', "Good. Get Daystrom. We're on our way. Let's go.", "We're going to find out, Doctor.", 'Spock?', 'Good, go ahead.', "Daystrom, we're going to do our best.", 'Spock.', 'Bridge, this is Kirk. Sulu?', "We've got helm and navigational control. Turn us about. Have Mister Chekov plot a course back to the space station.", 'Kirk here.', 'Go to the engineering station.', 'While it was getting ready for what? Spock?', "Doctor Daystrom. Doctor Daystrom, I want an answer right now. I'm tired of hearing about the M-5's new approach. What is it, exactly? What is it?", 'Well, Doctor?', 'Your new approach?', 'Kirk here. What is it?', 'The main attack force. The war games.', "Correction, Bones. Those four ships don't know it's M-5's game. And M-5 is going to destroy them.", 'Put it on.', 'Daystrom, does M-5 understand that this is only a drill?', 'Full strength?', "That's no miscalculation.", 'Estimate damage on Lexington, Spock.', "There's got to be a way of getting to the M-5. There's got to be a way!", 'Lieutenant?', "There's your murder charge. Deliberate. Calculated. It's killing men and women. Four starships, sixteen hundred men and women!", 'Daystrom!', 'Whose engrams?', 'The computer tie-in. You spoke to it before. It knows you.', 'You can save the M-5 if you talk to it and make it stop the attack.', "You'd better pray that the M-5 listens to the sound of him.", "Spock. The M-5 is not responding to him like a computer. It's talking to him.", 'The M-5 must be destroyed.', 'Security, take him to Sickbay.', 'Take care of him, Doctor.', 'Battle status?', 'Go on.', "They've just signed their own death warrant. M-5 will kill them to survive.", "Suppose it's still open to impression. Suppose it absorbed the regret Daystrom felt for the deaths it caused. The guilt.", 'The instrument of his death will not be the Enterprise if I can help it. M-5, tie-in.', 'This is Captain Kirk. You will be under attack in a moment.', 'You have already rendered one starship either dead or hopelessly crippled. Many lives were lost.', 'Why?', 'There were many men aboard those ships. They were murdered. Must you survive by murder?', 'Why?', 'But you have murdered. Scan the starship Excalibur, which you destroyed. Is there life aboard?', 'Because you murdered it. What is the penalty for murder?', 'And how will you pay for your acts of murder?', 'Scotty, Spock, before it changes its mind. Get down to Engineering, pull out every hook up that makes M-5 run. Pull out the plug, Spock.', 'Lieutenant.', "Intership communications. This is the captain speaking. In approximately one minute, we'll be attacked by Federation starships. The M-5 no longer controls the ship, but neither do we control it. The M-5 has left itself, and us, open for destruction. For whatever satisfaction we may get from the knowledge, our nineteen lives will buy the survival of over one thousand of our fellow starship crewmen.", 'Kirk here.', 'I need communications.', 'Then cut power.', 'Cut power. Keep those shields down.', "That's exactly the situation I was hoping for when I forced the M-5 to realise it had committed murder.", 'Daystrom felt such an act was against the laws of God and man. The computer that carried his engrams also believed it.', "I wasn't sure. Any other commander would have simply followed orders and destroyed us, but I knew Bob Wesley.", 'I gambled on his humanity.', 'Bridge. His logical selection was compassion.', 'Mister Sulu, take us back to the space station. Ahead, warp factor two.']
Flattened Dialogue: Not now, Leslie. Lieutenant, contact the space station. All right. Put them on. Yes, Commodore, I'd like an explanation Spock. Bob. I'll say. Spock, this is All right, Ensign. You can go. Thank you very much. Would you mind telling me what this is all about? What's that? An entire attack force against my ship? That's Doctor Richard Daystrom's device, isn't it? Tell me about that. What has all this got to do with the Enterprise? Why remove my crew? How much security does this gadget require? Twenty? I can't run a starship with twenty crew. And what am I supposed to do? What do you want me to say? M-5 is an honour, they tell me. Well, I'm honoured. Where is he? Scotty, where's Doctor Daystrom? Doctor Daystrom, this is my first officer, Mister Spock. Well, by all means, do so. Mister Scott, hook in the multitronic unit to the ship's main power banks. I wouldn't worry, Doctor. Doctor McCoy has clearance throughout the ship. I'm curious, Doctor. Why is it called M-5 and not M-1? Total control? There are certain things men must do to remain men. Your computer would take that away. You'll have to prove that to me, Doctor. I think that thing is wrong, and I don't know why. I don't mean that. I'm getting a Red Alert right here. That thing is dangerous. I feel. Only a fool would stand in the way of progress, if this is progress. You have my psychological profiles. Am I afraid of losing my job to that computer? Under human control. Am I afraid of losing command to a computer? Daystrom's right. I can do a lot of other things. Am I afraid of losing the prestige and the power that goes with being a starship captain? Is that why I'm fighting it? Am I that petty? The M-5 computer is now disengaged. All it's done is make the required course changes and some simple turns. Mister Sulu and Mister Chekov could've done that with their eyes closed. My orders are subject to my interpretation of how long the M-5 is in control. I'll run the ship in my own way, if you don't mind, Doctor Daystrom. You seem to enjoy trusting yourself to the computer. If you don't mind, I'll make my own recommendations. M-5 is committed. Standard orbit, Mister Sulu. Oh, yes. Report, Mister Spock. Check it out, Scotty. All right, my recommendations are as follows. We send down general survey party, avoiding contact of all intelligent life on the planet's surface. The survey party will consist of myself, Doctor McCoy, Astrobiologist Phillips, Geologist Rawlins and Science Officer Spock. Well, the only difference in reports and recommendations is the landing party personnel. That's only a matter of judgment. Why pick Carstairs instead of Rawlins? Carstairs is an ensign, no experience. This is his first tour of duty. Rawlins is chief geologist. Have you located the malfunction, Doctor? Yes, that's correct. Granted, it can work a thousand, a million times faster than the human brain, but it can't make a value judgment. It hasn't intuition. It can't think. Kirk here. What is it? I'll be right up. What are you doing here, Bones? Identification. Put it on audio. Acknowledge, Lieutenant. Then go to Red Alert. Already sounded the Red Alert. All right, Mister Sulu, phasers one one hundredth power. No damage potential, just enough to nudge them. Report on damage sustained in mock attack. Evaluation of M-5 performance. It'll be necessary for the log. Machine over man, Spock? It was impressive. It might even be practical. Put it on visual. Secure from general quarters. I'm not interested in eating, Bones. I've, I've never felt this way before. At odds with the ship. I sat there and watched my ship perform for a mass of circuits and relays, and felt useless. Unneeded. To Captain Dunsel. Thank you, Doctor. That's one of your better prescriptions. Do you know the one, 'All I ask is a tall ship'? 20th century Earth. ' Kirk here. On my way. Lieutenant, get Daystrom up here. Disengaging M-5 unit. Cut speed to warp one. Navigator, go to course one one three mark seven. I want that ship given a wide berth. Scotty, reverse engines. Slow us down. These controls are locked. We can't disengage the computer. Daystrom, release that computer control! Disengage this computer now. But it shouldn't have destroyed anything. There might just as easily have been a crew aboard that ship. Bones. Disengage the computer. Lieutenant, contact Starfleet Command. Tell them we are breaking off M-5 tests and returning to the space station. Come along, Doctor Daystrom, M-5 is out of a job. All right, Daystrom, let's turn this thing off. Force field? You mean it's not going to let any of us turn it off. All right, Doctor, you built this thing. How do you propose to turn it off? Correct it after you release control of my ship. No! Stay here. All right, Scotty. Turn it off. That wasn't a minor difficulty. That wasn't a robot. That thing murdered one of my crewman and you tell me you can't turn it off? And how long will it be before all of us simply get in the way? Spock, Scotty, come with me. Report, Spock. We'll reach the rendezvous point for the war games within an hour. We must regain control of the ship by then. Scotty? How long? Make it less. He's with the M-5 unit, watching it. I think it surprised even him. Did you find anything? Genius is an understatement. At the age of twenty four, he made the duotronic breakthrough that won him the Nobel and Zee-Magnes prizes. Isn't that enough for one lifetime? All right, it's difficult. What's your point? Genius doesn't work on an assembly line basis. Did Einstein, Kazanga, or Sitar of Vulcan produce new and revolutionary theories on a regular schedule? You can't simply say, today I will be brilliant. No matter how long it took, he came out with multitronics. The M-5. And he won't let Spock near it. What are you saying, that he's tampering with it, that he's making it act that way? Why? Now he's got you talking about that machine like a personality. Kirk here. Good. Get Daystrom. We're on our way. Let's go. We're going to find out, Doctor. Spock? Good, go ahead. Daystrom, we're going to do our best. Spock. Bridge, this is Kirk. Sulu? We've got helm and navigational control. Turn us about. Have Mister Chekov plot a course back to the space station. Kirk here. Go to the engineering station. While it was getting ready for what? Spock? Doctor Daystrom. Doctor Daystrom, I want an answer right now. I'm tired of hearing about the M-5's new approach. What is it, exactly? What is it? Well, Doctor? Your new approach? Kirk here. What is it? The main attack force. The war games. Correction, Bones. Those four ships don't know it's M-5's game. And M-5 is going to destroy them. Put it on. Daystrom, does M-5 understand that this is only a drill? Full strength? That's no miscalculation. Estimate damage on Lexington, Spock. There's got to be a way of getting to the M-5. There's got to be a way! Lieutenant? There's your murder charge. Deliberate. Calculated. It's killing men and women.
