Intership communications. This is the captain speaking. In approximately one minute, we'll be attacked by Federation starships. The M-5 no longer controls the ship, but neither do we control it. The M-5 has left itself, and us, open for destruction. For whatever satisfaction we may get from the knowledge, our nineteen lives will buy the survival of over one thousand of our fellow starship crewmen. Kirk here. I need communications. Then cut power. Cut power. Keep those shields down. That's exactly the situation I was hoping for when I forced the M-5 to realise it had committed murder. Daystrom felt such an act was against the laws of God and man. The computer that carried his engrams also believed it. I wasn't sure. Any other commander would have simply followed orders and destroyed us, but I knew Bob Wesley. I gambled on his humanity. Bridge. His logical selection was compassion. Mister Sulu, take us back to the space station. Ahead, warp factor two.

Title: The Ultimate Computer
Dialogue: ['Captain, the station is calling us.', 'Bridge to Captain Kirk.', 'Sensors are picking up a vessel paralleling our course, as yet unidentified.', 'Priority message coming in, sir.', 'M-5 has acknowledged for us, sir.', 'Aye, sir. Captain, M-5 has', 'Captain, message now coming in from Commodore Wesley.', 'Captain Kirk to the bridge, please. Captain Kirk.', "Captain, there's no response to any of our signals, but M-5 has given us an autorelay.", 'Captain Kirk, Mister Spock, to the bridge, please. Report to the bridge, please.', 'Sir, sensors are picking up four Federation starships. M-5 is altering course to intercept.', "Enterprise to USS Lexington. Come in, Lexington. Sir, I can't raise them. M-5 is blocking all frequencies, including automatic distress. Just a minute, sir. Captain, I'm getting audio signal from the Lexington.", 'Captain, M-5 is acknowledging.', 'Captain, visual contact with Lexington.', "I'm sorry. I can't override M-5 interference.", "Captain, I'm getting the Lexington again. Tapping in on their message to Starfleet Command, sir.", 'Captain, Lexington is receiving a message from Starfleet. They', 'Aye, sir.', 'Captain.']
Flattened Dialogue: Captain, the station is calling us. Bridge to Captain Kirk. Sensors are picking up a vessel paralleling our course, as yet unidentified. Priority message coming in, sir. M-5 has acknowledged for us, sir. Aye, sir. Captain, M-5 has Captain, message now coming in from Commodore Wesley. Captain Kirk to the bridge, please. Captain Kirk. Captain, there's no response to any of our signals, but M-5 has given us an autorelay. Captain Kirk, Mister Spock, to the bridge, please. Report to the bridge, please. Sir, sensors are picking up four Federation starships. M-5 is altering course to intercept. Enterprise to USS Lexington. Come in, Lexington. Sir, I can't raise them. M-5 is blocking all frequencies, including automatic distress. Just a minute, sir. Captain, I'm getting audio signal from the Lexington. Captain, M-5 is acknowledging. Captain, visual contact with Lexington. I'm sorry. I can't override M-5 interference. Captain, I'm getting the Lexington again. Tapping in on their message to Starfleet Command, sir. Captain, Lexington is receiving a message from Starfleet. They Aye, sir. Captain.

Title: The Ultimate Computer
Dialogue: ['Commodore Wesley. How do you do, sir?', 'The most ambitious computer complex ever created. Its purpose is to correlate all computer activity aboard a starship, to provide the ultimate in vessel operation and control.', "I hold an A-7 computer expert classification, Commodore. I'm well acquainted with Doctor Daystrom's theories and discoveries. The basic design of all our ship's computers are Doctor Daystrom's.", 'We are attempting to prove it can run this ship more efficiently than man.', 'The most unfortunate lack in current computer programming is that there is nothing available to immediately replace the starship surgeon.', 'I am honoured, Doctor.', "Fascinating, Doctor. This computer has a potential beyond anything you've ever done. Even your breakthrough in duotronics did not have the promise of this.", 'The M-5 has been perfected, Commander. Its potential is a fact.', 'If I can be of assistance, Doctor.', 'M-5 has performed admirably so far.', "Captain, I am forced to agree with Doctor Daystrom. With the course information plotted into it, his computer could have brought us here as easily as the navigator. In fact, it might have been a further demonstration of M-5's capability.", "Enjoy, Captain? No. I'm merely gratified to see Doctor Daystrom's new unit execute everything required of it in such a highly efficient manner. M-5 is another distinguished triumph for his career.", 'The planet is class M, Captain. Oxygen-nitrogen atmosphere suitable for human life support. Two major land masses, a number of islands, life form readings.', "M-5's readout, Captain.", 'Captain, the computer does not judge. It makes logical selections.', 'I am not familiar with these instruments, Doctor. You are using an entirely new type of control mechanism. However, it appears to me this unit is drawing more power than before.', 'Doctor, this unit is not a human body. The computer can process information, but only the information which is put into it.', 'Captain, sensors report two contacts now. One on the port bow, one on the stern. Distance, two hundred thousand kilometres and closing.', 'We are not scheduled for war games in this area. This may be a surprise attack as a problem for the M-5.', 'Phaser hit on port deflector four, Captain.', 'Attacking vessels are moving off.', 'Minor hit on deflector screen four. No appreciable damage.', 'The ship reacted more rapidly than human control could have manoeuvred her. Tactics, deployment of weapons, all indicate an immense sophistication in computer control.', 'Practical, Captain? Perhaps. But not desirable. Computers make excellent and efficient servants, but I have no wish to serve under them. Captain the starship also runs on loyalty to one man, and nothing can replace it, or him.', 'Dunsel, Doctor, is a term used by midshipmen at Starfleet Academy. It refers to a part which serves no useful purpose.', 'Another contact, Captain. A large, slow-moving vessel.', 'Unidentified. This is not a drill.', 'M-5 has identified her, Captain. The Woden. Listed in Starfleet Registry as an old-style ore freighter converted to automation. No crew. Coming into visual range.', 'No effect on any of the M-5 controls, Captain.', 'Captain, photon torpedoes locking on target. Full power.', 'All systems report normal, Captain.', 'I would say, Captain, that M-5 is not only capable of taking care of this ship, it is also capable of taking care of itself.', 'M-5 appears drawing power directly from the warp engines, tapping the matter-antimatter reserves.', 'The multitronic unit is drawing more and more power directly from the warp engines. The computer now controls all helm, navigation, and engineering functions.', 'There is one possibility. The automatic helm navigation circuit relays might be disrupted from engineering level three.', 'Most illogical. Of all people, he should have known how the computer would perform. Of course, the M-5 itself has not behaved logically.', 'No. But it is interesting.', 'Good.', 'Spock to Captain Kirk.', 'We are ready, Captain.', 'Mister Scott is ready to apply the circuit disrupter. As he does so, I shall trip the manual override into control.', 'Manual override is in control, Captain.', 'Mister Chekov.', 'Examine the H two seven nine elements, also the G nine five systems.', 'Thank you, Ensign.', "It appears, Captain, we've been doing what used to be called pursuing a wild goose. M-5 has rerouted helm and navigational controls, bypassing this primary system.", 'I believe that when M-5 discovered our tampering, it rerouted the controls, leaving this one active by simply sending through an electronic impulse at regular intervals.', 'I do not know. It is not performing in a logical manner.', 'I do not mean to offend, sir, but it behaves with an almost human pattern.', 'Attack force closing rapidly, breaking formation, attacking at will.', 'Hit on the Lexington.', "Hit in engineering section. Possible damage to her impulse engines. She's still maneuverable on warp drive.", 'The Excalibur, a direct hit.', 'Lexington hit again.', 'Probably true, Captain. It works faster, thinks faster than we do. It is a human mind amplified by the instantaneous relays possible in a computer.', 'Doctor Daystrom, you impressed human engrams on the M-5 circuits.', 'Then perhaps you could talk to the unit. M-5 has no reason to believe you would harm it.', 'I am most impressed with the technology, Captain. Doctor Daystrom has created a mirror image of his mind.', 'Fascinating.', 'Every living thing wants to survive, Captain. Daystrom must have impressed that instinctive reaction upon the computer.', 'Commodore Wesley is a dedicated commander. I should regret serving aboard the instrument of his death.', 'Captain, attack force almost within phaser range.', 'M-5 is leaving itself open to attack. The machine is committing suicide to atone for the sin of murder.', 'Spock to Captain.', 'The force field is gone, Captain. M-5 is neutralised.', 'I would say his multitronic unit is in approximately the same condition.', 'Captain, why did you feel the attacking ships would not fire when they saw the Enterprise apparently vulnerable? Logically, that is the sort of trap M-5 should have set.', 'No, Doctor. I simply maintain that computers are more efficient than human beings, not better.', 'I presume your question is meant to offer me a choice between machines and human beings, and I believe I have already answered that question.', 'It would be most interesting to impress your memory engrams on a computer, Doctor. The resulting torrential flood of illogic would be most entertaining.']
Flattened Dialogue: Commodore Wesley. How do you do, sir? The most ambitious computer complex ever created. Its purpose is to correlate all computer activity aboard a starship, to provide the ultimate in vessel operation and control. I hold an A-7 computer expert classification, Commodore. I'm well acquainted with Doctor Daystrom's theories and discoveries. The basic design of all our ship's computers are Doctor Daystrom's. We are attempting to prove it can run this ship more efficiently than man. The most unfortunate lack in current computer programming is that there is nothing available to immediately replace the starship surgeon. I am honoured, Doctor. Fascinating, Doctor. This computer has a potential beyond anything you've ever done. Even your breakthrough in duotronics did not have the promise of this. The M-5 has been perfected, Commander. Its potential is a fact. If I can be of assistance, Doctor. M-5 has performed admirably so far. Captain, I am forced to agree with Doctor Daystrom. With the course information plotted into it, his computer could have brought us here as easily as the navigator. In fact, it might have been a further demonstration of M-5's capability. Enjoy, Captain? No. I'm merely gratified to see Doctor Daystrom's new unit execute everything required of it in such a highly efficient manner. M-5 is another distinguished triumph for his career. The planet is class M, Captain. Oxygen-nitrogen atmosphere suitable for human life support. Two major land masses, a number of islands, life form readings. M-5's readout, Captain. Captain, the computer does not judge. It makes logical selections. I am not familiar with these instruments, Doctor. You are using an entirely new type of control mechanism. However, it appears to me this unit is drawing more power than before. Doctor, this unit is not a human body. The computer can process information, but only the information which is put into it. Captain, sensors report two contacts now. One on the port bow, one on the stern. Distance, two hundred thousand kilometres and closing. We are not scheduled for war games in this area. This may be a surprise attack as a problem for the M-5. Phaser hit on port deflector four, Captain. Attacking vessels are moving off. Minor hit on deflector screen four. No appreciable damage. The ship reacted more rapidly than human control could have manoeuvred her. Tactics, deployment of weapons, all indicate an immense sophistication in computer control. Practical, Captain? Perhaps. But not desirable. Computers make excellent and efficient servants, but I have no wish to serve under them. Captain the starship also runs on loyalty to one man, and nothing can replace it, or him. Dunsel, Doctor, is a term used by midshipmen at Starfleet Academy. It refers to a part which serves no useful purpose. Another contact, Captain. A large, slow-moving vessel. Unidentified. This is not a drill. M-5 has identified her, Captain. The Woden. Listed in Starfleet Registry as an old-style ore freighter converted to automation. No crew. Coming into visual range. No effect on any of the M-5 controls, Captain. Captain, photon torpedoes locking on target. Full power. All systems report normal, Captain. I would say, Captain, that M-5 is not only capable of taking care of this ship, it is also capable of taking care of itself. M-5 appears drawing power directly from the warp engines, tapping the matter-antimatter reserves. The multitronic unit is drawing more and more power directly from the warp engines. The computer now controls all helm, navigation, and engineering functions. There is one possibility. The automatic helm navigation circuit relays might be disrupted from engineering level three. Most illogical. Of all people, he should have known how the computer would perform. Of course, the M-5 itself has not behaved logically. No. But it is interesting. Good. Spock to Captain Kirk. We are ready, Captain. Mister Scott is ready to apply the circuit disrupter. As he does so, I shall trip the manual override into control. Manual override is in control, Captain. Mister Chekov. Examine the H two seven nine elements, also the G nine five systems. Thank you, Ensign. It appears, Captain, we've been doing what used to be called pursuing a wild goose. M-5 has rerouted helm and navigational controls, bypassing this primary system. I believe that when M-5 discovered our tampering, it rerouted the controls, leaving this one active by simply sending through an electronic impulse at regular intervals. I do not know. It is not performing in a logical manner. I do not mean to offend, sir, but it behaves with an almost human pattern. Attack force closing rapidly, breaking formation, attacking at will. Hit on the Lexington. Hit in engineering section. Possible damage to her impulse engines. She's still maneuverable on warp drive. The Excalibur, a direct hit. Lexington hit again. Probably true, Captain. It works faster, thinks faster than we do. It is a human mind amplified by the instantaneous relays possible in a computer. Doctor Daystrom, you impressed human engrams on the M-5 circuits. Then perhaps you could talk to the unit. M-5 has no reason to believe you would harm it. I am most impressed with the technology, Captain. Doctor Daystrom has created a mirror image of his mind. Fascinating. Every living thing wants to survive, Captain. Daystrom must have impressed that instinctive reaction upon the computer. Commodore Wesley is a dedicated commander. I should regret serving aboard the instrument of his death. Captain, attack force almost within phaser range. M-5 is leaving itself open to attack. The machine is committing suicide to atone for the sin of murder. Spock to Captain. The force field is gone, Captain. M-5 is neutralised. I would say his multitronic unit is in approximately the same condition. Captain, why did you feel the attacking ships would not fire when they saw the Enterprise apparently vulnerable? Logically, that is the sort of trap M-5 should have set. No, Doctor. I simply maintain that computers are more efficient than human beings, not better. I presume your question is meant to offer me a choice between machines and human beings, and I believe I have already answered that question. It would be most interesting to impress your memory engrams on a computer, Doctor. The resulting torrential flood of illogic would be most entertaining.

Title: The Ultimate Computer
Dialogue: ["I don't like it, Jim. A vessel this size cannot be run by one computer.", "Maybe you're trying to prove that, Spock, but don't count me in on it.", "Very funny. If it could, they wouldn't have to replace me. I'd resign because everybody else aboard would be nothing but circuits and memory banks. You know the type, Spock. Jim, you haven't had much to say about this.", "Frankly, the only fact that I'm concerned about is if this thing doesn't work, there are not enough men aboard to run the ship. That's begging for trouble.", 'Doctor Leonard McCoy, senior medical officer.', 'Is it supposed to do that?', "Did you see the love light in Spock's eyes? The right computer finally came along. What's the matter, Jim?", "I think it's wrong, too, replacing men with mindless machines.", "Jim, we've all seen the advances of mechanisation. After all, Daystrom did design the computers that run this ship.", "We're all sorry for the other guy when he loses his job to a machine. When it comes to your job, that's different. And it always will be different.", "Jim, if you have the awareness to ask yourself that question, you don't need me to answer it for you. Why don't you ask James T. Kirk? He's a pretty honest guy.", 'All the Sickbay systems are shut down until such time as the M-5 is informed there are patients to be cared for.', 'Dunsel? Who the blazes is Captain Dunsel? What does it mean, Jim? Spock? What does it mean?', "This isn't chicken soup. I may be just a ship's doctor, but I make a Finagle's Folly that's known from here to Orion. I strongly prescribe it, Jim.", 'To James T. Kirk, Captain of the Enterprise.', 'Simple but effective.', "It's a line from a poem. A very old poem, isn't it?", 'Jim.', 'Fantastic machine, the M-5. No off switch.', "Normal? That thing's trying to tell us nothing has happened.", 'There certainly does. Your brilliant young computer just destroyed an ore freighter. In fact it went out of its way to destroy an ore freighter!', "In which case you'd be guilty of murder.", 'And communications and fire control.', "I'll get the man responsible in the first place. Where is Daystrom?", "Please, Spock, do me a favour and don't say it's fascinating.", 'Have you found a solution, a way to shut that thing off?', 'Learning to kill.', 'That thing is a danger to us all. Now find some way to shut it off.', 'The biographical tape of Richard Daystrom.', "Not much, aside from the fact he's a genius.", "In his early twenties, Jim. That's over a quarter of a century ago.", "Maybe that's the trouble. Where do you go from up? You publish articles, you give lectures, then spend your life trying to recapture past glory.", "The M-1 through M-4, remember? Not entirely successful. That's the way Daystrom put it.", 'Right. The government bought it, then Daystrom had to make it work. And he did. But according to Spock, it works illogically.', "Jim, if a man had a child who'd gone antisocial, killed perhaps, he'd still tend to protect that child.", "I'm afraid that's the way he thinks about it.", 'Decoyed. It wanted us to waste our time.', "But M-5 doesn't know it's a game.", "If that thing cuts loose against unshielded ships, we're in", 'Of course.', "I don't like the sound of him, Jim.", "Jim, he's on the edge of a nervous breakdown, if not insanity.", "He'll have to be committed to a total rehabilitation centre. Right now he's under sedation and heavy restraints.", "Compassion. That's the one thing no machine ever had. Maybe it's the one thing that keeps men ahead of them. Care to debate that, Spock?", 'But tell me, which do you prefer to have around?', 'I was just trying to make conversation, Spock.']
Flattened Dialogue: I don't like it, Jim. A vessel this size cannot be run by one computer. Maybe you're trying to prove that, Spock, but don't count me in on it. Very funny. If it could, they wouldn't have to replace me. I'd resign because everybody else aboard would be nothing but circuits and memory banks. You know the type, Spock. Jim, you haven't had much to say about this. Frankly, the only fact that I'm concerned about is if this thing doesn't work, there are not enough men aboard to run the ship. That's begging for trouble. Doctor Leonard McCoy, senior medical officer. Is it supposed to do that? Did you see the love light in Spock's eyes? The right computer finally came along. What's the matter, Jim? I think it's wrong, too, replacing men with mindless machines. Jim, we've all seen the advances of mechanisation. After all, Daystrom did design the computers that run this ship. We're all sorry for the other guy when he loses his job to a machine. When it comes to your job, that's different. And it always will be different. Jim, if you have the awareness to ask yourself that question, you don't need me to answer it for you. Why don't you ask James T. Kirk? He's a pretty honest guy. All the Sickbay systems are shut down until such time as the M-5 is informed there are patients to be cared for. Dunsel? Who the blazes is Captain Dunsel? What does it mean, Jim? Spock? What does it mean? This isn't chicken soup. I may be just a ship's doctor, but I make a Finagle's Folly that's known from here to Orion. I strongly prescribe it, Jim. To James T. Kirk, Captain of the Enterprise. Simple but effective. It's a line from a poem. A very old poem, isn't it? Jim. Fantastic machine, the M-5. No off switch. Normal? That thing's trying to tell us nothing has happened. There certainly does. Your brilliant young computer just destroyed an ore freighter. In fact it went out of its way to destroy an ore freighter! In which case you'd be guilty of murder. And communications and fire control. I'll get the man responsible in the first place. Where is Daystrom? Please, Spock, do me a favour and don't say it's fascinating. Have you found a solution, a way to shut that thing off? Learning to kill. That thing is a danger to us all. Now find some way to shut it off. The biographical tape of Richard Daystrom. Not much, aside from the fact he's a genius. In his early twenties, Jim. That's over a quarter of a century ago. Maybe that's the trouble. Where do you go from up? You publish articles, you give lectures, then spend your life trying to recapture past glory. The M-1 through M-4, remember? Not entirely successful. That's the way Daystrom put it. Right. The government bought it, then Daystrom had to make it work. And he did. But according to Spock, it works illogically. Jim, if a man had a child who'd gone antisocial, killed perhaps, he'd still tend to protect that child. I'm afraid that's the way he thinks about it. Decoyed. It wanted us to waste our time. But M-5 doesn't know it's a game. If that thing cuts loose against unshielded ships, we're in Of course. I don't like the sound of him, Jim. Jim, he's on the edge of a nervous breakdown, if not insanity. He'll have to be committed to a total rehabilitation centre. Right now he's under sedation and heavy restraints. Compassion. That's the one thing no machine ever had. Maybe it's the one thing that keeps men ahead of them. Care to debate that, Spock? But tell me, which do you prefer to have around? I was just trying to make conversation, Spock.

Title: The Ultimate Computer
Dialogue: ['He was here. Doctor.', 'Aye, aye, sir. Mister Harper.', 'Captain, power shutdowns on deck four. Lights, environmental control.', "The power's gone off on deck five.", "Captain, I've located the source of the power shutdowns. It's the M-5 unit, sir. That thing's turning off systems all over the ship.", "Reverse thrusts will not engage, sir. Manual override isn't working either.", 'Captain, I suggest we disconnect it at the source.', "So now it has virtually unlimited power. Captain, what'll we do?", 'Aye. I can take them out and cut in the manual override from there.', 'If Mister Spock helps me, maybe an hour.', "Aye, that's got it, Mister Spock.", "That's it, Mister Spock.", "But it was active. I'd stake all that I know that it was.", "System's coming back. I can give you power for the shields, sir.", "That'll take longer.", 'Sir!']
Flattened Dialogue: He was here. Doctor. Aye, aye, sir. Mister Harper. Captain, power shutdowns on deck four. Lights, environmental control. The power's gone off on deck five. Captain, I've located the source of the power shutdowns. It's the M-5 unit, sir. That thing's turning off systems all over the ship. Reverse thrusts will not engage, sir. Manual override isn't working either. Captain, I suggest we disconnect it at the source. So now it has virtually unlimited power. Captain, what'll we do? Aye. I can take them out and cut in the manual override from there. If Mister Spock helps me, maybe an hour. Aye, that's got it, Mister Spock. That's it, Mister Spock. But it was active. I'd stake all that I know that it was. System's coming back. I can give you power for the shields, sir. That'll take longer. Sir!

Title: The Ultimate Computer
Dialogue: ['Approaching Alpha Carinae Two. ETA five minutes.', 'Captain, the M-5 unit has already identified the vessels as Federation starships Excalibur and Lexington.', 'Enemy vessel closing with us.', 'Changing course to two eight mark four two.', 'Turning to one one three mark five. Warp four speed.', 'Moving back to original course and speed.', 'Speed increasing to warp three, Captain.', 'Going to warp four, sir.', 'Returning to original course and speed.', "I've been updating that course for hours.", 'Chekov here, sir.', 'Sir, G nine five system appears dead.', 'All indicators are dark.', 'Sir, deflector shield just came on. Speed increasing to warp four.', 'Turning now, sir.', 'Closing on the Lexington again, sir. The Hood and Potemkin are moving off.', "Excalibur is maneuvering away, sir. We're increasing speed to follow.", 'Coming to new course, sir. Bearing on the Potemkin.', 'Captain, the ships are coming within range again.', 'Sir, deflector shields have dropped.']
Flattened Dialogue: Approaching Alpha Carinae Two. ETA five minutes. Captain, the M-5 unit has already identified the vessels as Federation starships Excalibur and Lexington. Enemy vessel closing with us. Changing course to two eight mark four two. Turning to one one three mark five. Warp four speed. Moving back to original course and speed. Speed increasing to warp three, Captain. Going to warp four, sir. Returning to original course and speed. I've been updating that course for hours. Chekov here, sir. Sir, G nine five system appears dead. All indicators are dark. Sir, deflector shield just came on. Speed increasing to warp four. Turning now, sir. Closing on the Lexington again, sir. The Hood and Potemkin are moving off. Excalibur is maneuvering away, sir. We're increasing speed to follow. Coming to new course, sir. Bearing on the Potemkin. Captain, the ships are coming within range again. Sir, deflector shields have dropped.

Title: Bread and Circuses
Dialogue: ['No doubt about it, Captain. The space debris comes from the survey vessel SS Beagle.', 'Portions of the antimatter nacelles, personal belongings. Captain, no signs of bodies whatsoever.', 'It would have come from planet four, star system eight nine two, directly ahead.', 'SS Beagle. Small class four stardrive vessel. Crew of forty seven, commanded by. Jim, I believe you knew him. Captain R M Merik.', 'Different in shape only, Captain. The proportion of land to water is exactly as on your Earth. Density five point five, diameter seven nine one seven at the equator, atmosphere seventy eight percent nitrogen, twenty one percent oxygen. Again, exactly like Earth.', 'I also picked up indications of large cities.', 'No sign of atomic power as yet, but far enough along for radio communications, power transportation, an excellent road system.', 'Television was the colloquial term.', 'Captain, the one described as the barbarian is also listed here. Flight officer William B. Harrison of the SS Beagle. At least there were some survivors down there.', 'But hardly more practical, captain. Close to the city we located, but not populated. We should not be observed.', 'Fascinating. This atmosphere is remarkably similar to your twentieth century. Moderately industrialised pollution containing substantial amounts of carbon monoxide and partially consumed hydrocarbons.', 'Yes, I believe that was the term. I had no idea you were that much of a historian, Doctor.', 'Then the Prime Directive is in full force, Captain?', 'I fail to see the humour in that situation, Doctor.', 'Complete Earth parallel. The language here is English.', 'There would seem to be evidence to that effect.', 'I call them ears.', 'Never. Colloquial twentieth-century English. An amazing parallel.', 'Sir, we came here looking for some friends, forty seven of them who were stranded here some six years ago. They wore clothing similar to ours. Have you heard of such men?', 'Captain, I thought you might find this interesting.', 'Fascinating.', 'Captain, a logical question, if I may. Septimus, how many years ago did Merikus become your first citizen?', 'Curious, Captain, the similarity in names. Were you told why Merik was dropped from the Space Academy?', 'Why, Doctor?', 'Even more fascinating. Slavery evolving into an institution with guaranteed medical payments, old-age pensions.', 'Doctor, if I were able to show emotion, your new infatuation with that term would begin to annoy me.', 'Really, Doctor, I had no idea they were trained. Watching you, I assumed it was trial and error.', 'Interesting, and given a conservative empire, quite understandable.', 'I said I understood it, Doctor. I find the checks and balances of this civilisation quite illuminating.', 'They do seem to have escaped the carnage of your first three world wars, Doctor.', 'Situations quite familiar to the six million who died in your first world war, the eleven million who died in your second, the thirty seven million who died in your third. Shall I go on?', 'Quite correct.', "I tell you I'm well able to defeat you.", 'I do not want to injure you.', 'Need any help, Doctor?', "Such emotions are foreign to me, Doctor. I'm merely testing the strength of the door.", 'Doctor, I am seeking a means of escape. Will you please be brief?', "Yes, that's quite true.", "Oh, yes. You humans have that emotional need to express gratitude. You're welcome, I believe, is the correct response. However, Doctor, you must remember I am entirely motivated by logic. The loss of our ship's surgeon, whatever I think of his skill, would mean a reduction in the efficiency of the Enterprise and therefore", 'Really, Doctor?', 'What did they do to you?', 'I wish we could have examined that belief of his more closely. It seems illogical for a sun worshiper to develop a philosophy of total brotherhood. Sun worship is usually a primitive superstition religion.', 'It will replace their imperial Rome, but it will happen in their twentieth century.']

Captain, no signs of bodies whatsoever. It would have come from planet four, star system eight nine two, directly ahead. SS Beagle. Small class four stardrive vessel. Crew of forty seven, commanded by. Jim, I believe you knew him. Captain R M Merik. Different in shape only, Captain. The proportion of land to water is exactly as on your Earth. I also picked up indications of large cities. No sign of atomic power as yet, but far enough along for radio communications, power transportation, an excellent road system. Television was the colloquial term. Captain, the one described as the barbarian is also listed here. Flight officer William B. Harrison of the SS Beagle. At least there were some survivors down there. But hardly more practical, captain. Close to the city we located, but not populated. We should not be observed. Fascinating. This atmosphere is remarkably similar to your twentieth century. Moderately industrialised pollution containing substantial amounts of carbon monoxide and partially consumed hydrocarbons. Yes, I believe that was the term. I had no idea you were that much of a historian, Doctor. Then the Prime Directive is in full force, Captain? I fail to see the humour in that situation, Doctor. Complete Earth parallel. The language here is English. There would seem to be evidence to that effect. I call them ears. Never. Colloquial twentieth-century English. An amazing parallel. Sir, we came here looking for some friends, forty seven of them who were stranded here some six years ago. They wore clothing similar to ours. Have you heard of such men? Captain, I thought you might find this interesting. Fascinating. Captain, a logical question, if I may. Septimus, how many years ago did Merikus become your first citizen? Curious, Captain, the similarity in names. Were you told why Merik was dropped from the Space Academy? Why, Doctor? Even more fascinating. Slavery evolving into an institution with guaranteed medical payments, old-age pensions. Doctor, if I were able to show emotion, your new infatuation with that term would begin to annoy me. Really, Doctor, I had no idea they were trained. Watching you, I assumed it was trial and error. Interesting, and given a conservative empire, quite understandable. I said I understood it, Doctor. I find the checks and balances of this civilisation quite illuminating. They do seem to have escaped the carnage of your first three world wars, Doctor. Situations quite familiar to the six million who died in your first world war, the eleven million who died in your second, the thirty seven million who died in your third. Shall I go on? Quite correct. I tell you I'm well able to defeat you. I do not want to injure you. Need any help, Doctor? Such emotions are foreign to me, Doctor. I'm merely testing the strength of the door. Doctor, I am seeking a means of escape. Will you please be brief? Yes, that's quite true. Oh, yes. You humans have that emotional need to express gratitude. You're welcome, I believe, is the correct response. However, Doctor, you must remember I am entirely motivated by logic. The loss of our ship's surgeon, whatever I think of his skill, would mean a reduction in the efficiency of the Enterprise and therefore Really, Doctor? What did they do to you? I wish we could have examined that belief of his more closely. It seems illogical for a sun worshiper to develop a philosophy of total brotherhood. Sun worship is usually a primitive superstition religion. It will replace their imperial Rome, but it will happen in their twentieth century.

Title: Bread and Circuses
Dialogue: ['Missing for six years, and now this junk in space.', 'Then whatever destroyed the ship, the crew was able to get off safely. Navigator, compute the present drift of the wreckage.', 'Mister Spock, assuming that the wreckage drifted at the same speed and direction for the past six years?', 'Standard orbit around the planet. There may be survivors there.', 'Yes, at the academy. He was dropped in his fifth year. He went into the merchant service.', 'Put it on the screen.', 'Yes, similar. But the land masses and oceans are quite different, however.', 'Exactly in some ways, different in others.', 'What era?', 'Put it on the screen.', 'Slaves and gladiators. What are we seeing, a twentieth-century Rome?', "Ready the transporter room, Mister Spock. We're beaming down.", 'You could have selected a more convenient place, Mister Spock.', 'The SS Beagle was the first ship to make a survey of this star sector when it disappeared.', 'No identification of self or mission. No interference with the social development of said planet.', "Let's go.", 'I think he means it, Spock.', 'We come from another province.', "We come from a place that's quite some journey from here. I doubt if you've heard", 'Do we look like any Romans you ever saw ?', "Our people don't believe in slavery.", "Wait. I can prove we're telling the truth. A small device. I'll take it out slowly. Kirk to Enterprise. Come in.", 'Scotty, lock in on my transmission beam. Scan us.', 'Including ourselves, how many of us are there?', "Good, Scotty. Continue scanning. We'll maintain transmission. Kirk out. The Enterprise is our ship, somewhere at sea. That's all I can tell you. If it isn't sufficient, you will have to kill us.", "Perhaps you've heard, let's say, an impossible story or a rumour of men who came from the sky or from other worlds.", 'The stars.', 'Yes, of course.', 'Spock?', 'The Jupiter Eight. Conventional internal combustion engine. You were right about the smog. But the Jupiter Eight? Mars toothpaste. Neptune bath salts.', 'Septimus, we need your help. We must go into the city. We know that one of our missing friends was seen there recently.', "We can't do that. Perhaps you know his name. Merik. Captain Merik.", "Yes. He's the leader of our friends.", "That doesn't sound like the same man.", 'Septimus, wherever we may be from, you must believe that it is one of our most important laws that none of us interfere with the affairs of others. If Captain Merik is Merikus, then he has violated that law, and he must be taken away and punished. Will you help us get to the truth of all this?', 'He failed a psycho-simulator test. All it takes is a split second of indecision. Hardly the type to become a political strongman.', 'Are you a slave, Flavius?', 'Then you heard the word of the sun?', "There are many things I'd like to know", "Tell Merikus I'd like to see him.", "Tell him it's Jim Kirk. Perhaps a friend.", "Well, if I am a friend and you don't tell him, do you really want to risk that?", "But if there have been slaves for over 2,000 years, hasn't there always been discontent, runaways?", "I'm not sure they're sure. When the slaves began to worship the sun, they became discontent again. When did all this happen?", 'You go on believing it, Flavius. All men are brothers.', 'Three against three. We may never get a better chance.', "I doubt if he'll get very far. He feels ill.", "All right, but he'll double over before we get very far.", "Let's go.", "Captain Merik, isn't it ?", 'I agree.', 'McCoy.', 'All right, what happened?', 'Go on.', 'What happened to your crew? Did they voluntarily beam, come ashore?', 'What happened to your crew?', "My world, proconsul, is my vessel, my oath, my crew. What happened to your vessel you've explained. What happened to your oath is obvious.", 'You sent your own men into the arena?', 'Do you really believe I could be made to order my own people down?', 'Kirk to Enterprise.', 'Scotty, if you have a fix. Stand by, Scotty.', "Yet on the other hand, my chief engineer's standing by for a message.", 'If I brought down a hundred of them armed with phasers', 'Scotty. Sorry to keep you waiting.', "Condition Green, all's well. Kirk out.", 'The rules. If Spock should finish his man off first, would he be able to help', 'Proconsul, in some parts of the galaxy I have seen forms of entertainment that makes this look like a folk dance.', "I've had to select men to die before so that others could be saved.", "It won't work.", "Whatever he has in mind, whatever tricks. You hear that, Proconsul? It won't work. I'm not co-operating. I may die, but you won't get any entertainment out of it.", 'Very good. Excellent.', "I've been in some strange worlds with strange customs. Perhaps this is considered torture here.", "You'll be the first to know.", 'Nothing except perhaps an explanation.', 'I appreciate that.', 'Of course.', 'I thank you. And my friends?', "I've heard it was similar.", 'Stand back.', 'Obsolete, but effective.', 'They threw me a few curves. No time to explain.', 'And strong personal feelings, he obeyed the Prime Directive. His temporary blackout of the city below resulted in no interference with the society and yet saved the lives of myself and the landing party.', 'Gentlemen.', 'Caesar and Christ. They had them both. And the word is spreading only now.', "Wouldn't it be something to watch, to be a part of? To see it happen all over again? Mister Chekov, take us out of orbit. Ahead warp factor one."]
Flattened Dialogue: Missing for six years, and now this junk in space. Then whatever destroyed the ship, the crew was able to get off safely. Navigator, compute the present drift of the wreckage. Mister Spock, assuming that the wreckage drifted at the same speed and direction for the past six years? Standard orbit around the planet. There may be survivors there. Yes, at the academy. He was dropped in his fifth year. He went into the merchant service. Put it on the screen. Yes, similar. But the land masses and oceans are quite different, however. Exactly in some ways, different in others. What era? Put it on the screen. Slaves and gladiators. What are we seeing, a twentieth-century Rome? Ready the transporter room, Mister Spock. We're beaming down. You could have selected a more convenient place, Mister Spock. The SS Beagle was the first ship to make a survey of this star sector when it disappeared. No identification of self or mission. No interference with the social development of said planet. Let's go. I think he means it, Spock. We come from another province. We come from a place that's quite some journey from here. I doubt if you've heard Do we look like any Romans you ever saw ? Our people don't believe in slavery. Wait. I can prove we're telling the truth. A small device. I'll take it out slowly. Kirk to Enterprise. Come in. Scotty, lock in on my transmission beam. Scan us. Including ourselves, how many of us are there? Good, Scotty. Continue scanning. We'll maintain transmission. Kirk out. The Enterprise is our ship, somewhere at sea. That's all I can tell you. If it isn't sufficient, you will have to kill us. Perhaps you've heard, let's say, an impossible story or a rumour of men who came from the sky or from other worlds. The stars. Yes, of course. Spock? The Jupiter Eight. Conventional internal combustion engine. You were right about the smog. But the Jupiter Eight? Mars toothpaste. Neptune bath salts. Septimus, we need your help. We must go into the city. We know that one of our missing friends was seen there recently. We can't do that. Perhaps you know his name. Merik. Captain Merik. Yes. He's the leader of our friends. That doesn't sound like the same man. Septimus, wherever we may be from, you must believe that it is one of our most important laws that none of us interfere with the affairs of others. If Captain Merik is Merikus, then he has violated that law, and he must be taken away and punished. Will you help us get to the truth of all this? He failed a psycho-simulator test. All it takes is a split second of indecision. Hardly the type to become a political strongman. Are you a slave, Flavius? Then you heard the word of the sun? There are many things I'd like to know Tell Merikus I'd like to see him. Tell him it's Jim Kirk. Perhaps a friend. Well, if I am a friend and you don't tell him, do you really want to risk that? But if there have been slaves for over 2,000 years, hasn't there always been discontent, runaways? I'm not sure they're sure. When the slaves began to worship the sun, they became discontent again. When did all this happen? You go on believing it, Flavius. All men are brothers. Three against three. We may never get a better chance. I doubt if he'll get very far. He feels ill. All right, but he'll double over before we get very far. Let's go. Captain Merik, isn't it ? I agree. McCoy. All right, what happened? Go on. What happened to your crew? Did they voluntarily beam, come ashore? What happened to your crew? My world, proconsul, is my vessel, my oath, my crew. What happened to your vessel you've explained. What happened to your oath is obvious. You sent your own men into the arena? Do you really believe I could be made to order my own people down? Kirk to Enterprise. Scotty, if you have a fix. Stand by, Scotty. Yet on the other hand, my chief engineer's standing by for a message. If I brought down a hundred of them armed with phasers Scotty. Sorry to keep you waiting. Condition Green, all's well. Kirk out. The rules. If Spock should finish his man off first, would he be able to help Proconsul, in some parts of the galaxy I have seen forms of entertainment that makes this look like a folk dance. I've had to select men to die before so that others could be saved. It won't work. Whatever he has in mind, whatever tricks. You hear that, Proconsul? It won't work. I'm not co-operating. I may die, but you won't get any entertainment out of it. Very good. Excellent. I've been in some strange worlds with strange customs. Perhaps this is considered torture here. You'll be the first to know. Nothing except perhaps an explanation. I appreciate that. Of course. I thank you. And my friends? I've heard it was similar. Stand back. Obsolete, but effective. They threw me a few curves. No time to explain. And strong personal feelings, he obeyed the Prime Directive. His temporary blackout of the city below resulted in no interference with the society and yet saved the lives of myself and the landing party. Gentlemen. Caesar and Christ. They had them both. And the word is spreading only now. Wouldn't it be something to watch, to be a part of? To see it happen all over again? Mister Chekov, take us out of orbit. Ahead warp factor one.

Title: Bread and Circuses
Dialogue: ['The word was smog.', 'I am not, Mister Spock. I was simply trying to stop you from giving us a whole lecture on the subject. Jim, is there anything at all we know about this planet?', 'No references to space, or the fact that there are other worlds, or more advanced civilisations.', "One, just once, I'd like to be able to land someplace and say, Behold, I am the Archangel Gabriel.", 'Naturally. You could hardly claim to be an angel with those pointed ears, Mister Spock. But say you landed someplace with a pitchfork.', 'For which we are grateful, for we are men of peace ourselves.', "Well, if you're speaking of worships of sorts, we represent many beliefs.", 'Odd that these people should worship the sun.', 'Because, my dear Mister Spock, it is illogical. Rome had no sun worshipers. Why should they parallel Rome in every way except one?', "Quite logical, I'd say, Mister Spock. Just as it's logical that twentieth-century Rome would use television to show its gladiator contests or name a new car the Jupiter Eight.", 'What term? Logic? Medical men are trained in logic, Mister Spock.', 'I do?', "No, I think I can walk. I'll try.", 'Are you out of your head?', "Next he'll be telling us he prefers it over Earth history.", 'They have slavery, gladiatorial games, despotism.', "You must know that's impossible. Starfleet regulations", 'Jim.', 'Must you always be so blasted honest?', 'I am defending myself!', 'Whatever gave you that idea?', 'You tell him, buster. Of all the completely ridiculous, illogical questions I ever heard in my life!', 'Angry, Mister Spock, or frustrated, perhaps?', "For the fifteenth time. Spock. Spock, I know we've had our disagreements. Maybe they're jokes. I don't know. As Jim says, we're not often sure ourselves sometimes, but what I'm trying to say is", "Well, what I'm trying to say is you saved my life in the arena.", "I'm trying to thank you, you pointed-eared hobgoblin!", "Do you know why you're not afraid to die, Spock? You're more afraid of living. Each day you stay alive is just one more day you might slip and let your human half peek out. That's it, isn't it? Insecurity. Why, you wouldn't know what to do with a genuine, warm, decent feeling.", "I know. I'm worried about Jim, too.", 'Jim!', 'What happened, Jim?', 'Captain, I see on your report Flavius was killed. I am sorry. I liked that huge sun worshiper.', 'A philosophy of total love and total brotherhood.']

Well, if you're speaking of worships of sorts, we represent many beliefs. Odd that these people should worship the sun. Because, my dear Mister Spock, it is illogical. Rome had no sun worshipers. Why should they parallel Rome in every way except one? Quite logical, I'd say, Mister Spock. Just as it's logical that twentieth-century Rome would use television to show its gladiator contests or name a new car the Jupiter Eight. What term? Logic? Medical men are trained in logic, Mister Spock. I do? No, I think I can walk. I'll try. Are you out of your head? Next he'll be telling us he prefers it over Earth history. They have slavery, gladiatorial games, despotism. You must know that's impossible. Starfleet regulations Jim. Must you always be so blasted honest? I am defending myself! Whatever gave you that idea? You tell him, buster. Of all the completely ridiculous, illogical questions I ever heard in my life! Angry, Mister Spock, or frustrated, perhaps? For the fifteenth time. Spock. Spock, I know we've had our disagreements. Maybe they're jokes. I don't know. As Jim says, we're not often sure ourselves sometimes, but what I'm trying to say is Well, what I'm trying to say is you saved my life in the arena. I'm trying to thank you, you pointed-eared hobgoblin! Do you know why you're not afraid to die, Spock? You're more afraid of living. Title: Bread and Circuses
Dialogue: ['Scott here, Captain.', 'Scanning, sir.', 'Twelve, Captain.', 'Bridge. Scott here.', 'We were becoming concerned, Captain. You were a bit overdue.', "But they have used the code term Condition Green, which means they're in trouble. But it also prohibits my taking any action. Mister Chekov, pinpoint power source locations. Type, power, load factors, and how much our beams will have to pull to overload them.", "Let it take time, lad. They're in trouble, and I'm under orders not to interfere. However, no order can stop me from frightening them. It may do no good, but it may suggest to someone just what a starship can really do. Aye.", 'Now, Mister Chekov. Activate.', 'Enterprise to Captain Kirk. Ready to beam up three.', 'Thank you, Captain.']

Type, power, load factors, and how much our beams will have to pull to overload them. Let it take time, lad. They're in trouble, and I'm under orders not to interfere. Title: Assignment: Earth
Dialogue: ['Transporter room to Captain.', "It appears we have accidentally intercepted someone's transporter beam, Captain.", "It's incredibly powerful.", 'Captain, something is beaming aboard this vessel.', 'The beam is originating at least one thousand light years away.', 'If what he says is true, Captain, every second we delay him could be dangerous.', 'A most difficult decision, Captain.', 'Quite a lovely animal, Captain. I find myself strangely drawn to it.', 'He did say his planet was hidden, Captain.', 'Current Earth crises would fill a tape bank, Captain. There will be an important assassination today, an equally dangerous government coup in Asia, and, this could be highly critical, the launching of an orbital nuclear warhead platform by the United States countering a similar launch by other powers.', 'Most definitely. Once the sky was full of orbiting H-bombs, the slightest mistake could have brought one down by accident, setting off a nuclear holocaust.', 'He might be inclined to prepare a perfect one, Captain. But then again he may be telling the truth.', 'Following him down is a major risk, Captain. If we ourselves do anything that changes history', 'In here, Captain.', "Chances are he's out of sight inside the rocket gantry or at one of the control centres.", "Here, let me help you, Sergeant. It's operated with this dial here.", 'I can try, Captain.', 'I can estimate some of this, Captain, but without more time', 'It is difficult to know which is best, Captain.', 'Without facts, the decision cannot be made logically. You must rely on your human intuition.', 'Correction, Mister Seven. It appears we did not interfere. The Enterprise was part of what was supposed to happen on this day in 1968.', "And you'll be pleased our records show that it resulted in a new and stronger international agreement against the use of such weapons.", 'Captain, we could say that Mister Seven and Miss Lincoln have some interesting experiences in store for them.', 'Live long and prosper, Mister Seven.']

Captain, something is beaming aboard this vessel. The beam is originating at least one thousand light years away. If what he says is true, Captain, every second we delay him could be dangerous. A most difficult decision, Captain. Quite a lovely animal, Captain. I find myself strangely drawn to it. He did say his planet was hidden, Captain. Current Earth crises would fill a tape bank, Captain. There will be an important assassination today, an equally dangerous government coup in Asia, and, this could be highly critical, the launching of an orbital nuclear warhead platform by the United States countering a similar launch by other powers. Most definitely. Once the sky was full of orbiting H-bombs, the slightest mistake could have brought one down by accident, setting off a nuclear holocaust. He might be inclined to prepare a perfect one, Captain. But then again he may be telling the truth. Following him down is a major risk, Captain. If we ourselves do anything that changes history In here, Captain. Chances are he's out of sight inside the rocket gantry or at one of the control centres. Here, let me help you, Sergeant. It's operated with this dial here. I can try, Captain. I can estimate some of this, Captain, but without more time It is difficult to know which is best, Captain. Without facts, the decision cannot be made logically. You must rely on your human intuition. Correction, Mister Seven. It appears we did not interfere. The Enterprise was part of what was supposed to happen on this day in 1968. And you'll be pleased our records show that it resulted in a new and stronger international agreement against the use of such weapons. Captain, we could say that Mister Seven and Miss Lincoln have some interesting experiences in store for them. Live long and prosper, Mister Seven.

Title: Assignment: Earth
Dialogue: ['No transporter beam can reach that far, not even in our century.', "It's locked, it's locked our circuits wide open.", "It's impossible to hide a whole planet.", "Still unable to analyze it, sir. It was so powerful, it fused most of our recording circuits. Could have brought him back through great distances, could have brought him back through time. There's no way for us to know.", 'We can estimate only within a thousand metres or so where he beamed down, Captain.', 'Aye.', 'Locked in. Proceed one nine five degrees true.', 'Correlated. Readings indicate a greater altitude. Approximately thirty metres higher, sir.', 'Proceed five metres, two four seven degrees true.', "There's an old-style weather satellite in orbit below us. If I could bounce off it, I could get some good views. I've got it.", 'I could get even closer. If I could spot him, I could lock on and beam him up.', 'Security, send two men up here right away.', "Stand by. I'm going to beam him up.", 'I had him and something yanked him away.', 'Scott here.', "I've got to risk calling the captain. Lieutenant Uhura, open a channel.", 'Captain, can you read me? I was beaming up Mister Seven, and something yanked him away from me.', 'Captain, monitors show all major powers on full missile alert. Retaliatory strike ordered on warhead impact.']

There's no way for us to know. We can estimate only within a thousand metres or so where he beamed down, Captain. Aye. Locked in. Proceed one nine five degrees true. Correlated. A hunch, Captain?

Title: Spock's Brain
Dialogue: ['Range forty three thousand and closing.', 'Aye, sir. Thirty eight thousand and closing.', 'System Sigma Draconis.', 'Nothing, sir.', 'Aye, Captain.', 'Sun, spectral type, Gamma nine. Nine planets, three of them, Class M possessing sapient life according to reports and long-range scanning.', 'The one on the left, number three, rates letter B on the industrial scale.', 'Yes, sir. Second planet Class M, number four, rates letter G.', 'Number six. No sign of industrial development. At last report, in a Glacial Age. Sapient life plentiful, but on a most primitive level.', 'Yes, sir.', 'No, sir.', 'Yes, sir.', 'Yes, sir.', 'No sign of organised civilisation. Primitive humanoids picked up at irregular intervals.', "I can't explain it, sir.", "Sigma Draconis Three. It's closest, heaviest population.", 'None of these planets could.', 'Several thousand years at least. Only the tropical zone is ice-free.', 'What if you guess wrong, Captain?', 'No structures, Captain. No mechanised objects that I can read. No surface consumption or generation of energy. Atmosphere is perfectly all right, of course. Temperature, a high maximum of forty. Livable.', "Captain, five hundred metres in that direction there's a foundation under the surface. A huge one. Registrations all over the place.", 'Yes, sir. Immensely old, completely buried. But they were here once.', 'What could the Others do to cause such terror?', 'A peculiar mixture.', "And the male humanoid who doesn't know the meaning of the word female.", "If it will trap the creatures for the Others, Captain, won't it trap us, too?", 'Aye, sir.', 'It might be a long wait. We may as well be comfortable.']
Flattened Dialogue: Range forty three thousand and closing. Aye, sir. Thirty eight thousand and closing. System Sigma Draconis. Nothing, sir. Aye, Captain. Sun, spectral type, Gamma nine. Nine planets, three of them, Class M possessing sapient life according to reports and long-range scanning. The one on the left, number three, rates letter B on the industrial scale. Yes, sir. Second planet Class M, number four, rates letter G. Number six. No sign of industrial development. At last report, in a Glacial Age. Sapient life plentiful, but on a most primitive level. Yes, sir. No, sir. Yes, sir. Yes, sir. No sign of organised civilisation. Primitive humanoids picked up at irregular intervals. I can't explain it, sir. Sigma Draconis Three. It's closest, heaviest population. None of these planets could. Several thousand years at least. Only the tropical zone is ice-free. What if you guess wrong, Captain? No structures, Captain. No mechanised objects that I can read. No surface consumption or generation of energy. Atmosphere is perfectly all right, of course. Temperature, a high maximum of forty. Livable. Captain, five hundred metres in that direction there's a foundation under the surface. A huge one. Registrations all over the place. Yes, sir. Immensely old, completely buried. But they were here once. What could the Others do to cause such terror? A peculiar mixture. And the male humanoid who doesn't know the meaning of the word female. If it will trap the creatures for the Others, Captain, won't it trap us, too? Aye, sir. It might be a long wait. We may as well be comfortable.

Title: Spock's Brain
Dialogue: ['What do you read, Mister Spock?', 'Any contact, Lieutenant?', 'Keep trying.', 'Magnification ten, Mister Chekov.', 'Well, Scotty?', 'Interesting design.', 'Life forms, Mister Spock?', 'Directed at what?', 'Security guard.', "I'm Captain James Kirk. This is the Starship Enterprise.", 'Helm status, Mister Sulu.', 'Condition reports from all decks, Lieutenant.', "Spock. Where's Spock?", 'Yes, what is it?', 'All right. On my way.', 'Spock. What happened?', 'Like this?', 'What happened?', "You've got him on complete life support. Was he dead?", 'What do you mean?', "Come on, Bones. What's the mystery?", 'His what?', 'How could he survive?', 'If his brain is missing, then Spock is dying.', 'That girl.', "From that ship. She took it. I don't know why, or where, but she must have taken it. Bones, how long can you keep him functioning?", "That's not good enough, Doctor.", "Then we'll take him with us.", 'In search of his brain, Doctor. From what you say, the moment we find it we must restore it to his body, or we lose him.', "I'll find it.", 'It was taken out. It can be put back in.', "The thief that took it has the knowledge. I'll force it out of her.", 'You and Scotty have Spock ready.', 'Where does the trail lead to?', 'Lock on, Mister Sulu. Maximum speed.', 'No question about the trail?', 'All scanners, extreme sweep.', 'Well?', "We've lost her trail, but she went into that system. Mister Chekov, put a schematic of Sigma Draconis on the screen.", 'Read out, Mister Chekov?', "She was breathing our air. She must've gone to one of them. Show us the three Class-M planets. Mister Chekov.", 'Earth equivalent approximately 1485.', 'The year 2030.', 'Third Class M planet, Mister Chekov.', 'Now. as I understand it, Mister Chekov, there are three Class-M planets,', 'Not one of which is capable of launching an interstellar flight,', 'Yet one of them accomplished it.', 'Thank you, Mister Chekov.', "That's the primitive glaciated planet.", 'The source of it?', 'What do your surface readings show, Mister Chekov?', 'With regular pulsations of generated energy?', "I can't afford to guess wrong. I've got to choose the right planet, get there, find the brain. Eight hours and thirty five minutes.", 'Recommendations, Mister Chekov.', "But advanced ion propulsion is beyond even our capabilities. It'd be a miracle if they had developed it.", 'Yes.', 'Yes. Why would they want it? Eight hours and thirty four minutes. Planet six is glaciated, you say?', "But the energy. Regular. It's there. It's real.", "Have the transporter room stand by. I'm taking a landing party down to planet six.", 'A hunch, Mister Sulu.', 'If I guess wrong, Mister Spock is dead. Spock will die.', 'Suit temperatures to seventy two. Life-form readings, Mister Spock? Mister Scott?', 'Watch out. We know their development is primitive.', 'Read out, Mister Chekov.', 'You have a thick skin.', 'Phasers on stun. I want them conscious.', 'Fire only on my signal. Flank out.', "We mean you no harm. We're not your enemies, we're your friends. We only wish to talk to you.", 'No. We come from a far place. We are men.', 'Like yourselves.', 'Who are the Others?', 'Do they live here with you?', 'Do they come from the sky?', 'Do they come for your women as well?', 'The female of your kind.', "Don't you have a mate?", 'Will you take us where we can find the Others?', "We do. We want to find them. Take us there and we'll let you go.", 'Buildings?', 'Somewhere down there is where the Others live. Scotty, see if you can find a way down.', "It's all right.", "It's all right. Let him go.", 'What was it he said, pain and delight?', 'A dead and buried city on a planet in a glacial age.', "I don't think so. Scotty.", "Metal. Forged, tempered. Our apish friends didn't make these. What do you think?", 'Or the food could be a lure set by the Others to bring them in here.', 'And this cave a trap.', 'Exactly.', 'Kirk to Enterprise.', 'Have Doctor McCoy beam down immediately.', "Mister Chekov, you and the security team will remain here at the entrance. We'll be in constant contact with you.", 'All right, Bones. Bring him along.', 'Ready?', 'Phasers on stun.', 'A lot of it?', 'What source?', 'Or what?', "We're slowing down.", 'Is she all right?', "Who's in charge? I wish to speak to him.", "What have you done with Spock's brain? Where've you taken it?", "You're lying!", 'See what you can pick up on your communicator.', "We don't want to hurt you. What is this place?", 'Who are you?', 'Spock, is that you?', 'Yes, Spock. Yes.', "We'll get you, Spock. It won't be long.", 'Quickly!', "There she is. That's the one. What have you done with Spock's brain?", "What have you done with Spock's brain?", 'This is Spock. You saw him on the ship. You have his brain. It must be restored to him immediately. What have you done with it?', 'I do not know about Luma, but you were on the Enterprise. I saw you.', 'You came to my ship!', 'I saw you on my ship.', "No, it doesn't.", "Sorry. We don't want to hurt anyone.", "No. We'll stay here and learn about you and tell you of us.", 'I wish to talk to those in charge.', 'Yes, the organisers, the managers. The leader of your people.', 'Who controls this complex?', 'Yes, the Controller. The Controller. Who controls? I would like to meet, to see him.', 'We intend no harm.', 'No, no, no. I promise you.', "Bones. Scotty. Spock's brain controls", 'Great leader. Great leader! We come from a far place to learn from your Controller.', 'He is our friend. You must take us to him. We beg you. Soon it will be too late.', 'You must take us.', 'I never felt anything like that. Every nerve in my body was on fire.', 'No wonder the Morgs are so obedient, and terrified.', "How is this place kept functioning by the primitive minds we've met?", 'They were smart enough to invent these training devices. What a way to maintain control over a man.', 'Yes, I certainly did notice those delightful aspects. But that too was strictly under command of the women.', 'With a communicator, we might be able to find out. This fellow is keeping us from our property.', 'I certainly think that science might provide an answer.', 'Agreed, Doctor.', 'Science will triumph. Come on, Scotty. Bones, give them something to keep them out for a while. Spock. Spock. Come on, Spock. Spock, you were on this frequency, Spock.', 'No. We might be able to locate you, if you gave us some idea of what they were using you for. Is it medical?', "Spock, we don't have time for that.", 'We came to put you back. Where are you?', 'Back into your body. We brought it along with us.', "The skill to remove it exists right where we are. Restoring it must also be possible. That's why we've got to get to you as quickly as we can.", 'Eighteen hours and twelve minutes.', 'That leaves us exactly five hours and forty eight minutes, Spock.', "Yes. Very brief. That's why we must get to you immediately. Beam us a signal so we can home in on you.", 'Bones.', 'Oh, Spock, one question.', "We've got pain-giving devices attached to us. Can you tell us how to get them off.", 'Oh, yes it does, Spock. Keep concentrating, Spock. Keep concentrating, Spock.', "You'll find another Controller.", "Spock, you're in a black box tied in with light rays into a complex control panel.", "You say you're breathing, pumping blood, maintaining temperature? Is it possible that you're re-circulating air, running heating plants, purifying water?", 'He will not stay. Now, you took his brain. You will put it back. How did you do it?', 'She was on the Enterprise. She must have done it. How did you do it?', 'How do you get the old knowledge?', 'What is the Teacher?', 'How does it work? Show us.', 'You must tell us.', "How does it work? Show us! We'll protect you.", "We're not the first to bring you the knowledge of killing. If you continue, you'll kill Spock.", "But Spock will be dead. His body's dying this minute.", 'No one may kill a man. Not for any purpose. It cannot be condoned.', "You must help us. When you came to the ship, you had the knowledge. Yet, when we came here, you didn't.", 'How long does the knowledge last?', "If you had the knowledge, could you restore what you've taken?", 'You must help us. You must restore with that knowledge what you have taken.', 'You must put back what you have taken.', 'Go ahead, Doctor. Put the Teacher on.', "No. You won't be destroyed. You'll be without your Controller for the first time, but you'll be much better off, I think.", "No, you'll live and develop as you should have. All this shouldn't have been done for you. Now the women here below and the men here above will control together.", "There are other ways. You'll discover them. You must move to the surface, you understand.", "No, you won't. You'll learn to build houses, to keep warm, to work. We'll help you for a while. Humans have survived under worse conditions. It's a matter of evolution. You'll be fine.", 'What is it?', 'Bones? Bones?', "Bones, you can't stop now.", 'Bones?', "You could. A while ago it was child's play.", 'Well?', 'Well?', 'How do you feel, Spock?', "What's that?", 'Well, we took the risk, Doctor.']

Title: Spock's Brain
Dialogue: ['Configuration unidentified. Ion propulsion, high velocity, though of a unique technology.', 'One. Humanoid or similar. Low level of activity. Life-support systems functioning. Interior atmosphere, conventional nitrogen-oxygen. Instruments indicate a transferal beam emanating from the area of the humanoid life form.', 'Directed at the Bridge of the Enterprise, Captain.', 'Fascinating. Activity without end, but with no volition.', 'Captain? Captain Kirk?', 'Captain, there is a definite pleasurable experience connected with the hearing of your voice.', 'Is that you, Doctor McCoy, and are you with the Captain?', 'Engineer Scott as well. Unfortunately, I do not know where I am.', 'A practical idea, Captain. It seems unlikely that I shall be able to get to you.', 'Yes, Captain, I am still here. Have you returned to the Enterprise?', 'I am not certain. I seem to have a body which stretches into infinity.', 'Then what am l?', 'Fascinating. It could explain much, Doctor. My medulla oblongata is hard at work apparently breathing, apparently pumping blood, apparently maintaining a normal physiologic temperature.', 'Why are you endangering your lives by coming here?', 'Back where?', 'Thoughtful, Captain, but probably impractical. While I might trust the doctor to remove a splinter or lance a boil, I do not believe he has the knowledge to restore a brain.', 'No denigration intended, Doctor McCoy. That skill does not yet exist in the galaxy.', 'Captain, I appreciate the risks you are taking on my behalf, but I must insist they are worthwhile only if there is a reasonable chance for success. Let me ask you, how much time has elapsed since', "Doctor McCoy must've told you that twenty four hours is the maximum my body can", 'It does seem all too brief a time to develop such skills, does it not?', 'Acknowledged.', 'Yes, Captain.', 'I shall give it top priority.', 'Captain, I have an answer for you. It seems your pain bands are manually controlled. The red button on a bracelet releases them. I know that does not make much sense.', 'How very flattering.', 'Fascinating.', 'Indeed, Captain. That is unquestionably part of what I am doing.', 'If I may explain, Captain. She refers to the tape storehouse of knowledge of the builders of this place. I scan it. A most impressive store.', 'It is a device with feeding circuits. They lead into the mind of the priestess leader. Its use is strictly predetermined by the builders.', 'She is an alien. The configurations of her brain are different. It could cause irreparable damage to your human brain, Doctor.', 'Captain, you might lose the doctor that way.', 'I cannot allow you to jeopardise your life for me.', 'Yes. Doctor McCoy.', 'If you will finish reconnecting my speech centre, I might be able to help.', "Yes. That's correct. One thing at a time. Ah, ah, mmm. That's better. Now, Doctor. Try the sonic separator.", 'Yes, I believe I already have some sensation of feeling. Please stimulate the nerve endings and observe the physical reactions, one by one. In each case, I shall tell you when the probe is correct. You will then seal using the tri-laser connector.', 'Ready.', 'Correct.', 'Correct.', 'Correct. Very good, Doctor.', 'Congratulations, Doctor. And thank you.', 'On the whole, Captain, I believe I am quite fit. Fascinating. A remarkable example of a retrograde civilisation. At the peak, advanced beyond any of our capabilities and now operating at this primitive level which you saw. And it all began thousands of years ago when a glacial age reoccurred. This underground complex was developed for the women. The men remained above, and a male-female schism took place. A fascinating cultural development of a kind which never', "As I was saying, a fascinating cultural development of the kind which hasn't been seen in ages. The last such occurrence took place on old Earth, when the Romans were warring with the ...."]

Yes, I believe I already have some sensation of feeling. Please stimulate the nerve endings and observe the physical reactions, one by one. In each case, I shall tell you when the probe is correct.
